Praefatio.	Preface.
Postquam compleui uobis o Filii, librum hunc, qui est postremus scientiae in medicina cum complemento ipsius, et consecutus sum finem in eo, ex expositionibus eius, et ipsius declarationibus, uisum est mihi, ut compleam ipsum uobis cum hoc Tractatu qui est pars operationis, id est, chirurgiae cum manu.	After I completed this book for you, O Sons, which is the last [book] of medical science with its completion, and I achieved its end through its expositions and explanations, it seemed right to me to complete it for you with this Treatise which is the part about operation, that is, surgery by hand.
Quoniam operatio cum manu prostrata est in regione nostra, et tempore nostro priuata omnino: donec fortasse periit scientia eius, et abscissum est uestigium eius: et non remanserunt ex ea, nisi descriptiones paruae in libris antiquorum, quas mutauerunt manus: et accidit eis error et haesitatio, donec clausae sunt intentiones eius, et elongata est uis ipsius: Visum est mihi, ut uiuificem eam cum ordinatione huius Tractatus in ea secundum uiam ex positionis, et declarationis, et abbreuiationis: et ut ueniam cum formis ferramentorum Cauterii, et reliquorum instrumentorum operis: cum fit ex declarationis additione, et ex properatione eius quod est necesse.	Since operation by hand has been laid low in our region, and in our time is entirely absent: until perhaps its science has perished, and its trace has been cut off: and nothing remained of it, except small descriptions in the books of the ancients, which hands have altered: and error and uncertainty befell them, until its purposes were closed off, and its power was diminished: It seemed right to me to revive it with the arrangement of this Treatise according to the way of exposition, and declaration, and abbreviation: and to present the forms of cautery instruments, and other instruments of the work: as it comes from the addition of explanation, and from the hastening of what is necessary.
Caussa autem propter quam non inuenitur bonus artifex eius cum manu sua in hoc nostro tempore, est: quia ars medicinae est longa, et oportet auctorem eius exercitari ante illud in scientia anatomiae, quam narrauit Galenus, donec sciat iuuamenta membrorum, et ipsorum formas, et eorum coniunctionem, et separationem, et habeat cognitionem ossium, et neruorum, et lacertorum, et numerum ipsorum, et eorum egressionem, et uenarum pulsatilium, et quietarum, et locorum exitus earum.	The reason why a good practitioner of it with his hand is not found in this time of ours, is: because the art of medicine is long, and its author needs to be exercised beforehand in the science of anatomy, which Galen narrated, until he knows the uses of the limbs, and their forms, and their connections, and separation, and has knowledge of bones, and nerves, and muscles, and their number, and their exits, and of the pulsing and quiet veins, and their places of exit.
Et propter illud dixit Hippocrates, quod nomen cum nomine est multum, et cum opere est paucum, et praecipue in arte manus.	And because of that Hippocrates said, that the name with the name is much, but with work is little, and especially in the art of the hand.
Nos uero iam diximus de illo in introitu huius libri.	We indeed have already spoken about that in the introduction of this book.
Quoniam qui non est sciens, quod diximus de anatomia, non euacuatur, quin iam cadat in errorem, quo interficiuntur homines: sicut ego uidi multos ex illis, qui formantur de hac scientia, et iactant se de ea absque scientia, et sine experimento.	Since whoever is not knowing what we said about anatomy, cannot avoid falling into error, by which men are killed: as I saw many of those, who are formed of this science, and boast about it without knowledge, and without experience.
Quod est, quia uidi medicum stolidum secuisse apostema scrophulosum in collo mulieris, et incidit quasdam arterias in collo: quare fluxit sanguis mulieris, donec cecidit mortua inter manus eius.	Which is, because I saw a foolish physician who cut a scrofulous abscess in a woman's neck, and cut certain arteries in the neck: wherefore the woman's blood flowed, until she fell dead between his hands.
Et uidi medicum alium, qui praesumpsit ut extraheret lapidem uiro, qui processerat in aetate, et lapis erat magnus.	And I saw another physician, who presumed to extract a stone from a man, who had advanced in age, and the stone was large.
Peruenit ergo ad eum, et extraxit ipsum cum frusto uesicae.	He therefore reached it, and extracted it with a piece of the bladder.
Quare mortuus est uir in tertio die.	Wherefore the man died on the third day.
Et ego quidem iam uocatus fueram ad extrahendum ipsum: et uidi ex magnitudine lapidis, et dispositione infirmi, quod moriretur.	And I indeed had already been called to extract it: and I saw from the size of the stone, and the condition of the patient, that he would die.
Et uidi medicum alium, qui accipiebat stipem apud quendam Ducum terrae nostrae propter medicinam: et accidit eunucho nigro, qui erat apud ipsum, fractura in crure eius prope calcaneum: et properauit medicus cum ignorantia sua, et strinxit fracturam super uulnus cum puluinaribus, et astellis strictura forti, et non dimisit uulneri expirationem.	And I saw another physician, who accepted payment from one of the Dukes of our land for medicine: and it happened to a black eunuch, who was with him, that there was a fracture in his leg near the heel: and the physician hastened with his ignorance, and bound the fracture over the wound with cushions, and splints with strong binding, and did not allow the wound to breathe.
Deinde absoluit eum secundum desyderia sua.	Then he released him according to his desires.
Postea dimisit eum diebus aliquot, et praecepit ei, ne solueret ligamentum: et stetit sic donec apostematum est crus eius, et ipsius pes, et peruenit ad perditionem.	Then he left him for several days, and ordered him not to loosen the bandage: and it remained thus until his leg became swollen, and his foot, and came to destruction.
Vocatus sum ergo ad eum: et properaui ad soluendum ligamentum: et consecuta est tranquillitas, et euasit a doloribus suis.	Therefore I was called to him: and I hurried to loosen the bandage: and tranquility followed, and he escaped from his pains.
Verumtamen corruptio iam confirmata erat in membro: et non potui refraenare ipsam.	However, corruption was already confirmed in the limb: and I could not restrain it.
Pon ergo cessauit corruptio perambulare in membro, donec periit.	Therefore the corruption did not cease to spread in the limb, until it perished.
Et uidi medicum alium, qui perforauit apostema cancerosum: et ulceratum est post dies, donec magnificata est malicia eius cum domino ipsius.	And I saw another physician, who pierced a cancerous abscess: and it became ulcerated after days, until its malignancy increased with its owner.
Quod est, quia quando est cancer purus ex humore melancholico, tunc non oportet ut perueniatur ad eum cum ferro omnino, nisi sit in membro quod toleret, ut abscindatur totum eius.	Which is because when cancer is pure from melancholic humor, then one should not approach it with iron at all, unless it is in a limb that can tolerate having all of it cut off.
Et propter illud o Filii, necesse est uobis, ut sciatis, quod operatio cum manu diuiditur in duas diuisiones: scilicet, operationem cui associatur salus: et operationem, cum qua est periculum in pluribus dispositionibus.	And because of that, O Sons, it is necessary for you to know that operation by hand is divided into two divisions: namely, operation associated with health: and operation with which there is danger in most conditions.
Et ego iam excitaui in omni loco huius libri, in quo uenit operatio, in qua est terror et timor.	And I have already warned in every place of this book where an operation occurs in which there is terror and fear.
Quare necesse est uobis, ut caueatis illud, et dimitatis ipsum: ut non inueniant stolidi uiam ad loquendum, et dehonestandum.	Therefore it is necessary for you to beware of that and leave it alone: so that fools may not find a way to speak and dishonor.
Accipite ergo mensuram cum sollicitudine et protectione, et infirmos uestros cum facilitate et firmitudine, et utimini uia meliore perducente gratia Dei ad salutem et successionem laudabilem: et dimittite aegritudines terribiles difficilis sanationis: et tollite animas uestras ab eo quod facit uos timere, ut ingrediatur super uos haesitatio in fide uestra et commodo uestro.	Therefore take measure with care and protection, and your patients with ease and firmness, and use the better way leading by God's grace to health and praiseworthy success: and leave terrible diseases of difficult healing: and remove your souls from that which makes you fear, lest hesitation enter upon you in your faith and your benefit.
Est enim magis remanens ad gloriam uestram, et sublimius in mundo isto, et postremo ad quantitates uestras.	For it is more remaining to your glory, and more sublime in this world, and finally to your measures.
Galenus enim iam dixit in quibusdam suis admonitionibus.	For Galen has already said in some of his admonitions.
Non medicetis aegritudinem malam: ne nominemini medici mali.	Do not treat a bad disease: lest you be named bad physicians.
Iam autem diuisi hunc Tractatum secundum tria Capitula. ¶	I have already divided this Treatise according to three Chapters. ¶
Capitulum primum.	Chapter First.
De Cauterio cum igne, et Cauterio cum medicina acuta, capitulatum, et ordinatum a capite usque ad pedes, et formis instrumentorum, et ferramentis Cauterii: et omni quod necessarium est in operatione. ¶	On Cautery with fire, and Cautery with sharp medicine, chaptered, and ordered from head to feet, and forms of instruments, and iron tools of Cautery: and everything that is necessary in operation. ¶
Capitulum secundum.	Chapter Second.
De sectione et perforatione, phlebotomia et uentosis, et uulneribus: et extractione sagittarum, et similibus illius: et totum capitulatum, ordinatum formis instrumentorum. ¶	On cutting and perforation, bloodletting and cupping, and wounds: and extraction of arrows, and similar to that: and all chaptered, ordered with forms of instruments. ¶
Capitulum tertium.	Chapter Third.
De restauratione, et dislocatione, et curatione torsionis, et similibus illius: capitulatum, ordinatum a capite usque ad pedes, et formis instrumentorum.	On restoration, and dislocation, and treatment of torsion, and similar to that: chaptered, ordered from head to feet, and forms of instruments.
Soli Deo Gloria.	Glory to God Alone.
Liber Chirurgici Albucasis.	The Surgical Book of Albucasis.
Pars I.	Part I.
¶ De Iuuamento, et Nocumento Cauterii: et quibus complexionibus conueniat, et quo tempore: et si cum ferro, uel auro.	¶ On the Benefit and Harm of Cautery: and which complexions it suits, and at what time: and whether with iron or gold.
Caput I.	Chapter I.
Sed Ante Quidem Quam rememorer operationis cum eo, oportet ut dicam qualitatem Iuuamentorum eius, et Nocumentorum ipsius: et in qua complexione exhibeatur.	But Before Indeed I recall operation with it, it is necessary that I speak of the quality of its Benefits, and of its Harms: and in which complexion it should be administered.
Dico ergo, quod sermo de qualitate iuuamenti Cauterii, et nocumenti eius, est sermo prolixus, et subtilis, scientia, et secretum occultum.	I say therefore, that discourse on the quality of the benefit of Cautery, and its harm, is a lengthy discourse, and subtle, a science, and a hidden secret.
Etiam locuta fuit in eo multitudo sapientum, et dissenserunt in eo: et mihi quidem sufficit parum ex sermonibus eorum, timens prolongationem.	Indeed many wise men have spoken about it, and disagreed about it: and for me a little of their discourse suffices, fearing prolongation.
Dico ergo, quod Cauterium confert uniuersaliter omni complexioni, quae est cum materia, et absque materia: excaeptis duabus complexionibus, quae sunt complexio calida absque materia, et complexio sicca absque materia.	I say therefore, that Cautery is universally beneficial for every complexion that is with matter and without matter: except for two complexions, which are the hot complexion without matter, and the dry complexion without matter.
In complexione autem calida et sicca cum materia dissenserunt.	However, regarding the hot and dry complexion with matter, they disagreed.
Quidam enim dixerunt, quod Cauterium iuuatiuum est in ea.	For some said that Cautery is beneficial in it.
Et dixerunt alii contrarium illius, scilicet quod Cauterium non est conueniens in aegritudine, quae est ex caliditate et siccitate: quoniam natura ignis est caliditas: et inconueniens est, ut sanetur ex agritudine calida et sicca, cum calido et sicco.	And others said the opposite of this, namely that Cautery is not suitable in illness which is from heat and dryness: since the nature of fire is heat: and it is unsuitable that a hot and dry illness be cured with something hot and dry.
Et dixit ille qui dicit contrarium illius: quod per Cauterium fit iuuamentum in omni aegritudine calida et sicca, quae accidit in corporibus hominum: quoniam quando tu comparas corpus hominis, et humiditates eius, ad complexionem ignis, inuenis corpus hominis frigidum.	And he who says the opposite of this said: that through Cautery benefit occurs in every hot and dry illness which happens in human bodies: since when you compare the human body, and its humors, to the complexion of fire, you find the human body cold.
Et ego quidem dico per sermonem eius: quia ex perimentum iam detexit mihi illud aliquotiens.	And I indeed say through his discourse: because experiment has already revealed this to me several times.
Verumtamen non oportet, ut ueniat super illud, nisi qui iam probatus est, et exercitatus in capitulo Cauterii exercitio ultimo, et cognouit diuersitatem complexionum hominum, et dispositionem aegritudinum in se ipsis, et caussas earum, et accidentia ipsarum, et spacium temporis earum.	However, none should attempt this unless they have already been tested and trained in the chapter of Cautery with ultimate training, and has known the diversity of human complexions, and the disposition of illnesses in themselves, and their causes, and their symptoms, and their duration.
Ex reliquis autem complexionibus non est super uos timor: et praecipue in aegritudinibus frigidis et humidis.	Concerning the remaining complexions there is no fear upon you: and especially in cold and wet illnesses.
Iam enim conuenerunt omnes medici super eas: et non dissenserunt in iuuamento cum Cauterio in eis.	For all physicians have agreed about these: and they have not disagreed about the benefit with Cautery in them.
Et scitote filii, quod ex secreto curationis per Cauterium cum igne, et bonitate eius super Cauterium cum medicina comburente est: quoniam ignis est simplex, cuius actio non peruenit, nisi ad membrum quod cauterisatur: et non nocet membro alio coniuncto cum eo, nisi nocumento paruo.	And know, sons, that from the secret of treatment by Cautery with fire, and its goodness over Cautery with burning medicine is: since fire is simple, whose action does not reach except to the member that is cauterized: and does not harm another member connected with it, except with small harm.
Medicinae uero comburentis actio peruenit ad illud quod elongatur ex membris: et fortasse facit accidere in membro aegritudinem difficilis sanationis, et fortasse interficit.	But the action of burning medicine reaches that which is distant from the members: and perhaps causes in the member an illness difficult to heal, and perhaps kills.
Ignis autem propter subtilitatem suam et bonitatem substantiae suae, non facit illud, nisi superfluat.	Fire however, because of its subtlety and the goodness of its substance, does not do that, unless it is excessive.
Iam uero innotuit nobis illud per experimentum, propter longitudinem seruitutis et studii cum arte, et stationem super ueritatem rerum: et propter illud excusor a longitudine sermonis.	This has indeed become known to us through experiment, because of long service and study with the art, and standing upon the truth of things: and because of that I am excused from length of discourse.
Et si non esset, quia non licet huic libro meo, afferrem uobis secretum occultum in igne, et qualitatem operationis eius in corporibus expulsionis suae, qua expellit aegritudines sermone philosophico demonstratiuo, qui acueretur a mentibus uestris.	And if it were not that it is not permitted in this book of mine, I would bring you a hidden secret about fire, and the quality of its operation in bodies of its expulsion, by which it expels illnesses with philosophical demonstrative discourse, which would be sharpened by your minds.
Et scitote filii, quod ipsi dissentiunt in tempore, in quo conuenit fieri cauterium, et ponunt melius tempus ueris.	And know, sons, that they disagree about the time in which it is suitable to perform cautery, and they place the best time as spring.
Et ego dico, quod cauterium conuenit in omni tempore: propterea, quod nocumentum accidens propter tempus submergitur in iuuamento, quod attrahitur cum cauterio.	And I say that cauterization is suitable at any time: because the harm that occurs due to timing is outweighed by the benefit that is drawn from cauterization.
Et praecipue si cauterium est propter dolores ex doloribus necessariis, fortibus, festinis, qui non tolerant tarditatem: propterea quod timetur ex eis, quod accidat malicia quae est maior, quam paruum nocumentum intrans propter tempus.	And especially if cauterization is for pains among necessary, severe, urgent pains, which do not tolerate delay: because it is feared from them that harm may occur which is greater than the small harm entering because of timing.
Et non cadat in mentibus uestris o filii illud, quod non extimant, nisi uulgus et stolidi medici, scilicet quod illi aegritudini quae sanatur per cauterium, non est reditio semper: et ponunt illud consequens, et res non est sicut putant: propterea quod cauterium non est, nisi loco medicinae, quae alterat complexionem, et exiccat humiditates quae sunt caussae, quare accidunt dolores.	And do not let it fall into your minds, O sons, that which only the common people and foolish physicians believe, namely that the illness which is cured by cauterization never returns: and they make this a rule, but things are not as they think: because cauterization is nothing but a substitute for medicine, which alters the constitution and dries up the humors which are the causes why pains occur.
Verumtamen cauterium superfluit super medicinam per uelocitatem ualetudinis suae, et uirtutem suae operationis, et uehementiam dominii sui: et possibile est, ut redeat aegritudo hora aliqua temporis secundum complexionem infirmi, et locationem aegritudinis suae, et uirtutem eius: et quod praeparatur in corpore eius ex aggregatione superfluitatum in eo: et quod peruenit ad ipsum in acquisitione sua ex cibis, et similibus illis ex caussis, nisi fit aegritudo, in qua administratur cauterium.	However, cauterization surpasses medicine through the speed of its effectiveness, and the power of its operation, and the vehemence of its dominion: and it is possible that the illness may return at some time according to the constitution of the sick person, and the location of their illness, and its strength: and what is prepared in their body from the accumulation of superfluities in it: and what reaches it in its acquisition from foods, and similar things from causes, unless it is an illness in which cauterization is administered.
Aegritudo subtilis in membro paucarum superfluitatum, et humiditatum, sicut cauterium dentis, propter dolorem, et similia illi, possibile est enim, ut non redeat in eo ille dolor.	A subtle illness in a member with few superfluities and humors, like cauterization of a tooth for pain, and similar to it, it is indeed possible that that pain may not return in it.
Sed illud fit in paucis.	But this happens in few cases.
At uero sermo uulgi iterum, quod cauterium est postremum medicinae, est sermo rectus: non ad illud quod ipsi intendunt in illo: quoniam ipsi credunt, quod non est curatio quae conferat cum medicina, neque cum alio post occasum cauterii.	But again the saying of the common people, that cauterization is the last resort of medicine, is a correct saying: not in the way that they intend it: since they believe that there is no cure that helps with medicine, nor with anything else after the setting of cauterization.
Res autem est econtrario illius, et intentio, quod cauterium est postremum medicinae, non est, nisi quod quando nos administramus modos curationis in aliqua aegritudinum, et non conferunt illae medicinae: deinde administramus in fine rei cauterium, et confert: tunc inde cadit, quod cauterium est postremum mediciuae, non secundum intentionem quam intelligunt uulgus et multistolidorum medicorum.	The matter is actually contrary to that, and the intention that cauterization is the last resort of medicine is nothing but that when we administer modes of treatment in any of the illnesses, and those medicines do not help: then we administer cauterization at the end of the matter, and it helps: then from this it follows that cauterization is the last resort of medicine, not according to the intention which the common people and many foolish physicians understand.
Antiqui autem dixerunt, quod cauterium cum auro est melius, quam cauterium cum ferro: et non dixerunt illud, nisi propter aequalitatem auri, et sublimitatem substantiae suae: et dixerunt, quod non facit pus locus cauterii.	The ancients moreover said that cauterization with gold is better than cauterization with iron: and they did not say that except because of the evenness of gold, and the sublimity of its substance: and they said that the site of cauterization does not produce pus.
Verum non est illud absolute: quoniam ego iam probaui illud, et inueni, quod ipsum non facit illud in quibusdam corporibus absque aliis.	But this is not absolutely true: since I have already tested it, and found that it does not do that in certain bodies as opposed to others.
Et cauterium cum ipso est bonum, et melius quam cum ferro, sicut dixerunt.	And cauterization with it is good, and better than with iron, as they said.
Verumtamen quando tu ignis cauterium in igne ex auro, non declaratur tibi, quando ignitur secundum quantitatem quam uis, propter rubedinem auri: et quando properat ad ipsum frigus, et si addis super ipsum ignitionem, liquescit in igne, et uertitur in laminas.	However when you heat the cautery in fire made from gold, it is not clear to you when it is heated according to the amount that you want, because of the redness of gold: and when cold hurries to it, and if you increase the heating upon it, it melts in the fire, and turns into sheets.
Quare cadit artifex ex illo in occupationem: et propter illud fit Cauterium cum ferro apud nos uelocius et propinquius, ex rectitudine ad operationem.	Therefore the practitioner falls from it into occupation: and because of that cauterization with iron among us is quicker and closer, from correctness to operation.
Et ego quidem iam ordinaui hoc Capitulum in Cauterio, secundum capitula: et ordinaui ea a capite usque ad pedes: ut alleuient quaerenti illud quod uult ex eo.	And I indeed have already arranged this Chapter on Cauterization, according to chapters: and I arranged them from head to feet: so that they might ease for the seeker that which he wants from it.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Caput in commissura coronali.	¶ On the method of cauterizing the Head at the coronal suture.
Caput II.	Chapter II.
Confert hic cauterizatio ad dominium humiditatis et frigiditatis super cerebrum: quae duae sunt caussae sodae, et multitudinis fluxus humorum ex capite ad partes oculorum et aurium, et multitudinis somni, et doloris dentium, et doloris gutturis: et uniuersaliter omnis aegritudinis, quae accidit ex frigiditate, sicut paralisis, et sodae, epilepsiae, et apoplexiae, et similia illis ex aegritudinibus.	Here cauterization helps against the dominion of humidity and coldness over the brain: which two are causes of headache, and abundance of fluid flow from the head to the parts of eyes and ears, and abundance of sleep, and tooth pain, and throat pain: and universally every illness which occurs from coldness, like paralysis, and headaches, epilepsy, and apoplexy, and similar things from illnesses.
Modus cauterizationis est, ut praecipias infirmo: ut euacuetur in primis cum medicina solutiua mundificante caput tribus noctibus, aut quatuor, secundum quod exigit uirtus infirmi, et eius aetas, et consuetudo eius.	The method of cauterization is that you should instruct the sick person: that they should be evacuated first with purgative medicine cleansing the head for three nights, or four, according to what the strength of the sick person requires, and their age, and their custom.
Deinde praecipe ei, ut radi faciat caput suum cum nouacula.	Then command him to have his head shaved with a razor.
Deinde fac eum sedere inter manus tuas quadratum, ita quod iam posuit manus suas super pectus suum.	Then have him sit squarely before you, such that he has placed his hands upon his chest.
Deinde pone radicem palmae tuae super radicem nasi sui inter oculos suos.	Then place the base of your palm above the bridge of his nose between his eyes.
Vbicumque ergo peruenerit digitus tuus medius, signa locum illum cum incausto.	Wherever your middle finger reaches, mark that spot with ink.
Deinde igni Cauterium Oliuare: cuius haec est forma.	Then heat the Olive-shaped Cautery: of which this is the form.
Deinde pone ipsum super locum signatum cum incausto, descensione, qua constringatur manus tua paulatim, et tu reuolues ipsum.	Then place it on the spot marked with ink, descending with your hand gradually restrained, and rotate it.
Deinde leua manum tuam uelociter, et aspicias locum.	Then lift your hand quickly, and examine the spot.
Quod si uides iam detegi ex osse quantitatem capitis alkiel, aut quantitatem zeuherbi, tunc eleua manum tuam.	If you see that a portion of bone the size of an alkiel or a zeuherb has been exposed, then lift your hand.
Et si non, itera manum tuam ferro ipso, aut cum alio ab ipso si infrigidatur: donec uideantur ossa, quae dixi tibi.	And if not, repeat with the same iron, or with another if it has cooled: until you see the bones I told you about.
Deinde sume aliquid ex sale, et solue illud in aqua, et imbibe in ipso cotum, et pone super locum: et dimitte ipsum tribus diebus.	Then take some salt, and dissolve it in water, and soak cotton in it, and place it on the spot: and leave it for three days.
Deinde pone super ipsum cotum imbibitum in butyro, et dimitte illum super locum, donec destruatur eschara ignis.	Then place cotton soaked in butter on it, and leave it on the spot until the fire scab is destroyed.
Deinde cura illud cum unguento tetrapharmacon, usquequo sanetur.	Then treat it with tetrapharmacon ointment until it heals.
Iam dixerunt, quod quanto uulnus plus remanet apertum, emittit pus: quare est melius et magis iuuatiuum.	They have said that the longer the wound remains open, the more pus it releases: therefore it is better and more beneficial.
Et dixerunt quidam eorum, ut cauterizetur cutis usque ad os: et teneatur Cauterium, donec aduratur quiddam spissitudinis ossis.	And some of them said to cauterize the skin down to the bone: and hold the Cautery until some thickness of bone is burned.
Deinde radatur post illud quod adustum est ex osse, deinde curetur.	Then scrape away what has been burned from the bone, then treat it.
Et dicunt alii, quod oportet ut cum cauterio perueniatur ad ultimum, donec imprimat in os impressionem for tem, ita quod cadat os, quod fit sicut forma kirate: aut instrumentum quod mulieres ponunt infuso alphabeti parui: et extimant, quod exspirantur ex hoc loco uapores capitis, et dimittatur uulnus apertum tempore longo.	And others say that one should proceed with the cautery to the ultimate point, until it makes a strong impression in the bone, so that the bone falls away, which becomes like the form of a carat: or the instrument that women use with a small alphabet infusion: and they believe that vapors of the head are expelled from this place, and the wound should be left open for a long time.
Deinde curetur, donec consolidetur.	Then it should be treated until it consolidates.
Mihi autem non uidentur hae duae species Cauterii omnino nisi in quibusdam hominibus secundum uiam timoris.	However, these two types of Cautery do not seem to me at all except in certain people by way of fear.
Et dimittere ipsum, apud me est melius cum salute ipsius.	And leaving it alone, in my opinion, is better for their safety.
Debilitatur enim caput ex solutione continuitatis ipsius naturalis: sicut testificati sumus in reliquis membris: et praecipue quando caput infirmi debile est natura: et species quidem Cauterii prima est magis salua et melior apud me, et ea utor: operare ergo cum ea in salute.	For the head is weakened by the breaking of its natural continuity: as we have witnessed in other limbs: and especially when the patient's head is naturally weak: and indeed the first species of Cautery is safer and better in my opinion, and I use it: therefore operate with it safely.
¶ De modo cauterizandi capitis in dolore totius capitis.	¶ On the method of cauterizing the head for pain in the whole head.
Caput III.	Chapter III.
Quando in toto Capite accidit dolor chronicus: et prolongatur illud in infirmo, et utitur hyeris, et cochiis, et caputpurgiis, et oleis, et empleumatis.	When chronic pain occurs in the whole head: and it persists in the patient, and he uses hieras, and cochias, and head purgatives, and oils, and poultices.
Et praecipue si iam cauterizatum est cauterio uno, quod narrauimus, et non confert ei aliquid ex illis: tunc considera.	And especially if it has already been cauterized with one cautery, which we described, and none of those things helps him: then consider.
Nam si caput infirmi est fortis creationis natura, et non est debile, et inuenit frigus uehemens: tunc cauteriza cum cauterio alio sub illo parum.	For if the patient's head is of strong natural creation, and is not weak, and he experiences severe cold: then cauterize with another cautery slightly below that one.
Deinde cauteriza ipsum super omne cornu capitis sui cauterio, do nec pertranseat cutis, et discooperiatur ex osse quantitas, quam narrauimus.	Then cauterize him over every corner of his head with the cautery, until it passes through the skin, and exposes bone to the quantity we described.
Et cauteriza ipsum cauterio uno in occipitio capitis sui, in loco qui nominatur uas: et est locus in quo ponitur uentosa: et eleua matum tuam in hoc, et non discooperias os.	And cauterize him with one cautery at the back of his head, in the place which is called the vessel: and it is the place where the cupping glass is placed: and lift your hand in this, and do not expose the bone.
Infirmus enim inuenit propter illud dolorem uehementem, et diuersum a dolore reliquorum cauteriorum capitis omnium.	For the patient experiences because of that severe pain, different from the pain of all other cauteries of the head.
Et ego dicam hoc Cauterium in loco suo: et oportet quod sit cauterium, quo cauterizantur cornua capitis, et occiput eius subtilius cauterio, quo cauterizatur medium capitis.	And I will discuss this Cautery in its place: and it is necessary that the cautery, with which the corners of the head and its back are cauterized, be more subtle than the cautery with which the middle of the head is cauterized.
Et haec est forma eius.	And this is its form.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in hemicrania, tam cum medicina adustiua, quam cum ferro.	On the method of cauterizing in migraine, both with burning medicine and with iron.
Caput IIII.	Chapter 4.
Quando accidit in parte capitis dolor et soda, aut extenditur dolor usque ad oculum, et euacuatur cum medicinis mundificantibus caput, et administratur reliqua curatio, quam dixi in diuisionibus aegritudinum, et non confert illud totum: tunc cauterizatio in eo est secundum duos modos: aut cauterizatio cum medicina acuta comburente: aut cum ferro.	When pain occurs in part of the head and migraine, or the pain extends to the eye, and it is evacuated with medicines that cleanse the head, and the remaining treatment that I mentioned in the division of diseases is administered, and all that does not help: then cauterization in it is according to two methods: either cauterization with sharp burning medicine or with iron.
Cauterium autem cum medicina acuta comburente, est, ut accipias dentem unum allii, et excortices ipsum, et abscindas extremitates eius ex duobus lateribus.	Cautery with sharp burning medicine is when you take one clove of garlic, and peel it, and cut off its ends from both sides.
Deinde scinde locum doloris in tempore cum phlebotomo lato, donec fiat in eo locus sub cute, in quo dens capitur.	Then cut the site of pain at the temple with a broad lancet, until there is a space under the skin in which the clove can be held.
Intromitte ergo eum in ipso sub cute, donec occultetur: deinde stringe super ipsum cum puluillo constrictione decenti, et dimitte ipsum quantitate quindecim horarum deinde solue eum, et extrahe allium, et dimitteuulnus duobus diebus, aut tribus: postea pone super ipsum cotum submersum in butyro, donec locus efficiat pus: deinde cura ipsum cum unguento usquequo sanetur.	Therefore insert it under the skin until it is hidden: then bind it with a compress with appropriate pressure, and leave it for about fifteen hours then loosen it, and remove the garlic, and leave the wound for two or three days: afterward place cotton soaked in butter on it, until the site produces pus: then treat it with ointment until it heals.
Et si uis fac illud cum quibusdam medicinis comburentibus, quas ego scripsi in tractatu duodecimo, de Medieinis adurentibus.	And if you wish, do this with certain burning medicines, which I wrote about in the twelfth treatise, concerning burning Medicines.
Cauterizatio uero eius cum ferro, est secundum hunc modum.	But its cauterization with iron is according to this method.
Igni Cauterium, cuius forma haec est.	Heat the Cautery, whose form is this.
Et nominatur Clauilis: quoniam forma capitis eius est sicut forma claui, in quo est quiddam curuitatis, et in medio eius est quaedam eminentia parua.	And it is called Clavilis: because the form of its head is like the form of a nail, in which there is some curvature, and in its middle there is a small protrusion.
Deinde pone ipsum super locum, et retine manum tuam: et tu reuolue ferrum paulatim cum uelocitate: et sit quantitas quae aduritur ex spissitudine cutis, sicut medietas eius.	Then place it on the site, and hold your hand steady: and rotate the iron gradually with speed: and let the amount that is burned of the thickness of the skin be about half of it.
Et eleua manum tuam, ut non aduratur arteria, quae est inferius, et accidat fluxus sanguinis.	And lift your hand, so that the artery which is below is not burned, and bleeding occurs.
Deinde imbibe cotum in aqua salis, et pone super locum, et dimitte ipsum tribus diebus: deinde pone cotum cum butyro: postea cura cum unguento usquequo sanetur.	Then soak cotton in salt water, and place it on the site, and leave it for three days: then place cotton with butter: afterward treat with ointment until it heals.
Et si uis, cauteriza hanc hemicraniam cum extremitate cultellari secunda Cauterii.	And if you wish, cauterize this migraine with the second knife-like end of the Cautery.
Et caue ab incisione arteriae in hac hemicrania, non antiqua proprie.	And beware of cutting the artery in this migraine, especially if not chronic.
¶ De modo cauteriezandi in hemicrania antiqua.	On the method of cauterizing in chronic migraine.
Caput V.	Chapter 5.
Quando curas hemicraniam, cum eo quod diximus ex curatione praecedente, et quod diximus in diuisionibus aegritudinum, et non confert curatio: et uides ex aegritudine, quod non sufficit ei quod diximus ex cauterio primo cum medicina, aut cum cauterio cum igne, tunc oportet ut ignias Cauterium cultellare, donec albificetur postquam signas super locum doloris cum linea, cuius longitudo sit medietas digiti, aut quasi illud: et depone manum tuam uice una, et stringe eam donec incidas arteriam, et peruenias usque ad os.	When you treat migraine with what we mentioned from the preceding treatment, and what we mentioned in the division of diseases, and the treatment does not help: and you see from the disease that what we mentioned from the first cautery with medicine or with cautery with fire is not sufficient, then it is necessary that you heat the knife-like Cautery until it becomes white after you mark the site of pain with a line whose length is half a finger or thereabouts: and lower your hand once, and press it until you cut the artery and reach the bone.
Verumtamen necesse est tibi, ut caueas a continuatione mandibulae, quae mouetur apud masticationem, ne aduratur latus, aut neruus qui mouet ipsam, unde accidat spasmus.	However, it is necessary for you to beware of the continuity of the jawbone, which moves during chewing, lest the side or the nerve that moves it be burned, whereupon spasm occurs.
Et esto super custotiam, et cautelam de fluxu sanguinis arteriae, quae abscisa est.	And be on guard and cautious about the bleeding of the artery which has been cut.
In abscisione enim eius est timor, et praecipue ei qui ignorat illud quod facit, et non est studiosus, nec expertus: et dimittit operationem cum eo in primis.	For in cutting it there is danger, especially for one who is ignorant of what he is doing, and is not studious nor experienced: and abandons the operation with it at first.
Et ego ueniam cum rememoratione regiminis fluxus sanguinis accidentis ex arteria secundum modum suum, et in loco suo huius libri.	And I will come with the remembrance of the management of bleeding occurring from the artery according to its method, and in its place in this book.
Quod si uides ex aegritudine, quod non sufficit ei hoc Cauterium, et uides corpus infirmi tolerans cauterium in medio capitis, sicut narrauimus, cura uulnus, donec sanetur.	But if you see from the disease that this Cautery is not sufficient for it, and you see the body of the patient tolerating cautery in the middle of the head, as we narrated, treat the wound until it heals.
Et si uis, administra Cauterium, quod diximus in capitulo extractionis arteriae cum Cauterio habente duos cultellos.	And if you wish, administer the Cautery which we mentioned in the chapter on extraction of the artery with the Cautery having two knives.
Est enim cauterizatio melior hac et magis conferens.	For it is better cauterization than this and more beneficial.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in dolore Aurium.	On the method of cauterization for ear pain.
Caput VI.	Chapter 6.
Quando accidit in Aure dolor a frigore, et curatur cum solutiuis, et reliqua curatione quam diximus in diuisione, et non remouetur dolor, tunc igni Cauterium: et est illud quod nominatur Punctum, cuius forma est haec.	When pain occurs in the ear from cold, and is treated with solvents, and the remaining treatment which we described in the division, and the pain is not removed, then cauterize with fire: and this is what is called the Point, whose form is this.
Deinde puncta cum eo post eius ignitionem in circumitu auris totius, sicut reuoluitur: aut in circumitu utriusque, si simul dolor est in utrisque.	Then puncture with it after heating it around the entire ear, as it revolves: or around both, if the pain is in both simultaneously.
Et elonga te cum Cauterio a radice auris parumper, postquam signaueris loca cum encaustro: et sit cauterii quantitas decem punctorum in omni aure, et quasi illa.	And distance yourself with the cautery from the root of the ear a little, after you have marked the places with ink: and let the amount of cauterization be ten points in each ear, or thereabouts.
Deinde cura loca, donec sanentur.	Then treat the areas until they heal.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Tortura.	On the method of cauterization for Facial Paralysis.
Caput VII.	Chapter 7.
Tortura quae curatur cum cauterizatione, non est nisi ex speciebus, quae accidunt ex phlegmate, secundum quod diximus in diuisionibus aegritudinum.	Facial paralysis which is treated with cauterization is only from the types that occur from phlegm, according to what we said in the division of diseases.
Et deuita cauterizationem speciei, quae accidit ex exiccatione, et spasmo nerui.	And avoid cauterization of the type that occurs from dryness and spasm of the nerve.
Quando curas hanc speciem torturae cum hyeris, et caputpurgiis, et gargarismis, et non confert curatio tua, tunc oportet ut cauterizes infirmum tribus Cauteriis: uno apud radicem auris, et secundo parum inferius a timpore suo, et tertio apud coniunctionem duorum labiorum.	When you treat this type of facial paralysis with hierae [medicines], and head purgatives, and gargles, and your treatment doesn't help, then you should cauterize the patient with three cauteries: one at the root of the ear, and the second a little below from its temple, and the third at the junction of the two lips.
Et pone Cauterium tuum ex contrario partis infirmae.	And place your cautery on the opposite side of the affected part.
Quoniam mollificatio non accidit, nisi in parte quae apparet sana.	For the softening occurs only in the part that appears healthy.
Et forma cauterizationis est, ut cauterizes ipsum Cauterio in directo extremitatis auris superioris sub cornu capitis parum: et alio in timpore: cuius longitudo sit secundum longitudinem pollicis.	And the form of cauterization is that you cauterize with the cautery in line with the upper extremity of the ear slightly below the horn of the head: and another at the temple: whose length should be according to the length of the thumb.
Et depone manum tuam cum cauterio, donec comburatur quantitas medietatis spissitudinis cutis.	And lower your hand with the cautery until half the thickness of the skin is burned.
Et haec est forma Cauterii, et est species ex cultellari, cuius forma praemissa est: uerumtamen non est subtilior ea parum, sicut uides: et oportet ut sit cultellus in eo superfluae grossitudinis parum.	And this is the form of the cautery, and it is a type of knife-like instrument, whose form was mentioned before: however it is not much more subtle than it, as you see: and the knife in it should be slightly more thick than usual.
Deinde cura loca, cum eo quod praecessit: donec sanetur.	Then treat the areas with what was previously mentioned: until it heals.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Apoplexia antiqua.	On the method of cauterization in chronic Apoplexy.
Caput VIII.	Chapter 8.
QUando antiquatur Apoplexia, et curas eam cum eo quod diximus, et non confert medicatio tua, et infirmus non habet febrem, tunc cauteriza eum quatuor cauteriis super omne cornu capitis sui, et cauterio in medio capitis, sicut diximus, et cauterio in occipitio capitis, secundum quod praecessit: et modus cauterii sit secundum quod praecessit.	When apoplexy becomes chronic, and you treat it with what we mentioned, and your medication doesn't help, and the patient doesn't have fever, then cauterize him with four cauteries above every horn of his head, and a cautery in the middle of the head, as we said, and a cautery in the back of the head, according to what preceded: and let the method of cautery be according to what preceded.
Etiam cauterizatur cum Cauterio super os stomachi: et est magis ultimum.	Also cauterize with a cautery above the mouth of the stomach: and this is most ultimate.
Deinde curetur, cum eo quod praecessit.	Then let it be treated with what preceded.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Obliuione.	On the method of cauterization for Memory Loss.
Caput IX.	Chapter 9.
Oportet ut in potu dentur in primis infirmo hyerae magnae, et pillulae mundificantes cerebrum.	First, the patient should be given great hierae to drink, and pills that purify the brain.
Deinde rade caput infirmi totum, et pone super occipitium eius emplastrum de synapi descriptum in tractatu emplastrorum: et pone ipsum aliquotiens.	Then shave the patient's entire head, and place on his occiput the mustard plaster described in the treatise on plasters: and apply it several times.
Ipsum namque est modus Cauterii: et fac illud secundum ordinem eundem, quem dixi illic.	For this is a method of cautery: and do it according to the same order that I described there.
Si ergo sanatur per illud, bonum est.	If therefore he is healed by that, it is good.
Si non: tunc fac ei cauteria tria in posteriori parte capitis sui, quae sint descendentia a superiori parte capitis usque ad inferiorem partem oculi: et pone inter omne cauterium grossitudinem digiti.	If not: then make three cauteries in the posterior part of his head, which should descend from the upper part of the head to the lower part of the eye: and place between each cautery the thickness of a finger.
Deinde cura Cauterium, cum eo quod praecessit.	Then treat the cautery with what preceded.
Si autem uis additionem, et infirmus est tolerans illud: tunc fac ei Cauterium in medio.	But if you want an addition, and the patient can tolerate it: then make him a cautery in the middle.
Quod si uis additionem: tunc cauteriza ipsum super duo cornua.	And if you want an addition: then cauterize him above the two horns.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur: sitque Cauterium oliuare secundum formam, quae praemissa est.	Then treat him until he heals: and let the cautery be olive-shaped according to the form which was mentioned before.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Paralisi, et mollificatione.	On the method of cauterization in Paralysis and softening.
Caput X.	Chapter 10.
Oportet ut procedas in mundificatione capitis cum hyeeris, et cum eo quod diximus.	You should proceed in purifying the head with hierae, and with what we mentioned.
Deinde rade caput infirmi: postea cauteriza ipsum cauterio in medio capitis, et cauterio super omne cornu capitis, et cauterio super posterius ipsius, et tribus super spondiles colli.	Then shave the patient's head: afterward cauterize him with a cautery in the middle of the head, and a cautery above every horn of the head, and a cautery above its posterior part, and three above the vertebrae of the neck.
Si autem indiges in aegritudine mollificatione corporis pluribus illis, et infirmus est tolerans, et aegritudo est fortis: tunc cauteriza ipsum quatuor cauteriis super spondiles dorsi, et ultima cum cauterio, donec comburatur ex cute plurimum eius, et eleua manum tuam.	But if you need more than those in the disease of softening of the body, and the patient can tolerate it, and the disease is severe: then cauterize him with four cauteries above the vertebrae of the back, and finish with the cautery, until most of the skin is burned, and lift your hand.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur: et sic cauterium Oliuare.	Then treat him until he heals: and thus the olive-shaped cautery.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Epilepsia.	On the method of cauterizing in Epilepsy.
Caput XI.	Chapter 11.
Non Cauterizatur epilepticus, nisi ille cuius epilepsia est ex phlegmate.	An epileptic person should not be cauterized, except one whose epilepsy is from phlegm.
Oportet ergo ut mundifices cerebrum eius in primis cum hyeris, et cum reliqua curatione quam diximus in diuisione: quando infirmus est magnus, aut est tolerans in accaeptione medicinarum.	Therefore it is necessary that you first cleanse their brain with hierae [herbal medicines], and with the remaining treatment which we mentioned in the division: when the patient is grown, or is tolerant in accepting medicines.
Si autem est puer, qui non tolerat medicinas, tunc administratur gargarisma, et masticationes mundificantes cerebrum, ante illud diebus multis cum bonificatione ciborum.	If however it is a child, who does not tolerate medicines, then administer gargling, and chewing substances that cleanse the brain, before that for many days with improvement of foods.
Deinde rade caput eius, postea cauteriza ipsum Cauterio uno in medio capitis, secundum quod praecessit in modo: et cauterio alio in occipitio eius, et super omne cornu capitis sui cauterio.	Then shave their head, afterwards cauterize it with one cautery in the middle of the head, according to what was previously described in the method: and with another cautery at the back of the head, and over every corner of their head with a cautery.
Quod si infirmus fuerit fortis, et fuerit tolerans, tunc cauteriza ipsum cauteriis, quae dixi in habente paralisim, et mollificationem corporis super spondiles colli, et spondiles dorsi: et sit Cauterium oliuare secundum modum qui praecessit.	But if the patient is strong, and is tolerant, then cauterize them with the cauteries which I described for one having paralysis and softening of the body over the vertebrae of the neck and vertebrae of the back: and let the cautery be olive-shaped according to the method which preceded.
Si autem infirmus est puer, tunc pone cauterium subtile, secundum hunc modum.	If however the patient is a child, then apply a fine cautery, according to this method.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Melancholia.	On the method of cauterizing in Melancholia.
Caput XII.	Chapter 12.
Quando caussa melancholiae sunt humiditates corruptae, et phlegma grossum, tunc cauteriza ipsum Cauteriis, quae diximus in habente paralisim.	When the causes of melancholia are corrupt humidities and thick phlegm, then cauterize them with the cauteries which we described for one having paralysis.
Et si caussa melancholiae est superfluitas decliuis ad melancholiam, et est corpus infirmi humectum, tunc da ei in potu quod mundificet cerebrum eius, secundum quod praecessit in diuisione: deinde rade caput infirmi, et fac postea tortellam decenter factam ex lino, sicut circulum.	And if the cause of melancholia is an excess inclining to melancholy, and the patient's body is moist, then give them to drink what will cleanse their brain, according to what preceded in the division: then shave the patient's head, and afterwards make a properly made circular pad from linen, like a circle.
Deinde pone ipsam in medio capitis: et infirmus sedens quadratus teneatur ab omni parte.	Then place it in the middle of the head: and let the patient sitting square be held from all sides.
Deinde praesenta linimentum.	Then present the liniment.
Et est dignius ex butyro ouium antiquo.	And it is most worthy from old sheep's butter.
Et calefac ipsum super ignem calefactione temperata mensura, quam toleret digitus, quando intromittitur in ipsum.	And heat it over fire with moderate heating to a measure which a finger tolerates when it is inserted into it.
Deinde euacua ipsum in medio capitis eius in circulo, et dimitte ipsum donec infrigidetur.	Then empty it in the middle of their head in a circle, and leave it until it cools.
Fac illud infirmo omni hebdomada semel, cum reliquo regimine eius bono, donec sanetur.	Do that to the patient once every week, with the rest of their good regimen, until they are healed.
Aut si uis, cauteriza ipsum faciendo puncta parua plurimum eius, praeter quod teneas manum cum cauterio: imo sit odorando.	Or if you wish, cauterize them making many small points, beyond which you do not hold the hand with the cautery: rather let it be by sensing.
Haec enim species cauterii humectat cerebrum cum qualitate.	For this type of cautery moistens the brain with its quality.
Deinde pone super ipsum cotum imbibitum in butyro, aut adipe gallinae.	Then place cotton soaked in butter or chicken fat over it.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in aqua descendente ad oculum.	On the method of cauterizing in water descending to the eye [cataract].
Caput XIII.	Chapter 13.
Quando declaratur tibi principium aquae in oculo per signa, quae dixi in diuisione, tunc incipe et pota infirmum, cum eo quod mundificet caput eius.	When the beginning of water in the eye becomes clear to you through the signs which I mentioned in the division, then begin and give the patient to drink what will cleanse their head.
Et custodi ipsum ab omnibus humiditatibus, et fac eum sedere in balneo, in ieiunio diebus aliquot.	And guard them from all moistures, and make them sit in the bath, fasting for some days.
Deinde praecipe ei, ut radat caput suum, et cauteriza ipsum in medio capitis sui.	Then command them to shave their head, and cauterize them in the middle of their head.
Deinde cauteriza ipsum super duo timpora duobus cauteriis, si est incaeptio descensus aquae in duobus oculis simul: aut ex latere uno, si est incaeptio aquae in oculo uno: et abscinde cum cauterio omnes uenas et arterias quae sunt sub cute: et sint cauteria in ea longa in latitudine timporum: et caue a fluxu sanguinis.	Then cauterize them over the two temples with two cauteries, if it is the beginning of water descending in both eyes together: or from one side, if it is the beginning of water in one eye: and cut with the cautery all veins and arteries which are under the skin: and let the cauteries in it be long in the width of the temples: and beware of blood flow.
Quod si uides aliquid ex eo, tunc abscinde eum statim cum quacumque medicina est possibile: et ego ueniam cum sapientia, quae est in extractione arteriarum, et abscisione earum, et cautela a fluxu sanguinis.	But if you see any of it, then cut it off immediately with whatever medicine is possible: and I will come with wisdom, which is in the extraction of arteries, and cutting them, and caution against blood flow.
Et quandoque cauterizatur in ceruice, sub duobus ossibus, duobus cauteriis ultime productis.	And sometimes it is cauterized in the neck, under the two bones, with two cauteries ultimately produced.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Lachrymis antiquis.	On the method of cauterizing in Ancient Tears.
Caput XIIII.	Chapter 14.
Quando lachrymae oculorum sunt antiquae, assiduae: et sunt super uenas, et arterias quae sunt in manifesto capitis exterius, uerificatur quod illud est ex superfluitatibus frigidis, phlegmaticis: tunc cauteriza cauterio eodem quod narraui in incaeptione aquae descendentis, cauterio in medio capitis, et duobus cauteriis super duo timpora, et duobus cauteriis in ceruice sub duobus ossibus.	When the tears of the eyes are ancient, constant: and are over veins and arteries which are manifest externally on the head, it is verified that this is from cold, phlegmatic superfluities: then cauterize with the same cautery that I narrated in the beginning of descending water, with a cautery in the middle of the head, and two cauteries over the two temples, and two cauteries in the neck under the two bones.
Et si indiges additione, tunc cauteriza ipsum in omni latere caute oculi, super extremitatem supercilii cum cauterio paruo.	And if you need addition, then cauterize them on every side of the eye cavity, over the extremity of the eyebrow with a small cautery.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in foetore Nasi.	On the method of cauterizing for foul smell of the Nose.
Caput XV.	Chapter 15.
Quando tu medicaris illud, cum eo quod diximus in diuisione, et non confert medicatio: tunc propera, et da in potu infirmocochias tribus noctibus: deinde rade caput eius, et cauteriza ipsum cauterio medio, cum cauterio oliuari.	When you treat it with what we described in the division, and the treatment doesn't help: then hurry, and give the patient to drink for three nights: then shave his head, and cauterize it with a medium cautery, using an olive-shaped cautery.
Deinde cauteriza ipsum cum cauterio clauili duobus cauteriis, super duo supercilia sub capillis parum.	Then cauterize it with a nail-shaped cautery using two cauteries, above the two eyebrows slightly under the hair.
Et custodite ab arteria, ne incidas eam.	And be careful of the artery, lest you cut it.
Et haec est forma cauterii Clauilis.	And this is the form of the nail-shaped cautery.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in mollificatione Palpebrae.	On the method of cauterizing for laxity of the Eyelid.
Caput XVI.	Chapter 16.
Quando mollificatur Palpebra oculi ab aegritudine, aut humiditate: tunc cauteriza Palpebram cauterio uno, cum hoc cauterio lunari.	When the eyelid of the eye becomes lax from illness or moisture: then cauterize the eyelid with one cautery, using this crescent-shaped cautery.
Et si uis, cauteriza ipsum supra duo supercilia parum duobus cauteriis in omni parte: et elongentur a duobus timporibus: et sit longitudo omnis cauterii, secundum longitudines supercilii: et non ultimes manum tuam cum cauterio, imo secundum quantitatem quod aduritur tertia palpebrae.	And if you wish, cauterize it above the two eyebrows slightly with two cauteries on each side: and let them be distant from the two temples: and let the length of each cautery be according to the length of the eyebrow: and do not extend your hand with the cautery, but rather according to the amount that burns a third of the eyelid.
Et haec est forma cauterii secundum hunc modum cauterii lunaris.	And this is the form of the cautery according to this method of the crescent-shaped cautery.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Palpebram cum pili inuersantur pungentes oculum.	On the method of cauterizing the Eyelid when hairs turn inward pricking the eye.
Caput XVII.	Chapter 17.
Cauterium in eo est secundum duos modos: aut cauterium cum igne: aut cauterium cum medicina comburente.	Cauterization in this case is according to two methods: either cautery with fire: or cautery with burning medicine.
In cauterio autem cum igne, praecipe infirmo ante illud, ut dimittat pilos suos, si est ex illis qui mundant eos, donec prolongentur et aequentur.	In cautery with fire, instruct the patient beforehand to let his hairs grow, if he is among those who trim them, until they become long and even.
Si autem pungunt eum apud ortum suum: tunc constringe oculos eius cum uitta, ut non moueantur, donec nascantur.	If however they prick him at their growth: then bind his eyes with a band, so they don't move, until they grow.
Cum ergo nascuntur et aequantur, tunc pone caput infirmi in sinu tuo: deinde signa super Palpebram oculorum eius cum encaustro, signo quod sit secundum figuram folii myrti: et sit principium signi prope pilos.	When therefore they grow and become even, then place the patient's head in your lap: then mark on his eyelid with ink, a mark that should be in the shape of a myrtle leaf: and let the beginning of the mark be near the hairs.
Deinde pone cotum imbibitum in albumine oui: aut in mucilagine psilii super oculum.	Then place cotton soaked in egg white: or in psyllium mucilage over the eye.
Deinde igni cauterium, cuius forma est haec.	Then heat the cautery, whose form is this.
Deinde cauteriza super figuram, quam signasti paulatim in uicibus multis, donec comburatur superficies cutis, quae est sicut figura folii myrti, totam apparentem proprie.	Then cauterize over the figure which you marked gradually in many passes, until the surface of the skin is burned, which is like the figure of a myrtle leaf, all visible specifically.
Et signum sanitatis operis tui est: ut si uideas Palpebram oculi iam contrahi, et pilos eleuari apud puncturam oculi.	And the sign of the success of your work is: that if you see the eyelid of the eye has contracted, and the hairs raised at the point where they prick the eye.
Eleua ergo manum tuam tunc: et dimitte ipsum tribus diebus.	Therefore lift your hand then: and leave it for three days.
Deinde pone super ipsum Cotum cum butyro, donec eradicetur eschara.	Then place Cotton with butter on it, until the scab falls off.
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguento, donec sanetur.	Then treat it with ointment until it heals.
Quod si redeat aliquod ex pilis post horam, et mollificetur palpebra: tunc itera Cauterium super illum locum, sicut fecisti in primis.	But if any of the hairs return after a while, and the eyelid becomes lax: then repeat the Cautery over that place, as you did at first.
Si autem pili sunt in inferiori: tunc cauteriza ipsam, donec eleuetur ad locum suum naturalem: et aequetur ut non pungant pili oculum.	If however the hairs are in the lower [eyelid]: then cauterize it, until it rises to its natural place: and becomes even so that the hairs don't prick the eye.
¶ De modo cauterizandi cum medicina comburente in eodem casu.	On the method of cauterizing with burning medicine in the same case.
Caput XVIII.	Chapter 18.
Est ut praecipias infirmo, ut dimittat pilos, donec prolongentur et aequentur.	It is that you should instruct the patient to let the hairs grow until they become long and even.
Fac ex charta de panno formam folii myrti.	Make from paper or cloth the shape of a myrtle leaf.
Deinde accipe ex sapone cognito, et ex calce non imbibita ex unoquoque pondus uncia I aut quasi illud: deinde tere ea simul contritione bona, et fac illud cum festinatione, ut non infrigidetur.	Then take of known soap and of unslaked lime, of each one ounce or thereabouts: then grind them together with good grinding, and do this quickly, so that it does not cool.
Deinde ex pande ex eo super chartam quam fecisti sicut formam folii myrti, et pone ipsum super palpebram oculi unius, aut duorum.	Then spread this over the paper which you made in the shape of a myrtle leaf, and place it over the eyelid of one eye, or both.
Et pone sub oculo cotum imbibitum in albumine oui: et caput infirmi sit in sinu tuo.	And place under the eye cotton soaked in egg white: and let the patient's head be in your lap.
Et pone digitum tuum indicem super medicinam, et preme ipsum parumper.	And place your index finger over the medicine, and press it slightly.
Et tu moueas ipsum quotiens sentit infirmus mordicationem medicinae: quoniam inuenit eius mordicatio sicut ignis.	And move it whenever the patient feels the stinging of the medicine: for its stinging feels like fire.
Dum ergo perseuerat hoc quod ipse inuenit mordicatio, tunc dimitte medicinam, et moue ipsam cum digito tuo.	While therefore the stinging that he feels persists, then leave the medicine, and move it with your finger.
Cum ergo quiescit mordicatio, tunc remoue medicinam, et ablue oculum cum aqua.	When therefore the stinging subsides, then remove the medicine, and wash the eye with water.
Et considera tunc, si uides palpebram eleuari, sicut eleuatur apud contractionem cum igne, aut cum incisione, est bene: et si non, tunc itera super ipsam ex medicina super locum, in quo non imprimit medicina, et non denigrat, donec aequetur operatio tua, et contrahatur oculus.	And observe then, if you see the eyelid rising, as it rises during contraction with fire, or with incision, it is good: and if not, then repeat with the medicine over the same place, where the medicine did not make an impression, and did not blacken, until your operation is even, and the eye contracts.
Deinde pone super ipsum Cotum cum butyro, donec eradicetur cutis adustionis.	Then place upon it cotton with butter, until the burnt skin is removed.
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguento diaphinicon, aut alio, donec sanetur.	Then treat it with diaphinicon ointment, or another, until it heals.
Et necesse est tibi apud operationem, ut custodias ultima custodia, ne in oculum cadat aliquid ex medicina.	And it is necessary for you during the operation to guard with utmost care, lest anything from the medicine falls into the eye.
Quod si mollificatur palpebra post dies, et pugnat ex capillis aliquid in oculo, tunc itera medicinam super illum locum, qui mollificatur ex palpebra proprie, sicut fecisti in primis.	But if the eyelid softens after days, and some of the hairs fight in the eye, then repeat the medicine over that place which is softened from the eyelid specifically, as you did at first.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then treat it until it heals.
Et haec est forma folii myrti.	And this is the shape of the myrtle leaf.
Et scias, quod oculi hominum diuersificantur in magnitudine, et paruitate.	And know that people's eyes differ in size, both large and small.
Ergo secundum illud sit consideratio tua: et non occultatur uia rectitudinis illi, cui est studium de hac arte.	Therefore according to that should be your consideration: and the path of correctness is not hidden from one who has studied this art.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Fistula lachrymali.	On the method of cauterizing in lachrymal fistula.
Caput XIX.	Chapter 19.
Quando curas Fistulam, cum eo quod diximus in diuisionibus aegritudinum, et non confert curatio tua: tunc, oportet ut cauterizes ipsam secundum hunc modum.	When you treat a fistula with what we have described in the divisions of diseases, and your treatment does not help: then, it is necessary that you cauterize it according to this method.
Praecipe infirmo, ut ponat caput suum in sinu tuo, et teneat caput eius minister inter manus suas taliter, ut non moueatur, neque agitetur cum capite suo.	Command the patient to place his head in your lap, and let an assistant hold his head between his hands in such a way that he does not move, nor shake with his head.
Deinde pone Cotum infusum in albugine oui, aut in mucilagine psilii super oculum eius: deinde igni Cauterium, cuius forma est haec.	Then place cotton soaked in egg white, or in psyllium mucilage over his eye: then heat the cautery, whose shape is this.
Sit concauum, sicut forma cannae pennae uulturis ab extremitate una, cum qua fit Cauterium: et si uis sit penetrans usque ad extremitatem aliam, et si uis sit sursum sic tenta.	Let it be hollow, like the shape of a vulture's feather quill at one end, with which the cauterization is done: and if you wish it may penetrate to the other end, and if you wish it may be held up thus.
Verumtamen hoc concauum est melius ad opus tuum.	However, this hollow one is better for your work.
Deinde exprime fistulam, si est aperta, et extrahe ex ea saniem, et exicca ipsam: et si non est aperta, tunc aperi eam, et extrahe pus eius.	Then squeeze the fistula, if it is open, and extract the pus from it, and dry it: and if it is not open, then open it, and extract its pus.
Deinde pone tunc super eam Cauterium, quod fit ignitum ualde.	Then place upon it the cautery, which should be very hot.
Et tene cum eo manum tuam parumper apud Cauterium ab oculo, ad partem nasi, ut non erret manus tua, aut inquietetur infirmus: et ponas Cauterium in adipe oculi, et corrumpas ipsum.	And hold your hand with it a little while during cauterization away from the eye, toward the nose, so that your hand does not err, or the patient become disturbed: and you place the cautery in the fat of the eye, and corrupt it.
Si ergo peruenis in principio Cauterii tui usque ad os, erit bene.	If therefore you reach in the beginning of your cauterization all the way to the bone, it will be good.
Et si non: tunc itera Cauterium semel, aut bis, si indiges illo: et dimitte illud tribus diebus.	And if not: then repeat the cauterization once, or twice, if you need that: and leave it for three days.
Deinde pone Cotum cum butyro, et cura ipsum cum unguento exiccatiuo, donec sanetur.	Then place cotton with butter, and treat it with drying ointment, until it heals.
Quod si praeterierint ei quadraginta dies, et non sanatur: tunc pone super ipsum medicinam acutam corrosiuam, donec detegatur os: et rade ipsum secundum quod uenit in capitulo suo.	But if forty days pass, and it does not heal: then place upon it sharp corrosive medicine, until the bone is exposed: and scrape it according to what comes in its chapter.
Et est modus alius Cauterii fistulae, quem quidam primi dixerunt.	And there is another method of cauterizing a fistula, which some of the ancients have described.
Intende ad locum fistulae, et finde ipsum: deinde pone in ipsam fissuram camahan subtile, id est, Cannulam subtilem, cuius forma haec est.	Look to the location of the fistula, and split it open: then place in this split a thin camahan, that is, a thin tube, whose form is this.
Et funde in ipsum quantitatem drachmae ex plumbo liquefacto, et tene manum tuam cum Canna retentione bona, et non moueatur infirmus omnino, ut non currat, uel perueniat plumbum liquefactum ad oculum eius.	And pour into it the quantity of a drachm of melted lead, and hold your hand with the tube with a good grip, and the patient should not move at all, so that the melted lead does not run or reach their eye.
Et oportet ut ponas super oculum infirmi cotum infusum in albumine oui, aut in aqua.	And it is necessary that you place over the patient's eye cotton soaked in egg white, or in water.
Plumbum enim comburit locum fistulae, et sanat ipsam sanatione mirabili.	For the lead burns the site of the fistula, and heals it with wonderful healing.
Quod si sanatur fistula, cum eo quod diximus ex Cauterio, et curatione, est bonum.	If the fistula is healed with what we have described of cautery and treatment, it is good.
Et si non, tunc necesse est administrare foramen nasi, et reducere fistulam ad cursum nasi, secundum quod ueniet in loco suo sibi proprio.	And if not, then it is necessary to work on the opening of the nose, and redirect the fistula to the passage of the nose, according to what will come in its own proper place.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in fissuris Labiorum.	¶ On the method of cauterizing in fissures of the Lips.
Caput XX.	Chapter 20.
Multotiens accidunt in Labio fissurae, quae nominantur Pili, et praecipue in labiis puerorum.	Often fissures occur in the lip, which are called Pili, and especially in the lips of children.
Cum ergo tu curas has fissuras, cum eo quod diximus in diuisione aegritudinum, et non confert curatio, tunc igni cauterium paruum cultellare, secundum hanc formam.	When therefore you treat these fissures with what we have described in the division of diseases, and the treatment is not effective, then heat a small knife-like cautery, according to this form.
Et sit concauitas eius secundum subtilitatem cultelli.	And let its concavity be according to the thinness of the knife.
Deinde pone ipsum ignitum festinanter in ipsis fissuris, donec perueniat cauterium ad profundum fissurarum.	Then place it heated quickly in these fissures, until the cautery reaches the depth of the fissures.
Deinde cura ipsum cum caeroto, donec sanetur.	Then treat it with wax salve until it heals.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in fistula Oris.	¶ On the method of cauterizing in fistula of the Mouth.
Caput XXI.	Chapter 21.
Quando accidit apostema in radice gingiuae, aut in palato, aut in radicibus dentium: deinde facit pus, et rumpitur: postea antiquatur, et currit pus, et fit fistula: deinde curas ipsam, et non confert in ea curatio, tunc oportet ut ignias cauterium secundum quantitatem, quod capiat in fistula.	When an abscess occurs in the root of the gum, or in the palate, or in the roots of teeth: then it makes pus, and bursts: afterwards it becomes chronic, and pus runs, and becomes a fistula: then you treat it, and if treatment is not effective, then it is necessary that you heat a cautery according to the size that will fit in the fistula.
Deinde intromitte ipsum ignitum in foramine fistulae, et tene manum tuam, donec perueniat ferrum ignitum ad profundum eius, et ultimum eius: fac illud semel, aut duabus uicibus.	Then introduce it heated into the opening of the fistula, and hold your hand, until the heated iron reaches its depth and its end: do this once, or twice.
Deinde cura ipsum post illud, cum eo quod diximus de curatione usquequo curetur.	Then treat it after that with what we have described of treatment until it is cured.
Si ergo abscinditur sanies, et sanatur, erit bonum.	If therefore the discharge is cut off, and it heals, it will be good.
Et si non, tunc necesse est detegere locum, et auferre os corrupum secundum quod ueniet in capite suo.	And if not, then it is necessary to expose the area, and remove the corrupted bone according to what will come in its chapter.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Gingiuis, et Dentibus mollificatis.	¶ On the method of cauterizing in Gums and loosened Teeth.
Caput XXII.	Chapter 22.
Quando mollificatur gingiua propter humiditates, et mouentur dentes, et curas eam cum medicinis, et non confert: tunc pone caput infirmi in sinu tuo.	When the gum is softened because of moisture, and the teeth move, and you treat it with medicines, and it is not effective: then place the head of the patient in your lap.
Deinde igni cauterium, cuius forma ueniet post haec, ita ut ponas Cannulam super dentem: et intromitte in ea Cauterium ignitum festinanter: et tene manum tuam parumper, donec sentiat infirmus calorem ignis iam peruenisse ad radicem dentis.	Then heat a cautery, whose form will come after this, so that you place the tube over the tooth: and introduce into it the heated cautery quickly: and hold your hand a little while, until the patient feels the heat of the fire has reached the root of the tooth.
Et eleua manum tuam: deinde itera Cauterium aliquotiens, secundum quod uis.	And lift your hand: then repeat the cautery several times, according to what you wish.
Deinde impleat infirmus os suum aqua salis, et teneat ipsam hora una: et exspuat ipsam.	Then let the patient fill their mouth with salt water, and hold it for one hour: and spit it out.
Dens enim motus firmatur, et gingiua mollificata stringitur, et siccatur humiditas corrupta.	For the loose tooth becomes firm, and the softened gum tightens, and the corrupt moisture dries up.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in dolore Dentium.	On the method of cauterizing for tooth pain.
Caput XXIII.	Chapter 23.
Quando dolor dentis est propter frigiditatem, aut in ipso est frigus, aut uermis, et non confert curatio cum medicinis: tunc Cauterium in ipso est secundum duos modos: aut Cauterium cum butyro: aut cauterium cum igne.	When tooth pain is due to cold, or there is cold in it, or a worm, and treatment with medicines does not help: then Cautery for it is according to two methods: either Cautery with butter or cautery with fire.
Cauterium autem eius cum butyro est, ut accipias butyrum uaccinum, et bullias ipsum in cochleari ferreo, aut in uenera.	The cautery with butter is when you take cow's butter and boil it in an iron spoon or in a vessel.
Deinde accipe cotum, et inuolue ipsum super extremitatem tentae.	Then take cotton and wrap it around the end of a probe.
Deinde submerge ipsum in butyro bullito: et pone ipsum super dentem dolorosum festinanter, et tene ipsum donec infrigidet: deinde itera ipsum aliquotiens, donec perueniat uirtus ignis ad radicem dentis.	Then submerge it in the boiled butter and place it quickly on the painful tooth, and hold it until it cools: then repeat this several times, until the power of the heat reaches the root of the tooth.
Et si uis, submerge lanam, aut cotum in butyro frigido, et pone ipsum super dentem dolentem: et pone super ipsum ferrum ignitum, donec perueniat ignis ad profundum concauitatis dentis.	And if you wish, submerge wool or cotton in cold butter, and place it on the aching tooth: and place a heated iron over it, until the heat reaches the depth of the tooth's cavity.
Cauterizatio autem eius cum igne est, ut intendas ad cannulam aeris, aut cannulam ferri.	The cauterization with fire is when you use a bronze tube or an iron tube.
Et sit in corpore eius quiddam grossitudinis, ut non perueniat acuitas ignis ad os infirmi.	And there should be some thickness in its body, so that the sharpness of the fire does not reach the patient's mouth.
Deinde igni Cauterium, cuius forma ueniet: et pone ipsum super illum dentem: et tene manum tuam, donec infrigidetur Cauterium.	Then heat the Cautery, whose form will come: and place it on that tooth: and hold your hand until the Cautery cools.
Fac illud aliquotiens, nam dolor remouebitur, aut in illo eodem die, aut die alio.	Do this several times, for the pain will be removed either on that same day or another day.
Et oportet in impressione illius Cauterii, ut impleat infirmus os suum buyro bono, et teneat ipsum hora una: deinde exspuat ipsum.	And in the application of that Cautery, the patient should fill their mouth with good butter and hold it for one hour: then spit it out.
Et haec est forma Cauterii.	And this is the form of the Cautery.
Cauteriza cum quacumque extremitate uis secundum quod est possibile: et haec est forma Cannulae.	Cauterize with whichever end you wish according to what is possible: and this is the form of the Tube.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Strophulis.	On the method of cauterizing Scrofula.
Caput XXIIII.	Chapter 24.
Quando Strophulae sunt a phlegmate, et ab humiditatibus frigidis, et non sunt obedientes digestioni per mecicinas, et uis digestionem earum uelociter: tunc igni Cauterium concauum, cuius forma est haec.	When Scrofula is from phlegm and from cold humors, and they are not responsive to digestion through medicines, and you want their digestion quickly: then heat a hollow Cautery, whose form is this.
Habens duas extremitates apertas, ut egrediatur fumus apud Cauterium ab extremitate altera: et pone ipsum ignitum super ipsum apostema semel, et secundo, si indiges illo, donec perueniat ad profundum apostematis.	Having two open ends, so that smoke may exit during Cautery from the other end: and place it heated on the abscess once, and a second time if you need it, until it reaches the depth of the abscess.
Quod si apostema est paruum: tunc pone Cauterium secundum quantitatem apostematis.	If the abscess is small: then apply the Cautery according to the size of the abscess.
Deinde dimitte ipsum tribus diebus, et pone super ipsum cotum infusum in butyro, donec remoueatur quod combussit ignis.	Then leave it for three days, and place cotton soaked in butter on it, until what the fire burned is removed.
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguento dentis, donec sanetur forma cannulae.	Then treat it with tooth ointment until the form of the tube heals.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in raucedine uocis, et constrictione anhelitus.	On the method of cauterizing for hoarseness of voice and constriction of breathing.
Caput XXV.	Chapter 25.
Quando uincunt humiditates super cannale pulmonis, et praecipue quando illud est cum frigiditate complexionis, tunc oportet ut euacuetur infirmus in primis cum medicinis solutiuis.	When humors overcome the pulmonary canal, and especially when this is with coldness of complexion, then it is necessary that the patient first be evacuated with purgative medicines.
Deinde cauteriza ipsum in nocrati apud radicem gutturis in loce depresso: et caue, ne peruenias cum Cauterio ad guttur, neque in cute, nisi quiddam eius.	Then cauterize them in the depression at the root of the throat: and be careful not to reach the throat with the Cautery, nor in the skin, except a little of it.
Deinde cauteriza ipsum cauterio alio apud iuncturam colli in ultimo spondili eius ultimando: et sit Cauterium clauile secundum modum, qui praecessit.	Then cauterize them with another cautery at the joint of the neck at its last vertebra finally: and let the Cautery be nail-shaped according to the method that preceded.
Deinde cura ipsum cum eo quod praecessit, donec sanetur.	Then treat them with what preceded until they heal.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in aegritudinibus Pulmonis, et Tussi.	On the method of cauterizing in diseases of the Lungs and Cough.
Caput XXVI.	Chapter 26.
Quando Tussis et aegritudo Pulmonis sunt ab humiditatibus frigidis, et infirmus non habet febrem, neque phthisim, et aegritudo antiqua: tunc cauteriza ipsum duobus cauteriis supra furculam in locis depressis, lenibus, uacuis.	When Cough and disease of the Lungs are from cold humors, and the patient does not have fever, nor consumption, and the disease is chronic: then cauterize them with two cauteries above the collarbone in depressed, smooth, empty places.
