Et caue, ne comburas neruum qui est illic, et accidat super infirmum malicia alia.	And take care not to burn the nerve that is there, lest another misfortune befall the patient.
Et scias, quod quando ex arteria fluit sanguis, tunc non est possibile abscindere ipsum: praecipue quaudo arteria est magna, nisi cum uno quatuor modorum.	And know that when blood flows from an artery, then it is not possible to stop it: especially when the artery is large, except by one of four methods.
Aut cum cauterio, sicut diximus.	Either with cautery, as we have said.
Aut cum extractione, quando non est extracta.	Or with extraction, when it has not been extracted.
Nam quando extrahitur, contrahuntur extremitates eius, et abscinditur sanguis.	For when it is extracted, its ends contract, and the blood stops.
Aut ligetur cum filo ligatione forti.	Or it may be tied with thread in a strong binding.
Aut ponantur super ipsum medicinae de proprietate, quarum est abscindere sanguinem, et stringatur cum puluinari constrictione decenti.	Or medicines may be placed over it whose property is to stop blood, and it may be compressed with a cushion with proper pressure.
Qui autem administrat abscisionem eius cum ligamento, et strictura cum panno, aut positione rerum comburentium, et similium, non confert ei penitus, nisi raro.	But he who attempts to stop it with bandaging, and tightening with cloth, or placing burning things and similar items, it helps him not at all, except rarely.
Si autem accidat alicui illud, et non sit ei praesens medicus, neque medicina: tunc incipiat cum positione digiti indicis super orificium uenae ipsius, sicut narrauimus, et constrictione eius ualde, donec obsessus sit sanguis a superiori parte uulneris, et super arteriam.	If however this happens to someone, and no physician or medicine is present: then let him begin by placing the index finger over the opening of the vein itself, as we have described, and pressing it very firmly, until the blood is contained from the upper part of the wound, and above the artery.
Et digitus non remoueatur, desuper ipsum cum aqua frigida uehementis frigoris semper, donec congeletur sanguis, et ingrossetur, et abscindatur.	And the finger should not be removed, [but] pour very cold water over it continuously, until the blood congeals, and thickens, and stops.
Et interim consideret in eo, quid indiget ex cauterio, aut ex medicina.	And meanwhile consider what is needed from cautery or from medicine.
¶ Partis Primae Finis.	End of Part One.
Liber Chirurgici Albucasis Pars II.	Surgical Book of Albucasis Part II.
¶ De Incisione, Perforatione, et Phlebotomia in uulneribus, et his similibus.	¶ On Incision, Perforation, and Bloodletting in wounds, and similar matters.
Iam Diximus in Capitulo Primo, omnem aegritudinem in qua conueniens est cum igne cauterium et medicina comburente, et occasiones eius, ipsius caussas, et instrumenta eius, et formas cauteriorum.	We have already spoken in the First Chapter about every illness in which cauterization with fire and burning medicine is appropriate, and its occasions, its causes, and its instruments, and the forms of cauterization.
Et posui illic capitula a uertice usque ad pedem.	And I have placed chapters there from head to foot.
Et ego procedam in hoc capitulo illa eadem uia: ut alleuietur super quaerentem quaesitum eius.	And I shall proceed in this chapter in the same way: so that the search may be made easier for the seeker.
Et antequam incipiam illud, oportet ut addiscatis o filii, quod in hoc capitulo est ex terrore illud quod est in capitulo primo de cauterizatione.	And before I begin it, you should learn, O sons, that in this chapter there is as much terror as there is in the first chapter about cauterization.
Et propter illud oportet, ut sit cautela in eo uehementior, quoniam in operatione quae est in hoc capitulo, multotiens cadit euacuatio cum sanguine, cum quo stat uita apud apertionem uenae, aut incisionem super apostema, aut apertionem exiturae, aut curationem uulneris, aut extractionem sagittae, aut incisionem super lapidem, et illis similia: ex quibus omnibus associatur tremor, et timor, et cadit in pluribus eorum mors.	And because of that it is necessary that caution in it be more vigilant, since in the operation which is in this chapter, many times evacuation occurs with blood, with which life stands, during the opening of a vein, or incision upon an abscess, or opening of a swelling, or treatment of a wound, or extraction of an arrow, or incision for a stone, and similar things: from all of which trembling and fear are associated, and in many of them death occurs.
Et ego moneo uos, ne cadat super uos illud in quo est haesitatio, nam quandoque cadunt ad uos in hac arte modi hominum cum modis infirmitatum.	And I warn you, lest that in which there is hesitation should fall upon you, for sometimes in this art types of men come to you with types of infirmities.
Ex eis enim est qui irascitur cum aegritudine sua, et est leuis apud eum mors: propter uehementiam eius quod inuenit ex infirmitate sua et longitudine eius maliciei.	Among them is he who becomes angry with his illness, and death is light to him: because of the severity of what he finds from his infirmity and the length of its malice.
Et cum aegritudine est ex timore quod significat mortem.	And with the illness there is fear which signifies death.
Et ex eis est, qui dat tibicensum suum, et ditat te cum eo, sperans sanitatem, et aegritudo eius est perniciosa.	And among them is he who gives you his wealth, and enriches you with it, hoping for health, while his illness is fatal.
Non ergo oportet ut consentiatis ei qui uenit ad uos ex eis, cuius modus est talis.	Therefore you should not consent to him who comes to you from among them, whose manner is such.
Et sit cautela uestra uehementior, quam cupiditas et uestra rapacitas.	And let your caution be more vigilant than your desire and your greed.
Et non praesumatis super aliquid ex illo, nisi post scientiam certam, quae uerificat apud uos illud ad quod peruenit successio laudabilis.	And do not presume upon anything from that, except after certain knowledge, which verifies for you that to which praiseworthy success leads.
Et utimini in curatione omnium infirmorum uestrorum, prognosticatione et indicatione de eo ad quod conuenienter sit salus.	And use in the treatment of all your patients, prognosis and indication of that to which health suitably follows.
In illo namque est uobis adiutorium super acquisitionem famae et gloriae, et memoriae et laudis.	For in that there is help for you in acquiring fame and glory, and memory and praise.
Inspiret uobis Deus o filii, intellectum suum, et non auferat uobis directionem et inspirationem: quoniam illud est in manu eius.	May God inspire in you, O sons, His understanding, and not take away from you guidance and inspiration: since that is in His hand.
Et ego quidem ordinaui hoc Capitulum distinguendo per capitula, secundum quod praecessit in capitulo Cauterii, a ceruice usque ad pedes: ut alleuietur uobis quaesitum quod uultis ex eo, et quo indigetis.	And indeed I have arranged this Chapter by distinguishing it into chapters, according to what preceded in the chapter on Cautery, from neck to feet: so that the quest which you want from it, and which you need, may be made easier for you.
¶ De curatione Aquae quae aggregatur in capitibus puerorum.	¶ On the treatment of Water which collects in the heads of children.
Caput I.	Chapter 1.
Scias, quod haec infirmitas multotiens accidit pueris apud partum: aut quando stringit obstetrix caput pueri absque leuitate.	Know that this illness often happens to children at birth: or when the midwife squeezes the child's head without gentleness.
Et quandeque accidit etiam ex caussa occulta quae non scitur.	And sometimes it also happens from a hidden cause which is not known.
Et ego quidem non uidi hanc aegritudinem in aliis quam in pueris: et ad omnem quem ex eis uidi properauit mors: propter illud ergo uisum est mihi dimittere operationem in ea.	And indeed I have not seen this illness in others than in children: and death hastened to all of them whom I saw: therefore because of that it seemed to me better to abandon operation in it.
Et ego quidem uidi ex eis puerum, cuius caput impletum erat aqua, et caput magnificabatur in omni die, donec non poterat sedere super seipsum, propter magnitudinem capitis sui: et humiditas augmentata fuit, donec mortuus est.	And indeed I saw among them a child, whose head was filled with water, and the head grew larger every day, until he could not sit up by himself, because of the size of his head: and the moisture increased until he died.
Et haec quidem humiditas, aut aggregatur inter cutem et os: aut aggregatur sub osse super sifac.	And indeed this moisture either collects between the skin and bone: or collects under the bone over the membrane.
Et operatio in illo, si est humiditas inter cutem et os, et apostema est paruum, tunc oportet ut findas in medio capitis fissura una in latitudine: et sit longitudo fissurae quasi duo nodi, donec currat humiditas.	And the operation in that, if the moisture is between the skin and bone, and the swelling is small, then it is necessary that you make in the middle of the head one incision in width: and let the length of the incision be about two knuckles, until the moisture runs out.
Et haec est forma spatumilis.	And this is the form of the spatula.
Si ergo humiditas est magis augmentata, et apostema est maius, tunc pone eas duas fissuras, secundum formam hanc.	If therefore the moisture has increased more, and the swelling is larger, then make these two incisions, according to this form. 
Et si humiditas est sub osse, et signum eius est, quod uides commissuras capitis apertas ab omni parte: et aqua deprimitur quando comprimis eam manu tua ad interiora, et non occultatur tibi illud: tunc oportet ut findas in medio capitis tribus fissuris, secundum hunc modum.	And if moisture is under the bone, and its sign is that you see the sutures of the head open from all sides: and the water is depressed when you compress it with your hand towards the inside, and this is not hidden from you: then it is necessary that you make three incisions in the middle of the head, in this way. 
Et post incisionem extrahe humiditatem totam.	And after the incision extract all the moisture. 
Deinde stringe fissuras cum pannis et puluillis.	Then bind the incisions with cloths and small pads. 
Deinde embroca illud desuper cum uino et oleo usque ad diem quintum.	Then foment it from above with wine and oil until the fifth day. 
Deinde solue ligamentum, et cura uulnus cum tentis, et unguentis.	Then loosen the bandage, and treat the wound with probes and ointments. 
Et non dimittas stringere caput cum aequalitate.	And do not cease to bind the head evenly. 
Et ciba infirmum omni cibo sicco paucae humiditatis, usquequo confortetur membrum, et sanetur.	And feed the patient every dry food of little moisture, until the limb is strengthened and healed. 
Et modus alius incisionis est, ut consideres ubi apparet magnitudo apostematis, et collectio aquae.	And another method of incision is that you observe where the size of the swelling appears, and the collection of water. 
Quoniam quandoque est in occipitio plus, aut in sincipite, aut in dextra, aut in sinistra.	Since sometimes it is more in the occiput, or in the sinciput, or on the right, or on the left. 
Ascende ergo cum incisione ubi apparet tibi apostema et impletio aquae: et scinde illud secundum quod tibi possibile est.	Therefore ascend with the incision where the swelling and fullness of water appears to you: and cut it according to what is possible for you. 
Et obserua, ne incidas arteriam, et accidat fluxus sanguinis, et moriatur infirmus ex illo fluxu cum euacuatione humiditatis.	And observe, lest you cut an artery, and bleeding occurs, and the patient dies from that flow with the evacuation of moisture. 
¶ De incisione Arteriarum quae sunt post aures.	¶ On the Incision of Arteries which are behind the ears.
Caput II.	Chapter 2. 
Quando accidunt alicui catarri ad oculos, aut ad pectus, et antiquatur illud, et non confert curatio medicinarum: tunc magis ultima curatio est in illo, incisio harum duarum arteriarum.	When catarrhs occur to someone in the eyes, or in the chest, and this becomes chronic, and treatment with medicines does not help: then the most ultimate treatment in that case is the incision of these two arteries. 
Oportet ergo quando uis incidere eas, ut radat infirmus caput suum.	Therefore it is necessary when you wish to cut them, that the patient shave his head. 
Deinde frica locum cum panno aspero, ut appareant arteriae.	Then rub the area with a rough cloth, so that the arteries appear. 
Deinde stringat infirmus collum suum, cum quolibet panno suo.	Then let the patient bind his neck with whatever cloth of his. 
Deinde considera, ubi pulset uena.	Then observe where the vein pulses. 
Et loca utriusque sunt loca quae sunt post aures depressa: et raro occultatur, nisi in quibusdam hominibus.	And the locations of both are the depressed places which are behind the ears: and rarely is it hidden, except in certain men. 
Deinde signa cum encaustro super utraque: et incide utramque cum spatumili utrimque acuro, incisione perueniente ad os: et fiat illud per latitudinem capitis.	Then mark with ink over both: and cut both with a double-sharp spatula, with an incision reaching to the bone: and let that be done across the width of the head. 
Et si uis, intromitte spatumile sub arteria, et incide eam ad superiora cum incisione.	And if you wish, insert the spatula under the artery, and cut it upwards with an incision. 
Et sit longitudo incisionis quasi duo digiti iuncti.	And let the length of the incision be about two joined fingers. 
Nam quando inciditur uena, egreditur sanguis egressione pulsatili, qui salit ad interiora saltu frequenti.	For when the vein is cut, blood exits in a pulsing manner, which leaps inward with frequent jumping. 
Si autem arteria non apparet sensui, tunc oportet ut mensures ab aure quantitatem spacii trium digitorum.	If however the artery does not appear to observation, then it is necessary that you measure from the ear the space of three fingers. 
Deinde signa cum encaustro, et finde usque ad os.	Then mark with ink, and cut until reaching the bone. 
Et illud quod oportet emittere ex sanguine, est VI uncia et fortasse emittis ex eo plus, aut minus.	And that which is necessary to emit of blood is 6 ounces and perhaps you emit more or less from it. 
Totum illud secundum quantitatem quae apparet tibi ex uirute infirmi et repletione arteriae eius.	All that according to the amount which appears to you from the patient's strength and the fullness of his artery. 
Deinde considera ad uulnus.	Then attend to the wound. 
Tunc si remanet ad os ex sifac aliquid, tunc incide illud, ut non accidat apostema calidum: tunc stringe uulnus cum liciniis ex panno lini.	Then if anything remains of the membrane at the bone, then cut it, so that a hot swelling does not occur: then bind the wound with linen cloth strips. 
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguento, donec sanetur.	Then treat it with ointment, until it heals.
¶ De extractione arteriarum, quae sunt in timporibus.	On the extraction of arteries that are in the temples.
Caput III.	Chapter III. 
Quando accidit homini hemicranea antiqua, aut catarri acuti propter humiditates acrimoniales, et caliditate in lacertis timporum, aut soda antiqua, uehemens, et similia illis: et medicatur cum modis curationis medicinae, et non confert illud: tunc experti sumus in his aegritudinibus extractionem arteriarum ex timporibus, aut cauterizationem earum, sicut narrauimus.	When a person suffers from chronic migraine, or acute catarrhs due to sharp humors, and heat in the muscles of the temples, or chronic severe headache, and similar conditions: and when treated with methods of medical treatment, and it does not help: then we have tested in these illnesses the extraction of arteries from the temples, or their cauterization, as we have described. 
Et modus operationis in extractione earum, est, ut radat infirmus pilos qui sunt in timporibus, et intendat ad arteriam apparentem in timpore.	And the method of operation in extracting them is that the patient should shave the hairs that are on the temples, and attend to the visible artery in the temple. 
Ipsa namque ostenditur tibi ex pulsu suo, et raro occultatur nisi in paucis hominibus, aut uehementia frigoris.	For it shows itself to you by its pulse, and rarely is hidden except in few people, or in extreme cold. 
Quod si occultatur tibi, tunc stringat infirmus caput suum cum quolibet panno suo: deinde frica locum cum panno aspero.	But if it is hidden from you, then the patient should bind his head with any of his cloth: then rub the area with a rough cloth. 
Aut uapora locum cum aqua calida, donec appareat tibi apparitione manifesta.	Or steam the area with hot water, until it appears to you with clear appearance. 
Deinde accipe spatumile, quod paulo ante formaui.	Then take the spatula, which I formed a little while ago. 
Deinde excoria cum eo cutem cum facilitate, donec peruenias ad arteriam.	Then carefully strip the skin with it until you reach the artery. 
Deinde proiice in eam uncinum, et extrahe eam ad superiora, donec extrahas eam ex cute, et facias eam euadere ex tunicis quae sunt sub ea ab omni parte.	Then insert a hook into it, and pull it upward until you extract it from the skin, and make it free from the membranes that are beneath it on all sides. 
Si autem arteria est subtilis: tunc inuolue eam cum extremitate uncini.	If the artery is thin: then wrap it with the end of the hook. 
Deinde incide ex ea partem secundum quantitatem qua elongentur extremitates eius, et contrahantur, et non accidat fluxus sanguinis.	Then cut a portion of it according to the length by which its ends separate and contract, and bleeding does not occur. 
Nam si non inciditur, et si non abscinditur, non ascendit sanguis penitus.	For if it is not cut, and if it is not severed, blood does not rise at all. 
Deinde euacua ex sanguine ana VI unci, usque ad .III.	Then drain from the blood six ounces, up to three. 
Quod si arteria est magna: tunc oportet ut liges eam in duobus locis ex filo duplo, forti, ex serico: aut ex chordis alhohod, ut non properet ad ipsam putrefactio ante consolidationem uulneris, et accidat fluxus sanguinis.	If the artery is large: then you must tie it in two places with a strong double thread, of silk: or with strings of gut, so that decay does not hasten to it before the wound consolidates, and bleeding occurs. 
Deinde incide superfluitatem, quae est inter duo ligamenta.	Then cut off the excess that is between the two ligatures. 
Fac illud in illa hora, aut post horam aliam.	Do that in that hour, or after another hour. 
Et si uis, cauteriza eam cauterio usque ad os, cum cauterio cultellari: donec incidantur extremitates eius, et stabit loco eiusdem operis.	And if you wish, cauterize it with a cautery up to the bone, with a knife-like cautery: until its ends are cut, and it will remain in place of the same operation. 
Et est melius opus, nisi si infirmus habet febrem, autest calefactae complexionis.	And it is the better procedure, unless the patient has fever, or is of hot complexion. 
Quoniam cauterium est ex eis, quae iuuant ad finiendas humiditates.	Since cautery is among those things that help to end humidities. 
Ergo est melius iuuamentum.	Therefore it is the better aid. 
Et oportet post extractionem arteriarum, ut impleatur locus cotto antiquo: et ponantur super ipsum puluilli decenter facti.	And after the extraction of arteries, it is necessary that the place be filled with old cotton: and properly made compresses be placed upon it. 
Et post solutionem curetur cum medicinis siccis, quae faciunt nasci carnem, et cum liciniis, donec sanetur.	And after loosening treat with dry medicines, which make flesh grow, and with lint pledgets, until it heals. 
Quod si interim dum operaris accidit fluxus sanguinis ex arteria, tunc propera ad abscindendum eum cum cauterio, aut ut impleas locum cum zegi: et stringe manum tuam, donec abscindatur sanguis.	But if meanwhile while you are operating bleeding occurs from the artery, then hasten to stop it with cautery, or to fill the place with vitriol: and press your hand, until the blood stops. 
Quod si nihil ex illis est tibi praesens, tunc pone super locum digitum tuum, donec congeletur sanguis.	But if none of those things is present with you, then place your finger over the place, until the blood congeals. 
Et embroca locum cum aqua uehementis frigoris, donec quiescat acuitas, et stringatur secundum quod oportet.	And bathe the place with very cold water, until the sharpness quiets, and it is bound as necessary. 
Et ex eo quod est leuius et facilius extractione arteriae, est, ut cauterizes uenam cum hoc cauterio habente duos cultellos: sitque acuitas duorum cultellorum similis almagdatem.	And among what is lighter and easier than extraction of the artery, is that you cauterize the vein with this cautery having two knives: and let the sharpness of the two knives be similar to almagdatem. 
Verumtamen sunt multo minoris acuitatis, quam duo cultelli.	However they are of much less sharpness than two knives. 
Quoniam si sunt acutae, sicut duo cultelli, properat utrisque frigus: et non incidunt carnem cum uelocitate.	For if they are sharp, like two knives, cold hastens to both: and they do not cut flesh quickly. 
Cum ergo in eis est aliquantulum grossitudinis, tenetur in eis calor ignis, et abscinditur caro uelociter: cum hoc ergo opus est melius omni opere, et leuius, et facilius.	When therefore there is some thickness in them, the heat of fire is retained in them, and flesh is cut quickly: with this therefore the procedure is better than every procedure, and lighter, and easier. 
Et sit spacium quod est inter duos cultellos quantitas grossitudinis digiti, postquam tu signas duo loca cum encaustro: et depone utrosque ignitos ualde, donec perueniant ad os, et incidant uenam in duobus locis: ut elongetur quod est inter extremitates eius.	And let the space that is between the two knives be the thickness of a finger, after you mark two places with ink: and set both down very hot, until they reach the bone, and cut the vein in two places: so that what is between its ends separates. 
Nam non consolidantur cum hoc cauterio penitus.	For they do not consolidate at all with this cautery. 
Et haec est forma cauterii.	And this is the form of the cautery.
¶ De cura cursus lachrymarum acutarum assiduarum ab oculis.	¶ On the treatment of constant acute tear flow from the eyes.
Caput IIII.	Chapter 4.
Quando sunt lachrymae assiduae, et est cursus earum ex uenis, quae sunt super craneum capitis exterius: et non confert in eis aliquid curationis medicinae cum medicinis, et uides faciem infirmi iam rubere, et sentit in fronte sua deambulationem, sicut est deambulatio formicarum: et oculi eius sunt extenuati, humidi, ita quod iam corrosi sunt pili eorum cum corrosione: et calefactae sunt palpebrae eius ex acuitate lachrymarum: tunc antiqui indiguerunt in curatione earum hac operatione, et denominauerunt eam curationem, cum Ense.	When tears are constant, and their flow is from the veins that are on the outside of the skull of the head: and no medical treatment with medicines helps them, and you see the patient's face becoming red, and he feels in his forehead a movement, like the movement of ants: and his eyes are weakened, moist, so that their eyelashes have been eroded with corrosion: and his eyelids are heated from the sharpness of tears: then the ancients needed this operation in treating them, and they called it treatment with the Sword.
Et est, ut praecipias infirmo radere pilos qui sunt in fronte sua.	And it is that you should order the patient to shave the hair that is on his forehead.
Deinde incide in fronte tres fissuras aequedistantes secundum longitudinem frontis: et sit longitudo fissurae quasi duo digiti, et fissura una sit aequedistans longitudini nasi in medio frontis, et secunda secundum longitudinem parumper a motu lacertorum, et tertia a parte altera: et caue ab incisione arteriarum quae sunt in duobus lateribus: et elonga manum tuam a continuatione duarum mandibularum, et sit spacium omnis incisionis quantitas trium digitorum coniunctorum: et sit tibi frustum spongiae praeparatum, aut panni siccati multi, cum quibus exsicces sanguinem.	Then make three equidistant incisions in the forehead according to the length of the forehead: and let the length of the incision be about two fingers, and let one incision be parallel to the length of the nose in the middle of the forehead, and the second along the length slightly away from the movement of the muscles, and the third on the other side: and beware of cutting the arteries that are on the two sides: and keep your hand away from the connection of the two jaws, and let the space of each incision be the width of three joined fingers: and have a piece of sponge prepared, or many dried cloths, with which to dry the blood.
Deinde intromitte spatumile duarum acutarum extremitatum, cuius mox sequens est forma.	Then insert a spatula with two sharp ends, whose form follows next.
Ab incisione quae est a parte timporis, usque ad incisionem secundam: et excoria cum eo totam cutem, quae est inter duas incisiones, cum sifac, quod est super os.	From the incision which is on the side of the temple, up to the second incision: and scrape with it all the skin that is between the two incisions, with the membrane that is over the bone.
Deinde fac illud etiam ab incisione media usque ad incisionem secundam.	Then do that also from the middle incision up to the second incision.
Deinde extrahe hoc spatumile, et intromitte in incisionem primam iterum instrumentum aliud, quod nominatur cultellare acutum, ab una parte lene, non acutum ab altera parte.	Then remove this spatula, and insert into the first incision again another instrument, which is called a sharp knife, sharp on one side, not sharp on the other side.
Et haec est forma eius.	And this is its form.
Et pone latus eius acutum uersus carnem annexam cum cute, et latus eius lene uersus os: et impelle ipsum, donec perueniat ad fissuram mediam: et abscinde cum eo omnia uasa, quae descendunt a capite ad oculos: praeter quod continuetur incisio usque ad illud quod apparet de cute.	And place its sharp side toward the flesh attached to the skin, and its smooth side toward the bone: and push it until it reaches the middle fissure: and cut with it all the vessels that descend from the head to the eyes: except that the incision should not continue up to what appears of the skin.
Deinde fac illud in fissura media usque ad fissuram aliam.	Then do that in the middle fissure up to the other fissure.
Et postquam currit ex sanguine quantitas aequalis, exprime loca ex frustis sanguinis coagulati.	And after an equal amount of blood has flowed, squeeze the areas to remove pieces of clotted blood.
Deinde pone in omnem fissuram licinium ex cotto ueteri, et pone super eos puluillos imbibitos in uino, et oleo, aut aceto.	Then place in every fissure a wick of old cotton, and place over them compresses soaked in wine and oil, or vinegar.
Et uide ut non accidat apostema calidum.	And see that no hot inflammation occurs.
Et in die tertia solue ligamentum, et administra infusionem multam cum aqua tepida.	And on the third day loosen the bandage, and apply plenty of infusion with lukewarm water.
Deinde cura illud ex unguento basilicon, et reliquis quibus curantur uulnera: usquequo sanetur.	Then treat it with basilicon ointment and the other things with which wounds are treated: until it heals.
¶ De cura lachrymarum acutarum et catarrorum ad oculos ex interioribus capitis.	¶ On the treatment of acute tears and catarrhs to the eyes from the interior of the head.
Caput V.	Chapter 5.
Quando accidunt alicui catarri acuti, acres, assidui: et uides oculos eius extenuatos, paruos, et iam debilitatus est aspectus eorum: et palpebrae ulceratae, et cadunt pili ex eis, et in profundo capitis est dolor acutus, laedens, et sternutatio consequens: tunc sume ex istis accidentibus, quod illae materiae, et catarri non ueniunt, nisi ex uenis multis.	When someone experiences acute, sharp, constant catarrhs: and you see his eyes weakened, small, and their sight has already been weakened: and the eyelids ulcerated, and hairs fall from them, and in the depth of the head there is sharp, harmful pain, and consequent sneezing: then take from these symptoms, that those materials and catarrhs come only from many veins.
Et melior curatio in eis est haec.	And the best treatment for them is this.
Et est, ut praecipias infirmo radere frontem suam.	And it is that you should order the patient to shave his forehead.
Deinde incide in eam fissuram unam in medio frontis, aut alterius parumper per latitudinem, et incipe cum fissura a timpore sinistro ad timpus dextrum: et sit incisio usque ad os: et elonga manum tuam a lacertis timporum, qui mouentur apud masticationem: donec quando detegitur os: et exsiccabis totum sanguinem cum spongia.	Then make one incision in it in the middle of the forehead, or slightly to the other side across the width, and begin with the incision from the left temple to the right temple: and let the incision be down to the bone: and keep your hand away from the muscles of the temples, which move during chewing: until when the bone is exposed: and you will dry all the blood with a sponge.
Tunc separa inter duo labia fissurae cum cotto ueteri, aut cum liciniis ex lino.	Then separate between the two lips of the fissure with old cotton, or with linen wicks.
Deinde stringe desuper cum puluillis: et imbibe puluillos cum uino et oleo, ut non accidat apostema calidum.	Then bind over it with compresses: and soak the compresses with wine and oil, so that no hot inflammation occurs.
Et quando soluis illud, et uides quod apostema calidum iam imminuitur: tunc oportet ut frices os, donec incipiat in eo nasci caro.	And when you loosen it, and you see that the hot inflammation has already diminished: then it is necessary that you rub the bone until flesh begins to grow on it.
Deinde cura ipsum cum regimine exiccatiuo quod facit nasci carnem: sicut si accipias ex farina tritici partes duas, et ex colophonia quatuor partes: et praepares ex eis emplastrum, et administretur ad natiuitatem carnis in istis uulneribus.	Then treat it with a drying regimen that makes flesh grow: as if you take two parts of wheat flour, and four parts of colophony: and prepare from them a plaster, and let it be administered for the growth of flesh in these wounds.
¶ De cura eius quod cadit in Aurem.	On the treatment of what falls into the Ear.
Caput VI.	Chapter 6.
Omne Quod in Aurem cadit, est una quatuor specierum: aut lapis mineralis, aut simile lapidi, sicut ferrum, et uitrum: aut est ex planta, sicut est cicer, et fabae: aut est res fluxibilis, sicut aqua, et acetum, et eis similia: aut aliquod animal.	Everything that falls into the Ear is one of four types: either a mineral stone, or something similar to stone, like iron and glass; or it is from a plant, like chickpeas and beans; or it is a flowing substance, like water and vinegar and similar things; or some animal. 
Quando ergo cadit in aurem lapis, aut genus lapidis ex eis quae non adduntur, neque crescunt in aure, expone Aurem soli: si ergo uides lapidem, tunc distilla in Aurem aliquid ex oleo uiolato, aut sisamino.	When therefore a stone falls into the ear, or a type of stone from those which neither expand nor grow in the ear, expose the Ear to the sun: if therefore you see the stone, then drip into the Ear something from violet oil, or sesame oil. 
Deinde administra extractionem eius, et fac sternutare cum condisi, et opila nares apud aduentum sternutationis, postquam tu ponis in circumitu auris frusta ex pannis, aut lana, et extendis aurem ad superiora.	Then administer its extraction, and cause sneezing with condisi, and block the nostrils at the onset of sneezing, after you place pieces of cloth or wool around the ear, and stretch the ear upward. 
Multotiens enim egreditur cum hac cura.	Many times indeed it comes out with this treatment. 
Si autem non egreditur, tunc administra extractionem eius cum Gesti, id est, Pizigarolis subtilibus: cuius forma est haec.	If however it does not come out, then administer its extraction with Gesti, that is, fine tweezers: whose form is this. 
Si ergo egreditur cum gesti, est bonum.	If therefore it comes out with tweezers, it is good. 
Et si non, tunc administra extractionem eius cum uncino caeco subtili paucae duplicationis.	And if not, then administer its extraction with a fine blunt hook of little doubling. 
Si ergo non egreditur per illud, tunc fac cannulam ex aere, et intromitte extremitatem cannulae in foramen auris multum, et opila quod est in circumitu cannulae cum caera mollificata cum oleo, ut non sit uento uia nisi cannulae: deinde extrahe cum uento tuo attractione forti.	If therefore it does not come out by that means, then make a tube from bronze, and insert the end of the tube into the ear canal deeply, and block what is around the tube with wax softened with oil, so that there is no path for air except through the tube: then extract with your breath by strong suction. 
Multotiens enim egreditur cum eo quod narrauimus.	Many times indeed it comes out with what we have described. 
Si autem non egreditur hoc modo: tunc accipe ex helkalimbat, aut ex uisco, id est, gluten praeparato, cum quo capiuntur aues, rem modicam: et pone ipsum in extremitate radii postquam tu inuoluis super eam cotum decenter positum: deinde intromitte ipsum in foramen auris cum facilitate, postquam tu exiccas aurem ab humiditate.	If however it does not come out this way: then take from helkalimbat, or from birdlime, that is, prepared glue, with which birds are caught, a small amount: and place it on the tip of a probe after you wrap it with cotton properly positioned: then insert it into the ear canal with care, after you dry the ear from moisture. 
Si ergo non egreditur cum omnibus quae narrauimus, tunc propera ad scindendum, antequam accidat apostema calidum, aut spasmus.	If therefore it does not come out with all that we have described, then hurry to cut, before a hot abscess occurs, or spasm. 
Et modus fissurae est, ut phlebotomes infirmum in primis in cephalica: et extrahe ei ex sanguine secundum mensuram uirtutis eius.	And the method of cutting is that you first bleed the patient in the cephalic vein: and draw blood from him according to the measure of his strength. 
Deinde fac sedere infirmum inter manus tuas, et conuerte aurem eius ad superiora, et finde fissuram paruam in radice auris apud adipem eius in loco depresso ipsi: et sit fissura lunaris figurae, donec peruenias ad lapidem: deinde aufer eum cum eo, quod est tibi possibile ex instrumentis.	Then have the patient sit between your hands, and turn his ear upward, and make a small incision at the root of the ear near its fatty part in the depressed place there: and let the incision be crescent-shaped, until you reach the stone: then remove it with whatever instruments are possible for you. 
Deinde sue fissuram ab hora tua cum uelocitate, et cura ipsam, donec sanetur.	Then sew the incision immediately with speed, and treat it until it heals. 
Quod si res cadens in aurem est ex uno granorum, quae crescunt, et inflantur: tunc administra extractionem eius.	But if the thing falling into the ear is from one of the grains that grow and swell: then administer its extraction. 
Si autem non obedit tibi ad exitum, tunc accipe spatumile tenue, subtile, secundum hanc formam.	If however it does not yield to you for exit, then take a thin, fine spatula, according to this form. 
Et administra cum eo abscisionem illius speciei ex granis, quae cadunt in aurem, et non facias illud, quando tu cogitas, quod illud granum iam humectatum est per uaporem auris, donec ponis ipsum frusta multa: deinde extrahe ea cum uncinis, aut cum gesti subtili, aut cum suctione, sicut diximus, nam extractio eius alleuiatur.	And administer with it the cutting of that type of grain which falls into the ear, and do not do that when you think that grain has already been moistened by the vapor of the ear, until you make it into many pieces: then extract them with hooks, or with fine tweezers, or with suction, as we said, for its extraction is made easier. 
In aqua autem quae ingreditur in aurem, oportet ut utatur infirmus sternutatione cum condisi in primis: et iam impleuit aurem suam cum aliquanto cotto ueteri: et est iacens super illam aurem, in qua est aqua.	For water however which enters the ear, it is necessary that the patient use sneezing with condisi first: and he has already filled his ear with some old cotton: and he is lying on that ear in which the water is. 
Si ergo egreditur per illud, est bonum.	If therefore it comes out by that means, it is good. 
Et si non: tunc accipe lapides multos, secundum longitudinem digiti, tenues, lenes, et calefac eos cum igne parumper, et intromittat infirmus ex eis unum in foramen auris suae: et saliat super pedem suum unum ex illa parte, et percutiat cum lapide alio super lapidem qui est in aure.	And if not: then take many stones, the length of a finger, thin, smooth, and heat them with fire a little, and let the patient insert one of them into his ear canal: and let him hop on one foot on that side, and strike with another stone upon the stone which is in the ear. 
Non ergo cesset facere illud cum lapide et lapide, donec egrediatur tota aqua.	Therefore he should not cease doing that with stone after stone, until all the water comes out. 
Et iam egreditur aqua ita, ut accipias ex parpyro, aut ex iunco unum, et intromittas extremitatem eius unam in aurem: et accendas extremitatem alteram cum igne, donec comburatur plurimum eius.	And water indeed comes out so that you take from papyrus, or from reed one piece, and insert one end of it into the ear: and light the other end with fire, until most of it burns. 
Deinde itera iuncum alium, et fac illud multotiens, donec egrediatur tota aqua: et extrahe ipsam cum cannula secundum quod praemissum est in lapide.	Then repeat with another reed, and do that many times, until all the water comes out: and extract it with a tube according to what was described previously for the stone.
In extractione autem animalis intrantis in eam, si est parui corporis, ut pulex, et ei simile, cura ipsum sicut dixi in diuisione.	In extracting small animals that enter it (the ear), if it is of small body, like a flea or similar, treat it as I described in the division. 
Sed si est corporis magni, quod appareat sensui: tunc administra extractionem eius cum gesti, et uncinis: et res eius est facilior omnibus, quae tenentur in aure.	But if it is of large body, which is visible to the senses: then perform its extraction with forceps and hooks: and this matter is easier than all things that are held in the ear. 
In extractione autem uermis generati in aure, quando curas eum cum eo quod diximus in diuisione, et in tractatu distilationum, et non confert curatio tua: tunc oportet ut aspicias aurem in sole.	In extracting a worm generated in the ear, when you treat it with what we described in the division and in the treatise on distillations, and your treatment does not help: then you should examine the ear in sunlight. 
Si ergo apparet illic aliquid ex uermibus, tunc extrahe illud cum gesti, aut cum uncinis subtilibus.	If therefore something appears there from the worms, then extract it with forceps or with fine hooks. 
Si autem non apparet illic aliquid, tunc accipe cannulam, cuius haec est forma, stricta inferius, ampla superius: et intromitte extremitatem subtilem in aurem secundum quantitatem quod tolerat eam infirmus: deinde suge cum ea suctione forti.	If however nothing appears there, then take a small tube, which has this form, narrow below, wide above: and insert the narrow end into the ear according to the amount that the patient can tolerate: then suck with it using strong suction. 
Fac illud multotiens, donec egrediantur omnes uermes.	Do this many times, until all worms come out. 
Si autem non obediunt tibi ad exitum, tunc opila circumitum cannulae cum caera, sicut dixi in lapide.	If however they do not yield to you for exit, then seal the circumference of the tube with wax, as I said regarding the stone. 
Quod si non egrediuntur cum eo quod diximus: tunc administra distillationes quas iam experti sunt antiqui in interfectione uermium: et inuenies illud in tractatu distillationum.	But if they do not come out with what we described: then administer the distillations which the ancients have already tested in killing worms: and you will find that in the treatise on distillations. 
Et sit effusio tua qua effundis olea et medicinas in aurem cum hoc instrumento, cuius forma depicta est hic.	And let your pouring with which you pour oils and medicines into the ear be with this instrument, whose form is depicted here. 
Sicut uides fac ipsum ex argento, aut aere, inferius strictum, in quo sit foramen paruum, amplum superius.	As you see make it from silver, or bronze, narrow below, in which there should be a small opening, wide above. 
Sit ergo ut impellens quod est in concauitate cannulae, sit ex aere decenter factum.	Therefore let the plunger which is in the cavity of the tube be made appropriately from bronze. 
Et si uis, accipe radium, et inuolue in extremitate eius cottum inuolutione decenti: deinde proiice oleum, aut succum, aut quod uis ex istis medicinis in cannulam: et ipsa sit in aure: deinde intromitte radium cum cotto desuper, et exprime ipsum manu tua compressione temperata, donec impellatur oleum in concauitate auditus, et sentiat ipsum infirmus interius: et illud quod infunditur in aurem, sit iam calefactum cum igne parumper: et caue ne sit res quae distillatur in eam frigida ualde: medicinae enim non tolerant illud.	And if you wish, take a probe, and wrap cotton at its end with a proper wrapping: then pour the oil, or juice, or whatever you want from these medicines into the tube: and let it be in the ear: then insert the probe with cotton from above, and press it with your hand with moderate pressure, until the oil is forced into the cavity of hearing, and the patient feels it inside: and let that which is poured into the ear be already slightly warmed with fire: and take care that the thing which is distilled into it is not very cold: for medicines do not tolerate that.
¶ De cura opilationis accidentis Auri.	On the treatment of blockage occurring in the Ear.
Caput VII.	Chapter 7. 
Quandoque egrediuntur quidam infantes ex uentribus matrum suarum non perforati.	Sometimes certain infants emerge from their mothers' wombs with [ears] not perforated.
Et iam accidit etiam quibusdam hominibus opilatio in meatu Auris a uulnere, aut carne nata in ea.	And blockage in the ear canal also happens to some people from a wound, or flesh growing in it.
Et haec opilatio quandoque fit in profundo foraminis Auris, quam non consequitur uisus: et quandoque accidit ad exteriora foraminis parum, et consequitur eam uisus.	And this blockage sometimes occurs deep in the ear hole, which sight cannot reach: and sometimes it occurs near the exterior of the hole, and sight can reach it.
Illa ergo quae accidit in profundo Auris, et quam non comprehendit aspectus, est in pluribus dispositionibus difficilis sanationis.	Therefore that which occurs deep in the ear, and which sight cannot comprehend, is in most cases difficult to cure.
Et in illa quam consequitur uisus, oportet ut ponas Aurem infirmi in sole, et aspicias in ea: tunc si uides opilationem apparentem, aperi eam cum spatumili subtili, cuius forma est haec quae sequitur, sit extremitas eius in qua sit quaedam latitudo parua, cuius quaedam pars sit acuta: et reliquum spatumile sit duarum laterum lenium: ut non laedat aurem.	And for that which sight can reach, you should place the patient's ear in the sun, and look into it: then if you see an apparent blockage, open it with a thin spatula, whose form follows here, let its tip have some small width, of which some part should be sharp: and let the rest of the spatula have two smooth sides: so that it does not harm the ear. 
Si ergo opilatio est a carne nata in meatu auris: tunc tene eam cum uncino subtili, et incide eam cum facilitate uehementi, donec auferatur tota caro.	If therefore the blockage is from flesh grown in the ear canal: then hold it with a fine hook, and cut it with careful force, until all the flesh is removed.
Quod si opilatio est in profundo auris: tunc accipe radium subtilem, lenem, et calefac ipsum cum igne parumper: deinde mitte ipsum in meatum auris.	But if the blockage is deep in the ear: then take a thin, smooth probe, and heat it slightly with fire: then insert it into the ear canal.
Si ergo senseris opilationem cum eo, quod inuenit infirmus cum grauitate auditus, conare apertionem eius cum facilitate: et caue, ne uulneres neruos auris.	If therefore you sense the blockage with it, which the patient finds with difficulty of hearing, attempt to open it carefully: and beware, lest you wound the ear nerves.
Deinde pone in aurem licinium secundum quantitatem amplitudinis foraminis, quod inuoluisti in unguento aegyptio: fac illud aliquot diebus, donec sis securus de consolidatione uulneris.	Then place in the ear a lint according to the size of the hole's width, which you have wrapped in Egyptian ointment: do this for several days, until you are assured of the wound's healing.
Aut accipe licinium, et infunde ipsum in aqua rosata, et pulueriza super ipsum zegi tritum, et utere ipso.	Or take lint, and soak it in rose water, and sprinkle ground vitriol over it, and use it. 
Quod si uides aurem iam apostemari: tunc oportet ut extrahas licinium, et permittas ipsum cum licinio alio, quod inuolues in caeroto quod sit factum cum oleo rosato, donec sedetur apostema calidum: deinde cura ipsum usquequo sanetur.	If you see the ear becoming infected: then you should remove the lint, and replace it with another lint, which you will wrap in a wax preparation made with rose oil, until the hot inflammation subsides: then treat it until it heals.
Si autem accidat fluxus sanguinis: tunc submerge spongiam, aut pannos in aqua frigida, et pone super eam aurem: et utere reliqua curatione, quae abscindit fluxum sanguinis praedicta in tractatu distillationum.	But if bleeding occurs: then submerge a sponge, or cloths in cold water, and place them over that ear: and use the remaining treatment, which stops bleeding as described in the treatise on distillations. 
¶ De cura Altheli palpebrarum.	On the treatment of warts of the eyelids.
Caput VIII.	Chapter 8. 
Isti Althelil qui accidunt in Palpebris oculi, quandoque sunt humidi, et sunt sicci.	These warts that occur on the eyelids of the eye are sometimes moist, and are dry.
Oportet ergo ut teneas eos cum tenaliis: aut cum uncino, et incidas eos cum spatumili a radicibus suis.	Therefore you should hold them with forceps: or with a hook, and cut them with a spatula from their roots.
Deinde pone super loca zegi tritum.	Then place ground vitriol over the areas.
Si autem ex eis fluat sanguis, tunc cauteriza eos cum cauterio lenticulari subtili.	But if blood flows from them, then cauterize them with a fine lenticular cautery.
Et cauterizare eos, est melius post incisionem.	And cauterizing them is better after incision.
Multotiens enim redeunt quando remanet ex radicibus suis aliquid.	For they often return when something remains from their roots.
Et quando cauterizantur cum igne, comburuntur illae radices, et non redeunt.	And when they are cauterized with fire, those roots are burned, and do not return. 
¶ De cura Grandinum palpebrarum oculi.	On the treatment of Hailstones of the eye's eyelids.
Caput IX.	Chapter 9. 
Multotiens accidit in palpebris aliquid quod assimilatur Crandini in fortitudine sua, et sua duricie, et propter illud nominatur Grando: et est aggregatio humiditatis grossae in palpebra superiore, et palpebra inferiore.	Often occurs in the eyelids something that resembles Hailstone in its hardness, and its firmness, and because of that it is called Hail: and it is an accumulation of thick moisture in the upper eyelid, and lower eyelid.
Operatio ergo in eis est, ut consideres tunc, si est Grando procedens in eo, quod apparet de palpebra, et mouentur ad omnem partem, et res eius est facilis.	Therefore the operation on them is, that you should consider then, if it is Hail proceeding in what appears of the eyelid, and they move to every part, and its matter is easy.
Finde ergo super eam fissura per latitudinem.	Therefore make an incision over it lengthwise.
Deinde excoria eam ab omni parte cum facilitate, donec euadat.	Then carefully excise it from all sides until it comes out.
Deinde suspende eam cum uncino, et abscinde ipsam.	Then suspend it with a hook, and cut it off.
Si autem non praeparatur tibi abscisio eius, nisi postquam tu penetras palpebram cum incisione parumper, tunc nocet infirmo illud in aliquo.	But if its removal is not possible for you, except after you penetrate the eyelid with a small incision, then that harms the patient somewhat.
Quod si fissura est magna: tunc aggrega ipsam cum sutura: et cura ipsam, donec sanetur.	But if the incision is large: then bring it together with sutures: and treat it until it heals.
Et si est parua, non superueniet tibi malum ex ea.	And if it is small, no harm will come to you from it.
Vnguentum enim restaurat ipsam, et incarnat eam.	For ointment restores it, and makes it heal.
Et si grando est decliuis ad interiora auris uersus superficiem intrinsecam, tunc inuersa palpebram, et suspende grandinem cum uncino: praeter quod indigeas incisione, et preme eam ab omni parte.	And if the hail is declining toward the interior of the ear toward the inner surface, then invert the eyelid, and suspend the hail with a hook: rather than needing incision, and press it from all sides.
Quod si elongatur palpebra per incisionem, non nocet illud in aliquo.	But if the eyelid is elongated by the incision, that does not harm in any way.
Deinde ablue oculum post incisionem grandinis, cum aqua salsa: et cura locum cum eo quod incarnat, donec sanetur infirmus.	Then wash the eye after the incision of the hail, with salt water: and treat the area with that which heals, until the patient recovers.
¶ De cura Axirnath palpebrarum.	On the treatment of Axirnath of the eyelids.
Caput X.	Chapter 10.
Axirnath est adeps qui generatur in tunicis palpebrae superioris: et plurimum quidem accidit illud pueris: et ipsum grauat oculos eorum, et accidunt eis catarri in matutinis, et non possunt intueri lumen solis, propterea, quod lachrymae properant ad eos, et propter illud uides eos discumbere super facies suas semper, et super eas dormiunt, et sunt palpebrae eorum sub superciliis humidae, quas iam cooperuit inflatio: et eminentia quidem Axirnath apparens est oculo, et quando tu premis locum cum digitis tuis, sentis Axirnath inter eos.	Axirnath is a fatty substance that forms in the layers of the upper eyelid: and indeed it occurs mostly in children: and it weighs down their eyes, and they get catarrhs in the mornings, and they cannot look at sunlight, because tears come quickly to them, and because of this you see them always lying on their faces, and they sleep on them, and their eyelids under the eyebrows are moist, which swelling has already covered: and indeed the prominence of Axirnath is visible to the eye, and when you press the area with your fingers, you feel Axirnath between them. 
Et modus operationis eius est, ut ponat infirmus caput suum in sinu tuo.	And the method of operating on it is that the patient should place their head in your lap. 
Deinde accipe pannum lini, et praepara in eo licinia, et fac ex illo licinio circulum secundum quantitatem quod continet Axirnath ab omni parte.	Then take a linen cloth, and prepare strips from it, and make from that strip a circle according to the size that contains the Axirnath from all sides. 
Deinde pone eum super eam, et preme cum digitis tuis ab omni parte, ut aggregetur Axirnath in medio circuli.	Then place it over it, and press with your fingers from all sides, so that the Axirnath gathers in the middle of the circle. 
Deinde finde in medio illius humiditatis cum spatumili incidente fissuras per latitudinem, et non sit fissura maior illa quae fit in phlebotomia in profundo.	Then make an incision in the middle of that moisture with a cutting spatula, making cuts across the width, and let the incision not be deeper than what is made in phlebotomy. 
Aut oportet ut findas cutem totam, donec peruenias ad Axirnath in pluribus enim dispositionibus procedit Axirnath ex fissura secundum formam frusti pinguedinis albae.	Either it is necessary that you cut the entire skin, until you reach the Axirnath for in many cases the Axirnath comes out of the incision in the form of a piece of white fat. 
Extrahe ergo eam cum panno, quem infiltrasti inter digitos tuos ad exteriora: et tu reuoluis manum tuam ad dextram et sinistram, donec dispergatur: et caue, ne addas in fissura, ut non peruenias cum spatumili ad oculum, et laedas eum.	Therefore extract it with a cloth, which you have worked between your fingers toward the outside: and you turn your hand to the right and left, until it disperses: and take care not to deepen the incision, lest you reach the eye with the spatula and harm it. 
Si autem non appareat tibi Axirnath in principio fissurae, tu addas in fissura parum cum facilitate, donec procedat Axirnath.	If however the Axirnath does not appear to you at the beginning of the incision, you should deepen the incision a little bit carefully, until the Axirnath comes out. 
Deinde extrahe eam, sicut diximus.	Then extract it, as we have said. 
Deinde submerge pannos in aceto et aqua, et pone eos super locum, et stringe eum cum puluillis.	Then soak cloths in vinegar and water, and place them over the area, and bind it with small cushions. 
Et ex hominibus sunt qui terunt salem, et ponunt ipsum in concauitate fissurae, ut liquefiat quod remansit ex illa humiditate.	And among people there are those who grind salt and place it in the cavity of the incision, so that what remains of that moisture may dissolve. 
Deinde cura ipsam, donec sanetur.	Then treat it until it heals. 
Si autem accidat in loco apostema calidum, tune cura ipsum cum emplastris sedatiuis, donec sanetur.	If however a hot abscess occurs in the area, then treat it with soothing plasters until it heals.
¶ De modis Ataxmir oculi, id est, cum palpebra mollificatur oculi, unde fit ut rugetur sicut non debet.	¶ On the types of Ataxmir of the eye, that is, when the eyelid becomes soft, whereupon it wrinkles in a way it shouldn't.
Caput XI.	Chapter XI.
Quando nascuntur in palpebris oculi pili additi praeter cursum sub pilis naturalibus, et antiquantur: tunc ipsi nocent oculo, et faciunt accidere modos aegritudinum, sicut lachrymas assiduas, et mollificationem palpebrarum, et albuginem, donec fit illud caussa destructionis oculi.	When additional hairs grow in the eyelids beneath the natural hairs and become established: then they harm the eye and cause various types of ailments, such as constant tearing, softening of the eyelids, and white spots, until this becomes the cause of the eye's destruction.
Et Ataxmir quidem oculi curatur secundum quatuor modos.	And indeed Ataxmir of the eye is treated in four ways.
Aut per cauterium cum igne.	Either by cautery with fire.
Aut cum medicina acuta, secundum quod praemissum est in capitulo cauterii.	Or with sharp medicine, according to what was described in the chapter on cautery.
Aut curatur Ataxmir per incisionem et suturam.	Or Ataxmir is treated by incision and suture.
Aut per cannas, secundum quod ego dicam.	Or by tubes, according to what I will describe.
Oportet ut ponas caput infirmi in sinu tuo.	It is necessary that you place the patient's head in your lap.
Deinde conuerte palpebram oculi manu tua sinistra.	Then turn the eyelid with your left hand.
Si ergo conuertitur, bonum est.	If therefore it turns, it is good.
Et si non: intromitte acum in eam, in qua sit filum ab inferiori parte palpebrae, et fac penetrare acum cum filo desuper, et sit illud prope pilos ipsos, id est, prope marginem palpebrae, in quo nascuntur pili: et trahe filum ad superiora cum palpebra, et conuerte eam cum radio.	And if not: insert a needle with thread from the lower part of the eyelid, and make the needle penetrate through with the thread from above, and let this be near the hairs themselves, that is, near the margin of the eyelid where the hairs grow: and pull the thread upward with the eyelid, and turn it with a probe.
Deinde finde in interiori parte palpebrae sub pilis additis cum spatumili incidente a lachrymali maiore usque ad lachrymale minus.	Then make an incision in the inner part of the eyelid under the additional hairs with a cutting spatula from the larger tear duct to the smaller tear duct.
Deinde extrahe filum, et pone sub palpebra puluillum paruum ex cotto, aut panno: deinde signa super palpebram cum encaustro, quod sit sicut figura folii myrti.	Then remove the thread, and place under the eyelid a small pad of cotton or cloth: then mark on the eyelid with ink a figure like a myrtle leaf.
Verumtamen oportet, ut fit figura secundum quantitatem et eleuationem palpebrae: quoniam iam diuersificatur illud in hominibus.	However, it is necessary that the figure be according to the size and elevation of the eyelid: since this varies among people.
Ex eis enim est, qui indiget ut incidatur ex palpebra quantitas magna, secundum quantitatem quae mollificatur a palpebra.	Among them indeed is one who needs to have cut from the eyelid a large amount, according to the amount that has become soft from the eyelid.
Deinde cum spatumili finde super duas lineas quas signasti, et incipe a lachrymali maiore usque ad lachrymale minus, et sit fissura una prope pilos naturales, sicut est grossitudo radii.	Then with the spatula cut along the two lines which you marked, and begin from the larger tear duct up to the smaller tear duct, and let one cut be near the natural hairs, like the thickness of a probe.
Deinde intromitte uncinum in uno duorum angulorum cutis.	Then insert a hook into one of the two angles of the skin.
Deinde excoria ipsam totam.	Then excise all of it.
Deinde aggrega cum sutura duo labia, cum acu et filo lana subtili: et absterge sanguinem, et fac adhaerere quod superfluit ex filis super duo supercilia, cum quibusdam rebus inuiscantibus, si uis facere illud: et si non, non cures.	Then join the two edges with sutures, using a needle and fine wool thread: and wipe away the blood, and make what is excess of the threads adhere above the two eyebrows, with certain sticky substances, if you wish to do this: and if not, don't worry about it.
Deinde dimitte suturam et fila usque ad tres dies, aut quatuor: postea cura illud.	Then leave the suture and threads for three or four days: afterward treat it.
Et si uis, dimitte uulnus absque sutura, et cura ipsum cum eo, quod exsiccat et constringit.	And if you wish, leave the wound without sutures, and treat it with something that dries and constricts.
Nam palpebra eleuatur apud sigillationem uulneris et aggregationem eius: sed futura est melior.	For the eyelid is elevated during the sealing of the wound and its joining: but suturing is better.
Hunc modum curandi Ataxmir docuerunt antiqui.	The ancients taught this method of treating Ataxmir.
Verumtamen in eo est sollicitudo super infirmum, et est ex bona operatione, et non est in eo timor.	However, in it there is concern for the patient, and it is from good practice, and there is no fear in it.
Et modus alius est in Ataxmir etiam: et est, ut signes super palpebram figuram, quae sit sicut figura folii myrti, sicut narrauimus.	And there is another method also in Ataxmir: and it is that you mark on the eyelid a figure that is like the figure of a myrtle leaf, as we described.
Deinde eleua palpebram cum tribus uncinis separatis, aut aggregatis, secundum formam hanc quae sequitur, deinde incide quod superfluit cum forficibus paruis, secundum hanc formam, cum aequalitate incisionis.	Then elevate the eyelid with three hooks separated or joined, according to this form which follows, then cut what is excess with small scissors, according to this form, with evenness of incision.
Si autem non est tibi possibile tenere uncinum, et non aequatur illud: tunc accipe acum in qua sit filum, et intromitte ipsum in medio figurae: et intromitte filum aliud prope lachrymale maius, et filum secundum prope lachrymale minus: et aggrega inter digitos tuos fila cum aequalitate.	If however it is not possible for you to hold the hook, and that is not even: then take a needle with thread, and insert it in the middle of the figure: and insert another thread near the larger tear duct, and a second thread near the smaller tear duct: and gather the threads between your fingers evenly.
Deinde eleua manum tuam eleuatione aequali: et eleua cutem super quam est signatum cotum, sicut narrauimus.	Then raise your hand with an even elevation: and elevate the skin over which the cotton is marked, as we described.
Deinde aggrega duo labia uulneris cum sutura: et cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then join the two edges of the wound with sutures: and treat it until it heals.
Si uero accidat apostema apud incisionem tuam, aut fissuram tuam: seda illud apostema cum caeroto, et his similibus, ex unguentis sedantibus.	If however swelling occurs at your incision or your cut: calm that swelling with wax ointment, and similar things, from soothing ointments.
Et quandoque accidit palpebrae etiam, ut conuertantur pili eius.	And sometimes it also happens to the eyelid that its hairs turn inward.
Oportet ergo ut utaris in ea quod diximus in incisione: sed sutura utrisque magis est artificialis.	Therefore it is necessary that you use in it what we said in incision: but suturing in both cases is more skillful.
¶ De cura Ataxmir cum cannis.	On the treatment of Ataxmir with reeds. 
ET Est, ut conuertas palpebram, et scindas fissuram quae est deintus, secundum quod narraui.	And it is thus: you turn over the eyelid and make an incision in the inner fissure, according to what I have described. 
Deinde arte fac duas cannas, aut duo ligna subtilia: quarum longitudo sit secundum longitudinem palpebrae, et latitudo earum sit minor latitudine spatumilis: et tu iam incidisti in extremitatibus utriusque ab utrisque partibus ubi tenes fila.	Then skillfully make two reeds, or two thin pieces of wood: their length should be according to the length of the eyelid, and their width should be less than the width of a spatula: and you have already made cuts in the extremities of both on both sides where you hold the threads. 
Deinde aggrega utramque cum subtilitate super illud quod superfluit ex palpebra oculi, et stringe duas cannas ab utrisque partibus strictura forti, et dimitte eam diebus aliquot.	Then carefully bring both together over what protrudes from the eyelid, and bind the two reeds tightly on both sides with a strong binding, and leave it for several days. 
Cutis enim stricta morietur, et denigrabitur, et putrefiet, donec cadet per se.	For the constricted skin will die, turn black, and rot, until it falls off by itself. 
Si ergo tardatur, tunc incide eam cum forficibus.	If therefore it is delayed, then cut it with scissors. 
Deinde cura eam, donec sanetur.	Then treat it until it heals. 
Cum ergo consolidatur, eleuatur palpebra: et non pungunt pili.	When therefore it heals, the eyelid is raised: and the hairs do not prick. 
Et haec est forma duarum cannarum, quas facies secundum hanc figuram, et quantitatem in longitudinem et latitudinem.	And this is the form of the two reeds, which you will make according to this figure and measurement in length and width. 
¶ De eleuatione pilorum pungentium in oculo cum acu.	On raising pricking hairs in the eye with a needle.
Caput XII.	Chapter XII. 
Operatio in illo est, ut accipias acum subtilem, et intromittas in eam filum ex serico subtile, lene.	The operation in this case is that you take a fine needle, and insert into it a fine, smooth silk thread. 
Deinde aggreges extremitates eius, et nodes utramque nodo subtili ualde: et sit longitudo filorum palmus unus.	Then gather its ends, and tie both with a very fine knot: and let the length of the threads be one palm. 
Deinde compone in Alinxotati filum aliud subtile sub eo in breui, et noda extremitates eius si uis.	Then arrange in the Alinxotati another fine thread below it briefly, and tie its ends if you wish. 
Deinde ponat infirmus caput suum in sinu tuo, et sit prope solem ut declaretur operatio: quoniam est operatio subtilis, uel minuta.	Then let the patient place his head in your lap, and let it be near the sun so that the operation is clear: since it is a delicate or minute operation. 
Deinde intromitte acum cum alinxotati in radicem palpebrae, et fac eam penetrare in palpebram festinanter, donec extrahas eam desuper pilum naturalem.	Then insert the needle with the alinxotati into the root of the eyelid, and make it penetrate the eyelid quickly, until you draw it out above the natural hair. 
Deinde trahe pilum usque supra alinxotati: et intromitte in alinxotati illum pilum: si est unus, aut duo, aut tres, non plures.	Then draw the hair up above the alinxotati: and insert into the alinxotati that hair: whether it is one, or two, or three, not more. 
Deinde trahe manum tuam cum eo, donec egrediatur pilus cum alinxotati in palpebra cum pilo naturali.	Then pull your hand with it, until the hair comes out with the alinxotati in the eyelid with the natural hair. 
Si autem trahatur alinxotati, et non egrediatur pilus cum ea: trahes alinxotati ad inferiora, cum filo quod tu composuisti in ea, donec egrediatur alinxotati ex foramine superiori, et uideas eam uisione oculi: tunc enim trahes alinxotati, et filum: et extrahe utraque, et claude oculum: et dimitte ipsum clausum duobus diebus, aut tribus, donec adhaereat pilus loco suo, et nascatur super ipsum caro.	But if the alinxotati is pulled and the hair does not come out with it: pull the alinxotati downward, with the thread that you arranged in it, until the alinxotati comes out from the upper opening, and you see it with your eye: then indeed pull the alinxotati and the thread: and extract both, and close the eye: and leave it closed for two or three days, until the hair adheres to its place, and flesh grows over it. 
Quod si pilus est breuis, tunc aut associa ei pilum longum ex pilis naturalibus, et eleuatur cum eo: aut dimitte ipsum, donec elongetur post spacium, et tunc eleua ipsum.	But if the hair is short, then either join to it a long hair from the natural hairs, and it is raised with it: or leave it until it lengthens after a time, and then raise it. 
¶ De cura Alxatrati quae accidit in palpebra superiori.	On the treatment of Alxatrati which occurs in the upper eyelid.
Caput XIII.	Chapter XIII. 
Quando accidit oculo haec Alxatrati, nominatur Leporina.	When this Alxatrati occurs in the eye, it is called Leporina (Hare-eye). 
Et haec Alxatrati est aut naturalis, aut accidentalis.	And this Alxatrati is either natural or accidental. 
Accidentalis ergo fit ex consolidatione uulneris, aut sectionis, aut cauterii, et similium illis.	The accidental therefore occurs from the healing of a wound, or an incision, or a cautery, and similar things to these. 
Et modus operationis in ea est, ut tu findas illam consolidationem, et ut separes labia eius, et ponas in eo quod est inter ea licinium ex lino, et liges eam, donec sanetur.	And the method of operation in it is that you split that healed area, and separate its edges, and place between them a lint of flax, and bind it until it heals. 
Et non oportet, ut utaris in curatione eius rebus quae exiccant et constringunt: nam si tu facis illud, redit Alxatrati deterior quam fuit: imo utere in ea rebus quae mollificant, sicut foenumgraecum: et embroca cum aqua, in qua cocta sit althea, semen lini: et unguento dyaquilon, quod liquefactum sit cum aliquo ex oleis: et inuolue cum eo licinium, et cura cum eo.	And it is not proper that you use in its treatment things which dry out and constrict: for if you do that, the Alxatrati returns worse than it was: rather use in it things which soften, like fenugreek: and foment with water in which marsh-mallow and flaxseed have been cooked: and with diachylon ointment, which has been liquefied with some of the oils: and wrap the lint with it, and treat with it. 
Et thesaurus curationis tuae est, ut coneris omni ingenio, ut non consolidetur, secundum formam quae fuit in primis.	And the treasure of your treatment is that you strive with all ingenuity, that it does not heal according to the form which was there at first. 
Et haec quidem operatio quam diximus, non est nisi quaedam rectificatio Alxatrati, ut non redeat forma loci secundum quod fuit omnino.	And this operation which we have described is nothing but a certain rectification of Alxatrati, so that the form of the place does not return entirely to what it was.
¶ De cura Alxatrati quae fit in palpebra inferiori, et est rugatio uel contractio sursum ad dextrum et sinistrum.	Concerning the treatment of Alxatrati which occurs in the lower eyelid, and is a wrinkling or contraction upward to the right and left.
Caput XIIII.	Chapter 14.
Haec Alxatrati quae fit inferius, est quae uere nominatur Alxatrati.	This Alxatrati which occurs below is what is truly called Alxatrati.
Et est naturalis, et est accidentalis.	And it is natural, and it is accidental.
Et accidentalis fit ex uulnere, aut fissura, aut cauterio, et illis similibus.	And the accidental type occurs from a wound, or a fissure, or cauterization, and similar things.
Et uia operationis in ea est, ut accipias acum, in qua sit filum duplum, et tingas eam in carnem, et facias eam penetrare a lachrymali sinistro usque ad lachrymale dextrum, donec perueniat filum in duabus extremitatibus carnis.	And the method of operation for it is that you should take a needle with a double thread, and push it into the flesh, and make it penetrate from the left tear duct to the right tear duct, until the thread reaches both ends of the flesh.
Deinde extende carnem ad superiora cum acu, et incide eam cum spatumili lato.	Then stretch the flesh upward with the needle, and cut it with a broad spatula.
Si ergo redit figura palpebrae secundum quod oportet, est bonum.	If therefore the shape of the eyelid returns as it should, it is good.
Et si non, accipe radium, et pone ipsum in fissuram, et conuerte cum eo palpebram: et finde duas fissuras in latere interiore palpebrae, et sint extremitates duarum fissurarum ex duobus angulis incisionis, donec concurrant et fiat ex eis angulus: donec quando aggregantur fiat figura earum haec figura, et est litera lauda graeca.	And if not, take a probe, and place it in the fissure, and turn the eyelid with it: and make two fissures on the inner side of the eyelid, and let the ends of the two fissures be from the two angles of the incision, until they meet and form an angle from them: until when they are joined their shape becomes this figure, which is the Greek letter lambda.
Deinde aufer illam carnem per quantitatem, quod est latus eius acutum inferius, ab eo quod sequitur palpebram.	Then remove that flesh by the amount that is its sharp lower edge, from what follows the eyelid.
Deinde aggrega partes separatas: sue eam cum filo lanae.	Then join the separated parts: sew it with wool thread.
Deinde cura eas cum eo quod diximus, de medicinis mollificantibus, et liciniis, donec sanentur.	Then treat them with what we mentioned, with softening medicines, and lint, until they heal.
Et si Alxatrati accidat ex fissura, et sutura, aut cauterio: tunc oportet ut findas fissura plana sub pilis palpebrarum, etiam secundum quod praecessit.	And if Alxatrati occurs from a fissure, and suture, or cauterization: then you should make a flat fissure under the eyelid hairs, also according to what preceded.
Deinde separa inter duo labia cum licinio, secundum quod diximus.	Then separate between the two lips with lint, according to what we said.
Et summa sermonis de cura Alxatrati, quando est desuper, aut inferius, est, ut currat in ea operatio, secundum quod praeparatur ex forma Alxatrati.	And the summary of the discussion about treating Alxatrati, whether it is above or below, is that the operation should proceed in it according to how the form of Alxatrati presents itself.
Ipsa namque est multarum diuersitatum in forma: et artifex prudens praeparat ingenium cum quocunque modo est possibile ei, donec redire faciat figuram ad formam naturalem, aut prope eam, et ipsemet infirmus, secundum quod conuenit ei ex operatione et instrumentis in plurimis dispositionibus.	For it has many variations in form: and the skilled craftsman prepares his technique in whatever way is possible for him, until he makes the shape return to its natural form, or close to it, and the patient himself, according to what suits him in terms of operation and instruments in most conditions.
¶ De adhaerentia palpebrae oculi cum coniunctiua, aut cornea.	Concerning the adhesion of the eyelid with the conjunctiva, or cornea.
Caput XV.	Chapter 15.
Quandoque accidit haec consolidatio multis hominibus, ita ut consolidetur palpebra superior cum albedine oculi, et prohibeat ipsum ab operationibus suis naturalibus.	Sometimes this consolidation happens to many people, such that the upper eyelid consolidates with the white of the eye, and prevents it from its natural operations.
Oportet ergo quod intromittas extremitatem radii sub palpebra, et eleues eam sursum: aut extendas eam cum uncino: deinde incide adhaerentiam cum spatumili subtili, quod non sit cum acuitate incisionis spatumilium, imo sit obtusum parumper: ut non inquietetur infirmus apud operationem, et remoueatur spatumile, et laedat oculum cum acuitate sua: et sit incisio tua quasi tu excories illam adhaerentiam cum facilitate, donec quando redit palpebra secundum formam suam naturalem, et sanetur adhaerentia tota.	Therefore it is necessary that you insert the end of a probe under the eyelid, and raise it upward: or stretch it with a hook: then cut the adhesion with a fine spatula, which should not have a sharp cutting edge, rather it should be somewhat blunt: so that the patient is not disturbed during the operation, and the spatula is removed, and does not harm the eye with its sharpness: and your incision should be as if you are skinning that adhesion with ease, until when the eyelid returns to its natural form, and the entire adhesion heals.
Funde tunc in oculum aquam salsam, cum aqua ablue ipsum: aut distilla in ipsum ex sief facto, ex ziniar dissoluto cum aqua.	Then pour salt water into the eye, wash it with water: or drip into it from an eye-salve made from verdigris dissolved in water.
Deinde separa inter palpebram et oculum cum licinio lini: et pone super oculum lanam infusam cum albugine oui: et post diem tertium utere sief, et cum solidatiuis, donec sanetur.	Then separate between the eyelid and eye with linen lint: and place over the eye wool soaked in egg white: and after the third day use eye-salve, and with healing agents, until it heals.
¶ De incisione ungulae et eminentiae carnis lachrymarum.	¶ On the incision of the pterygium and the prominent flesh of the tear ducts.
Caput XVI.	Chapter 16.
Scias, quod ungula est secundum duos modos.	Know that the pterygium occurs in two forms.
Aut est neruosa: et est similis sifac duro, subtili.	Either it is fibrous: and it is similar to a hard, thin membrane.
Aut est non neruosa, similis humiditati congelatae albae: quae quando tangit cam ferrum, aut conaris capere eam cum uncino, abscinditur, et non figitur in ea uncinus.	Or it is non-fibrous, similar to white congealed fluid: which when iron touches it, or when you try to grasp it with a hook, it breaks apart, and the hook does not hold in it.
Et utraeque species non incipiunt, nisi a lachrymali maiore, usquequo uadit paulatim, donec cooperit uisum, et prohibet lumen, et motum oculi.	And both types begin only from the larger tear duct, until it gradually progresses until it covers the vision, and blocks light, and movement of the eye.
Et modus operandi in incisione eius est: ut ponat infirmus caput suum in sinu tuo.	And the method of operating in its incision is: that the patient places their head in your lap.
Deinde aperi oculos eius, et eleua palpebram manu tua.	Then open their eyes, and lift the eyelid with your hand.
Deinde collige ungulam cum uncino paucae duplationis, et extende eam ad superiora.	Then gather the pterygium with a hook of little doubling, and extend it upwards.
Deinde accipe acum, et intromitte in eam pilum ex pilis equi, et bouis, aut uaccae: et sit filum forte, et duplica extremitatem acus parumper, et fige eam in medio ungulae: et penetra eam cum acu, et liga cum filo ungulam, et extende eam ad superiora: et excoria cum pilo latus ungulae quod sequitur pupillam, ac si tu serres eam cum pilo usque ad postreimnum eius.	Then take a needle, and insert into it a hair from a horse, and ox, or cow: and let the thread be strong, and double the end of the needle slightly, and fix it in the middle of the pterygium: and penetrate it with the needle, and tie the pterygium with the thread, and extend it upwards: and strip away with the hair the side of the pterygium that follows the pupil, as if you were sawing it with the hair all the way to its end.
Deinde incide residuum in radice lachrymalis cum spatumili subtili, aut cum forficibus paruis: et dimitte carnem lachrymalis naturalem, ut non accidat ex incisione eius cursus lachrymarum assiduus.	Then cut the remainder at the root of the tear duct with a fine spatula, or with small scissors: and leave the natural flesh of the tear duct, so that constant tearing does not occur from its incision.
Et quandoque extenditur ungula cum uncino solo: aut cum filo, sicut diximus.	And sometimes the pterygium is extended with just a hook: or with thread, as we have said.
Deinde excoriatur cum spatumili leni, cuius haec est forma.	Then it is stripped away with a smooth spatula, whose form is this.
Et caue, ne tangat spatumile tunicam corneam, et accidat in ea ruptura, et perforetur pupilla.	And be careful, lest the spatula touch the cornea, and a rupture occurs in it, and the pupil is perforated.
Deinde post incisionem, proice in oculum aliquid salis contriti, aut ex sief facto ex ziniar, et dimitte ipsum usque ad diem alium.	Then after the incision, throw into the eye some ground salt, or from an eye-salve made from verdigris, and leave it until another day.
Deinde cura ipsum cum eo quod oportet, usquequo sanetur.	Then treat it with what is appropriate, until it heals.
Quod si ungula est non neruosa, et non potes intromittere in eam acum, neque figitur in ea uncinus, tunc multotiens curatur haec species ungulae cum medicinis, et sanatur sicut narraui in diuisione.	But if the pterygium is non-fibrous, and you cannot insert a needle into it, nor does a hook hold in it, then many times this type of pterygium is treated with medicines, and heals as I described in the division.
Quod si uis incidere eam, tunc aperi oculum infirmi, et accipe spatumile subtile, lene, debilis acuitatis, secundum hanc formam.	But if you wish to cut it, then open the patient's eye, and take a fine spatula, smooth, of weak sharpness, according to this form.
Et rade ungulam desuper rasione cum subtilitate.	And scrape the pterygium from above with a scraping motion with delicacy.
