Et caueat a tactu suae epiglotis, ut non accidat ei tussis, et impellat cum eo os, aut spinam, aut intromittat ipsum medicus manu sua.	And he should beware of touching his epiglottis, lest coughing occur, and push the bone or thorn with it, or let the physician insert it with his hand.
Verum quod infirmus intromittat, hoc est melius: propter scientiam suam de loco rei annexae: et impellat inferius, aut trahat manum suam cum instrumento sursum, totum illud secundum quantitatem quae praeparatur ei, donec egrediatur.	Indeed it is better that the patient insert it: because of his knowledge of the location of the attached thing: and push downward, or pull his hand with the instrument upward, all that according to the amount that is prepared for him, until it comes out.
¶ De extractione Sanguisugae.	¶ On the extraction of Leeches.
Caput XXXIX.	Chapter 39.
Quando medicatur sanguisuga cum eo quod dixi in diuisione ex curatione cum medicinis, et non confert, tunc considera in gutture infirmi coram sole, siue apud solem postquam premis linguam eius cum instrumento quod narraui tibi.	When a leech is treated with what I mentioned in the division about treatment with medicines, and it does not help, then examine the patient's throat in front of the sun, or by the sun after you press his tongue with the instrument I described to you.
Si ergo cadit uisus tuus super sanguisugam, extrahe eam cum uncino paruo, aut cum gesti subtilibus decenter.	If therefore your sight falls upon the leech, extract it with a small hook, or with fine forceps appropriately.
Quod si non est possibile cum eis: tunc accipe cannulam concauam, et intromitte eam in guttur infirmi usque prope guttur: deinde intromitte in concauitatem cannulae ferrum ignitum cum igne.	But if it is not possible with these: then take a hollow reed, and insert it into the patient's throat up to near the throat: then insert into the hollow of the reed an iron heated with fire.
Fac illud multotiens: et abstineat infirmus ab aqua tota die.	Do this many times: and let the patient abstain from water all day.
Deinde accipiat uitreatam plenam aqua frigida, et aperiat os eius in ea: et colluat os suum cum ea, et non deglutiat ex ea aliquid: et moueat aquam una hora post aliam cum manu sua.	Then let him take a glass full of cold water, and open his mouth in it: and let him rinse his mouth with it, and not swallow any of it: and let him move the water one hour after another with his hand.
Sanguisuga enim ilico cum sentit aquam cadit.	For the leech immediately falls when it senses water.
Si autem non egreditur cum eo quod narrauimus, tunc suffumiga infirmum cum cimicibus, aut cum asa cum instrumento quod narraui in suffumigatione uuulae.	If however it does not come out with what we have described, then fumigate the patient with bedbugs, or with asafoetida using the instrument I described for fumigation of the uvula.
Fac illud multotiens, quoniam ipsa cadet.	Do this many times, for it will fall.
Et modus operationis in suffumigatione est, ut accipias ollam, in qua sint prunae uiuae cum igne: et olla sit cooperta cum coopertorio, in cuius medio sit foramen: et componatur in illo foramine extremitas instrumenti.	And the method of operation in fumigation is that you take a pot, in which there are live coals with fire: and let the pot be covered with a lid, in whose middle there is a hole: and let the end of the instrument be placed in that hole.
Deinde proiice suffumigationem, et ponat infirmus os suum in extremitate cannulae, et claudat os suum, ut non egrediatur suffumigatio, donec scias quod suffumigatio iam peruenit ad sanguisugam.	Then cast the fumigation, and let the patient put his mouth on the end of the reed, and close his mouth, so that the fumigation does not escape, until you know that the fumigation has already reached the leech.
Nam sanguisuga statim cadet.	For the leech will immediately fall.
Quod si non cadit, tunc itera suffumigationem multotiens.	But if it does not fall, then repeat the fumigation many times.
Et toleret infirmus sitim, et comedat salsa, et allia, et non bibat aquam.	And let the patient endure thirst, and eat salty things, and garlic, and not drink water.
Necesse est ergo ut egrediatur cum hoc regimine.	It is therefore necessary that it come out with this regimen.
Et haec est forma instrumenti cum quo extrahitur sanguisuga ex gutture, quando cadit super ipsam uisus.	And this is the form of the instrument with which the leech is extracted from the throat, when sight falls upon it.
Est simile forcipibus, sicut uides: nisi quia est ei haee curuitas quae intromittitur ad guttur.	It is similar to forceps, as you see: except that it has this curve which is inserted into the throat.
Et extremitas eius similis ori auis quae nominatur ciconia, in quo est asperitas limae: quando comprehendit aliquid, non dimittit ipsum omnino.	And its end is similar to the mouth of a bird which is called a stork, in which there is the roughness of a file: when it grasps something, it does not let it go at all.
¶ De apertione Apostematum, et eorum sectione, et cura in genere.	On the opening of Abscesses, and their incision, and treatment in general.
Caput XL.	Chapter 40.
Apostematum species sunt multae, multorum modorum, secundum quod uenit rememoratio eorum, scilicet unius, et unius in hoc libro: et sunt diuersae in perforatione eorum, et sectione ipsorum ex duobus modis.	There are many types of abscesses, of many kinds, according to what has been mentioned about them, namely one by one in this book: and they differ in their perforation and incision in two ways.
Quorum unus est ex specie apostematis in seipso, et eo quod comprehendit ex humiditatibus.	One of these is from the type of abscess itself, and what it contains of fluids.
Et modus secundus est propter loca, in quibus accidit ex corpore.	And the second way is because of the places in the body where it occurs.
Quoniam apostema accidens in capite, est aliud ab apostemate accidente in ano: et apostema accidens in loco carnoso, est aliud ab apostemate accidente in iuncturis: et unicuique eorum est iudicium suum ex operatione.	For an abscess occurring in the head is different from an abscess occurring in the anus: and an abscess occurring in a fleshy place is different from an abscess occurring in the joints: and each of them has its own judgment regarding treatment.
Et ex apostematibus sunt quae non oportet ut perforentur, nisi post maturationem saniei in eis, et complementum eius: et ex eis sunt, quae oportet ut perforentur, dum sunt cruda, et non maturantur secundum complementum.	And among abscesses there are those which should not be opened except after the maturation of pus in them and its completion: and among them are those which should be opened while they are raw and not fully matured.
Sicut apostemata quae sunt propinqua iuncturis.	Like abscesses that are near to joints.
Quoniam apostema quando accidit prope iuncturam, et prolongatur esse eius, donec putrefit quod est in circumitu eius fortasse corrumpuntur ligamenta, aut nerui illius iuncturae: quare est caussa propior contractionis illius membri.	For when an abscess occurs near a joint and its existence is prolonged until what is around it putrefies, perhaps the ligaments or nerves of that joint are corrupted: which is a more immediate cause of contraction of that limb.
Aut est apostema apud membrum principale: quoniam si tu tardas perforationem eius, donec maturetur, nocebit uel illi, uel per illud membro principali.	Or it is an abscess near a principal member: for if you delay its opening until it matures, it will harm either it or through it the principal member.
Aut est prope anum, perfora ergo ipsum immaturum: et non oportet, ut perfores, apostema crudum, non completae digestionis, nisi quod est prope anum, ut non putrefiat profundum, et longetur ad interiora ani, et fiat fistula, aut fiat in termino eius quod non sanatur.	Or it is near the anus, therefore pierce it while immature: and you should not pierce a raw abscess of incomplete digestion, except what is near the anus, so that it does not putrefy deeply and extend to the interior of the anus, and become a fistula, or reach a point where it cannot be healed.
Oportet ut scias horam perforationis apostematis, quod maturatum est secundum complementum: et est apud sedationem doloris, recessionem febris, et diminutionem rubedinis, et pulsationis, et acuitatem capitis apostematis: et reliqua signa.	You should know the time for opening an abscess that is fully matured: and it is upon the settling of pain, recession of fever, and diminution of redness and pulsation, and sharpness of the head of the abscess: and other signs.
Et oportet, ut facias eandem perforationem in inferiori loco apostematis, et uehementioris eminentiae: et sit perforatio uadens in longitudine corporis, si apostemata sunt in partibus manuum et pedum, et locis lacertorum, et chordarum, et neruorum, et arteriarum, et ad ultimum in omnibus locis aequalibus, quibus non est reflexio.	And you should make the same perforation in the lower part of the abscess and at its most prominent point: and let the perforation go in the length of the body, if the abscesses are in parts of the hands and feet, and in places of muscles, tendons, nerves, and arteries, and finally in all even places which have no bend.
In illis autem quae reflectuntur, uade cum perforatione secundum illud membrum.	In those that do bend, proceed with the perforation according to that member.
Quando uero apostema est in locis carnosis: tunc melius est ut dimittas perforationem eius, donec confirmetur eius digestio, sicut diximus secundum complementum.	When the abscess is in fleshy places: then it is better to postpone its perforation until its digestion is confirmed, as we said, to completion.
Quoniam si tu perforas ipsum ante illud, prolongatur cursus uirus ex eo, et est multae sordis et sordiciei, et fortasse indurantur labia eius, et profunditas eius.	For if you pierce it before that, the flow of virus from it is prolonged, and there is much filth and dirt, and perhaps its lips and its depth become hardened.
Et quaedam apostemata perforantur secundum latitudinem corporis apud necessitatem: aut secundum illud quo indiget membrum.	And certain abscesses are perforated according to the width of the body when necessary: or according to what the member needs.
Et oportet, ut administres in apostematibus paruis perforationem paruam, et in apostematibus magnis perforationem amplam: aut sectiones multas per similitudinem magnitudinis apostematis.	And you should administer in small abscesses a small perforation, and in large abscesses a wide perforation: or many incisions according to the similarity of the size of the abscess.
Et sunt ex apostematibus, in quibus oportet ut concauetur cutis: et incidatur quando iam facta est sicut pannus, et facta est in termino, quod iam mortua est: sicut illud quod accidit in multis, ut dubelet, et bubonibus.	And there are among abscesses those in which it is necessary to hollow out the skin: and cut it when it has already become like cloth, and has reached the point where it is already dead: like that which occurs in many, such as dubelet and buboes.
Et ex eis sunt quae secantur sectione habente tres angulos.	And among them are those which are cut with a triangular incision.
Et ex eis est, ex quo inciditur sicut figura folii myrti.	And among them is that from which is cut like the shape of a myrtle leaf.
Sicut apostema inguinum.	Like the abscess of the groin.
Et ex eis sunt in quibus administratur sectio rotunda, et sectio lunaris: et similes eis ex sectionibus.	And among them are those in which a round incision and a lunar incision are administered: and similar ones from incisions.
Illud uero cui non est caput, sicut sunt apostemata lenia superficialia, oportet ut perfores ipsum perforatione superficiali, uel plana tantum.	That which has no head, like superficial smooth abscesses, you should pierce it with a superficial or flat perforation only.
Et oportet, quando apostema est grossum, et iam collegit saniem multam, et perforas ipsum, ut non properes et extrahas pus totum in illa hora: imo extrahe ex ipso partem eius.	And it is necessary, when the abscess is large and has already collected much pus, and you pierce it, that you do not hurry and extract all the pus at that time: rather extract a portion of it.
Deinde opila apostema usque ad diem alium.	Then plug the abscess until another day.
Deinde extrahe quiddam ex pus iterum.	Then extract some more pus again.
Fac illud multotiens secundum gradationem, donec egrediatur: praecipue si infirmus est debilis uirtutis, aut mulier praegnans, aut puer paruus, aur senex decrepitus: spiritus enim animalis ab animali multotiens resoluitur cum egressione saniei: et fortasse moritur infirmus, et tu non percipis.	Do this many times gradually until it comes out: especially if the patient is weak in strength, or a pregnant woman, or a small child, or a decrepit old man: for the vital spirit often leaves the body with the release of pus: and perhaps the patient dies, and you do not perceive it.
Caue ergo hoc capitulum cautela magna.	Therefore be very careful with this chapter.
Et post perforationem tuam, qua ista perforas apostemata, oportet ut abstergas uulnus: et considera.	And after your perforation, with which you pierce these abscesses, you should clean the wound: and observe.
Si ergo est uulnus apostematis paruum, aut est sectio plana, tunc administra licinia ex lino, aut coto antiquo.	If therefore the wound of the abscess is small, or the incision is flat, then apply lint made from linen or old cotton.
Et si est apostema magnum, et fissurae perforationis multae sunt, oportet tunc ut intromittas in omnem fissuram licinium, donec perueniant adinuicem.	And if the abscess is large, and there are many fissures from the perforation, then it is necessary to insert lint into every fissure, until they meet each other.
Et si in apostemate abscidisti partem cutis, aut in circumitu concauasti eam: tunc oportet ut impleas eam coto ueteri, aut sicut quando texitur pannus, aut raditur lanugine lini absque humiditate: et stringe ipsum usque ad tertium diem.	And if in the abscess you have cut away part of the skin, or hollowed it out around the circumference: then you should fill it with old cotton, or as when cloth is woven, or with scraped flax fiber without moisture: and bind it until the third day.
Deinde proiice ipsum, et cura illud cum eo quod oportet ex unguento, donec sanetur.	Then remove it, and treat it with whatever ointment is necessary, until it heals.
Si autem accidat fluxus sanguinis in hora tuae operationis, tunc administra aquam frigidam, et acetum, postquam imbibitur in eis pannus: et ponis ipsum super locum fluxus sanguinis multotiens.	If however bleeding occurs at the time of your operation, then apply cold water and vinegar, after a cloth has been soaked in them: and place it over the site of bleeding many times.
Si autem perseuerat fluxus sanguinis, tunc oportet ut administres regimen, et curationem, et pulueres, quae narraui in locis multis huius nostri libri, et ex diuisione.	If however the bleeding persists, then you should administer the regimen, and treatment, and powders, which I have described in many places of this book of ours, and from the division.
Si autem est in tempore hyemis, et locus apostematis est multorum neruorum: tunc oportet ut infundas puluillos cum uino, et oleo calidis: et ponas eos super loca.	If however it is in winter time, and the site of the abscess has many nerves: then you should soak the compresses with warm wine and oil: and place them over the areas.
Et si fuerit in aestate, et loca sunt carnosa: tunc oportet ut ponas puluillos imbibitos in aqua, et oleo, aut eum uino et oleo, et totum illud frigidum.	And if it is in summer, and the areas are fleshy: then you should place compresses soaked in water and oil, or with wine and oil, and all of that cold.
Donec quando erit dies tertius, sicut diximus, tunc oportet ut soluas apostema, et abstergas ipsum, et administres in curatione eius quod ei conuenit, donec sanetur.	Until when it will be the third day, as we have said, then you should loosen the abscess, and clean it, and administer in its treatment what is suitable for it, until it heals.
Hoc est ergo quod necessarium est ex cognitione curationis apostematum uniuersaliter.	This therefore is what is necessary to know about the treatment of abscesses in general.
Secundum semitam uero distinctionis, iam dixi de omni apostemate, qualiter est uia ad curationem eius capitulatim singulariter.	According to the path of distinction, I have already spoken about every abscess, how there is a way to its treatment chapter by chapter individually.
¶ De sectione apostematum quae accidunt in cute capitis.	On the incision of abscesses that occur in the skin of the head.
Caput XLI.	Chapter 41.
Accidunt in cute capitis apostemata parua, et sunt ex speciebus Nodorum, quos continent tunicae, quae sunt eis sacci: quasi ipsa sint hausolati gallinae.	Small abscesses occur in the skin of the head, and they are of the types of Nodes, which are contained by tunics that are like sacs to them: as if they were like the crop of a chicken.
Et ipsorum species sunt multae.	And their types are many.
Ex eis sunt pingues: et ex eis sunt quae continent humiditatem similem limo: et ex eis quae continent humiditatem similem frisatis et pultibus: et eis similibus, et ex eis sunt, quae sunt lapidea dura.	Among them are fatty ones: and among them are those that contain moisture similar to mud: and among them are those that contain moisture similar to ground grain and porridge: and similar things, and among them are those that are stone-hard.
Et in sectione omnium, et ipsorum extractione non est timor, dum apud ipsorum sectionem non facit contrarietatem arteria.	And in the incision of all of them, and their extraction there is no fear, as long as during their incision no artery presents opposition.
Et operatio in sectione eorum est, ut experiaris ea cum instrumento, cuius forma uenit post haec, quod nominatur Intromissum, donec scias quid contineat.	And the procedure in cutting them is that you examine them with an instrument, whose form comes after this, which is called the Probe, until you know what it contains.
Nam si est illud quod continet humiditas, tunc seca ipsum sectione secundum longitudinem sectione superficiali: secundum hanc formam.	For if it is that which contains fluid, then cut it with an incision along the length with a superficial cut: according to this form.
Et incipe cum sectione ex linea b. ad lineam, g. Cum ergo euacuatur humiditas, tunc excoria kistin quae continet illam humiditatem, et non dimittas ex ea aliquid penitus.	And begin with the incision from line b. to line g. Then when the fluid is evacuated, strip away the cyst which contains that fluid, and do not leave any of it at all.
Multotiens enim redit, si remanet ex ea aliquid.	For many times it returns, if anything of it remains.
Deinde submerge cotum in unguento aegyptio, si est praesens: et si non, in aqua et sale: et imple cum eo uulnus, et dimitte ipsum usque ad diem alium.	Then submerge cotton in Egyptian ointment, if it is available: and if not, in water and salt: and fill the wound with it, and leave it until another day.
Ipsum enim corrodet quod remansit ex kisti.	For it will corrode what remained of the cyst.
Deinde itera super ipsum cotum cum aegyptio secundo, et tertio, et si indiges illo, donec confidas quia non remanserit ex kisti aliquid, tunc enim cura uulnus cum unguento, donec sanetur.	Then repeat the cotton with Egyptian [ointment] a second and third time, and if you need it, until you are confident that nothing remains of the cyst, then treat the wound with ointment until it heals.
Quod si apostema continet nodum pinguem: tunc seca ipsum secundum hanc formam, sectione habente formam crucis: et proiice uncinos inter duolabia sectionis, et excoria ipsum ab omni parte: et conare uirtutem tuam in extractione tunicae quae continet ipsum.	But if the abscess contains a fatty node: then cut it according to this form, with an incision having the form of a cross: and insert hooks between the two lips of the incision, and strip it away from all sides: and concentrate your strength in extracting the tunic which contains it.
Si autem contrarietatem facit tibi arteria, tunc fac illud quod narrabo tibi post.	But if an artery presents opposition to you, then do what I will tell you later.
Et similiter fac in apostemate, si est lapideum, ex sectione, et curatione eadem, secundum quod diximus.	And similarly do in the case of an abscess, if it is stony, with the same incision and treatment, according to what we have said.
Et sectio super apostema lapideum est facilior: quoniam est pauci sanguinis et humiditatis.	And the incision upon a stony abscess is easier: since it has little blood and moisture.
Et quandoque sunt quaedam horum apostematum quae sunt in capite in quibusdam hominibus, cum quibus penitus non est humiditas.	And sometimes there are certain of these abscesses which are in the head in some people, with which there is absolutely no moisture.
Quod est: quia ego secui super apostema in capite mulieris uetulae, et inueni apostema sicut lapis solidus et durus, asper, albus, qui non poterat frangi: et si percuteretur cum eo aliquis proiiciendo, uulnerat ipsum.	That is: because I cut into an abscess in the head of an old woman, and found the abscess like a solid and hard stone, rough, white, which could not be broken: and if someone were struck by throwing it, it would wound them.
In aliis uero apostematibus accidentibus in capite, praeter haec scilicet apostemata quae accidunt in capitibus puerorum, et apud radices aurium, sectio eorum omnium sit sectio superficialis.	In other abscesses occurring in the head, besides these namely abscesses which occur in the heads of children, and near the roots of the ears, the incision of all of them should be a superficial incision.
Vel pone perforationem eorum semper ab inferiori parte eorum, ut alleuietur cursus saniei ad inferiora.	Or place their perforation always at their lower part, so that the flow of pus is eased downward.
Deinde cura ea cum eo quod conuenit eis ex curatione.	Then treat them with what is suitable for them in terms of treatment.
¶ De sectione Strophularum in collo.	On the Excision of Scrofulas in the Neck.
Caput XLII.	Chapter 42.
Multotiens acccidunt ista apostemata in collo, et sub assellis, et inguinibus: et quandoque accidunt in reliquo corpore.	These swellings often occur in the neck, and under the armpits, and in the groins: and sometimes they occur in the rest of the body.
Et super illa quae ex eis accidunt in collo, sunt unum, et multa: et generantur ab inuicem: et omnis Strophula ex eis est intra tunicam propriam ei, sicut est in nodis et apostematibus capitis, sicut narrauimus.	And those of them that occur in the neck are single or multiple: and they generate from one another: and every Scrofula among them is within its own membrane, as is the case with nodes and swellings of the head, as we have described.
Et species harum Strophularum sunt multae.	And the types of these Scrofulas are many.
Et ex eis enim sunt lapideae: et ex eis sunt quae continent humiditates: et ex eis sunt malignae, quae non obediunt curationi.	And among them indeed some are stone-like: and some of them contain fluids: and some of them are malignant, which do not respond to treatment.
In illa ergo quam ex eis uides bonae dispositionis in tactu, cuius manifestum est propinquum colori cutis, et mouetur ad omnem partem, et non est annexa cum neruis colli, neque cum guidegi, neque cum arteria, neque est profunda: oportet ut seces eam sectione superficiali a superiori parte ad inferiorem partem corporis ex linea, b. ad lineam, g. et excoria eam ab omni parte: et extende duo labia cutis cum uncino, aut cum uncinis multis, si indiges illo, sicut diximus in apostematibus capitis, et extrahe eam paulatim.	Therefore, for the one among them that you see to be of good condition to the touch, whose appearance is close to skin color, and moves in all directions, and is not attached to the nerves of the neck, nor to the jugular, nor to the artery, nor is deep: you should cut it with a superficial incision from the upper part to the lower part of the body from line b. to line g. and separate it from all sides: and stretch the two lips of skin with a hook, or with many hooks, if you need that, as we said regarding swellings of the head, and extract it gradually.
Et est super cautelam, ut non incidatur uena, aut neruus.	And one must be cautious not to cut a vein or nerve.
Et sit spatumile non acutum ualde: ut non addat tibi manum tuam cum incisione, aut inquietet infirmum, et incidas quod non est necesse.	And let the spatula not be too sharp: so that it does not slip in your hand during cutting, or disturb the patient, and you cut what is not necessary.
Si autem incidis uenam, aut arteriam, aut prohibet te ab operatione, tunc pone in uulnus zegi tritum, aut quosdam pulueres qui abscindunt sanguinem, et stringe uulnus, et dimitte ipsum, donec quiescat acuitas apostematis, et mollificetur uulnus: uel incipit et uult putrefieri.	If however you cut a vein, or artery, or it prevents you from operating, then place ground vitriol in the wound, or certain powders which stop blood, and bind the wound, and leave it until the acuteness of the swelling subsides, and the wound softens: or it begins and wants to putrefy.
Nam sanguis abscinditur tuncia Redi ergo ad operationem tuam, donec compleas.	For the blood is stopped at once. Therefore return to your operation, until you complete it.
Deinde inquire digito tuo indice, si remansit aliquid ex Strophulis aliis paruis: ergo incide eas, et munda eas.	Then investigate with your index finger if any other small Scrofulas remain: therefore cut them out and clean them.
Quod si est in radice Strophulae uena magna: tunc oportet ut non incidas illam Strophulam ex radice sua: imo oportet ut liges eam cum filo duplato forti, et dimittas eam donec cadat per se absque nocumento.	But if there is a large vein at the root of the Scrofula: then you should not cut that Scrofula from its root: rather you should tie it with a strong doubled thread, and leave it until it falls off by itself without harm.
Deinde imple uulnus coto ueteri, quod iam submersisti in unguento aegyptio.	Then fill the wound with old cotton, which you have already immersed in Egyptian ointment.
Deinde cura ipsum.	Then treat it.
Si inciditur Strophula tota, tunc oportet ut aggreges labia duo uulneris: et suas ipsum statim, postquam uides quia prorsus non remansit superfluitas.	If the whole Scrofula is cut out, then you should bring together the two lips of the wound: and suture it immediately, after you see that absolutely no excess remains.
Si autem uides quod remansit superfluitas propter magnitudinem Strophulae, tunc oportet ut intendas ad incidendam radicem eius, et extrahendam eam: et administra suturam quam diximus.	If however you see that excess remains due to the size of the Scrofula, then you should aim to cut its root, and extract it: and apply the suture which we mentioned.
Et quae ex Strophulis continet humiditates, perfora illam perforatione superficiali: ut appareat tibi locus maturitatis eius: et pone perforationem ab eo quod sequitur inferius corporis, sicut diximus.	And for those Scrofulas which contain fluids, pierce it with a superficial perforation: so that its point of maturation appears to you: and make the perforation from that which follows below the body, as we said.
Deinde administra post perforationem licinia cum unguento, et similia eis, ut corrodat quod remansit ex corruptione, donec quando uides uulnus iam mundatum esse: tunc cura ipsum cum unguento generatiuo carnis, donec sanetur.	Then after perforation, apply dressings with ointment, and similar things, to remove what remains of the corruption, until when you see the wound is now clean: then treat it with flesh-generating ointment until it heals.
¶ De sectione Epiglotis ab apostemate intra guttur accidente.	¶ On the incision of the Epiglottis from an abscess occurring inside the throat.
Caput XLIII.	Chapter 43.
Dixerunt antiqui hanc sectionem in Epigloti, et non uidi aliquem in terra nostra, qui eam fecerit: et haec est scriptura sermonis eorum.	The ancients spoke of this incision in the Epiglottis, and I have not seen anyone in our land who has performed it: and this is the writing of their discourse.
In habentibus autem synanchiam, oportet ut deuitetur sectio Epiglotis: cum non fiat iuuamentum per illud: propterea, quod omnes uenae et pulmo sunt infirmi.	In those having quinsy, the cutting of the Epiglottis should be avoided: since no benefit comes from it: because all the veins and the lung are weak.
In illis uero qui habent apostema calidum in ore, aut gutture, aut duabus amigdalis, quando non est aegritudo in cannali, oportet uti sectione Epiglotis, ad fugiendum ex perditione quae fit ex praefocatione.	But in those who have a hot abscess in the mouth, or throat, or both tonsils, when there is no disease in the airway, it is necessary to use incision of the Epiglottis, to escape from the destruction that comes from suffocation.
Oportet ergo quando uolumus illud, ut secemus Epiglotim sub tribus circulis Epiglotis, aut quatuor, sectione parua per latitudinem, in eo quod est inter duos circulos per quantitatem, quod sit sectio in sifac, non in cartilagine: et iste quidem locus est conueniens sectioni, quoniam est priuatus carne, et uasa sanguinis ab eo sunt longinqua.	Therefore when we wish to do this, we should cut the Epiglottis below three rings of the Epiglottis, or four, with a small incision across the width, in that which is between two rings by such an amount, that the cut is in the membrane, not in the cartilage: and this indeed is the suitable place for cutting, since it is devoid of flesh, and blood vessels are far from it.
Quod si medicator est timidus, tunc oportet ut extendat cutem gutturis cum uncino.	But if the physician is timid, then he should stretch the throat skin with a hook.
Deinde findat cutem, donec quando peruenit ad cannalem: deuitet uas sanguinis, si uidet ex eis aliquid.	Then split the skin, until when he reaches the airway: avoid blood vessels, if he sees any of them.
Deinde secet sifac quod narrauimus: et significatur super sectionem cannalis ex phlegmate quod egreditur ex ea, cum eo quod disrumpitur, et abscisione uocis.	Then cut the membrane which we described: and the cutting of the airway is indicated by phlegm which comes out of it, with that which bursts forth, and loss of voice.
Et dimitte uulnus apertum tempore aliquo.	And leave the wound open for some time.
Cum ergo remouetur hora in qua timetur praefocatio, aggrega duo labia uulneris cutis, et sue ipsam solam absque cartilagine.	When therefore the time passes in which suffocation is feared, bring together the two lips of the skin wound, and sew it alone without the cartilage.
Deinde administra medicinas quae faciunt nasci carnem, usquequo sanetur.	Then apply medicines which cause flesh to grow, until it heals.
Inquit Albucasis.	Albucasis says:
Summa huius sermonis quem narrauimus, expositio non est, nisi quando uident, quod aliquod horum apostematum iam opilauit guttur infirmi: et sublimatus est infirmus super mortem, et uult intersecari anhelitus eius: uadunt ad secandum Epiglotim, ut respiret infirmus super locum uulneris quadam respiratione, et saluetur a morte: et propter hoc praeceperunt dimittere uulnus apertum, donec consumatur malicia aegritudinis, et est malicia eius tribus diebus, et quasi ipsa: tunc ergo praecaeperunt suere uulnus, et curare ipsum, donec sanetur.	The sum of this discourse which we have related, the explanation is only when they see that one of these abscesses has already blocked the throat of the sick person: and the sick person has been raised above death, and his breath wants to be cut off: they proceed to cut the Epiglottis, so that the sick person may breathe through the wound site with some breathing, and be saved from death: and because of this they instructed to leave the wound open, until the malignancy of the disease is consumed, and its malignancy is three days, and almost the same: then therefore they instructed to sew the wound, and treat it until it heals.
Et illud quod uidi per me ipsum est, quod una ancilla accaepit cultellum, et misit cum in guttur suum, et incidit cum eo partem cannalis pulmonis.	And that which I saw myself is that a maid took a knife, and put it in her throat, and cut with it part of the lung's airway.
Et uocatus sum ad curationem eius, et inueni eam mugire, sicut est mugitus mortui.	And I was called to treat her, and I found her moaning, like the moaning of the dying.
Detexi ergo a uulnere, et inueni sanguinem qui egressus fuerat ex uulnere paruum.	I thus uncovered the wound, and found the blood which had come out from the wound was little.
Confisus ergo sum, quod ipsa non absciderat uenam, neque guidegi: et uentus egrediebatur ex uulnere.	I was thus confident that she had not cut a vein, nor the jugular: and wind was coming out of the wound.
Properaui ergo, et sui uulnus, et curaui ipsum, donec sanum est: et non accidit ancillae aliquid, nisi raucedo in uoce: et rediit post dies ad meliorem dispositionum suarum.	I hurried therefore, and sewed the wound, and treated it until it was healed: and nothing happened to the maid, except hoarseness in her voice: and after days she returned to her better conditions.
Hinc ergo dico: quod in sectione Epiglotis non est timor.	Hence therefore I say: that in cutting the Epiglottis there is no fear.
¶ De sectione Herniae gutturis.	¶ On cutting the Hernia of the throat.
Caput XLIIII.	Chapter 44.
Hoc Apostema nominatum Hernia gutturis, est apostema magnum, secundum colorem corporis: et est in mulieribus multum.	This Abscess named Hernia of the throat, is a large abscess, according to the color of the body: and it is common in women.
Et est secundum duos modos: aut enim est naturale: aut est accidentale.	And it is of two types: for either it is natural: or it is accidental.
In naturali certe non est ingenium.	In the natural certainly there is no remedy.
Accidentale uero est secundum duos modos: quorum unus est similis nodis pinguibus.	But the accidental is of two types: of which one is similar to fatty nodes.
Et modus alter, est similis apostemati quod fit ex nodatione arteriae.	And the other type is similar to an abscess which occurs from knotting of the artery.
Et in ipso est timor, et non oportet ut praesumptio fiat ad ipsum cum ferro, nisi in eo quod est paruum: et tu proba ipsum, et inuestiga ipsum cum Intromisso.	And in it there is danger, and one should not make an attempt at it with iron, except in that which is small: and you test it, and investigate it with a probe.
Si ergo inuenis ipsum simile nodo pingui, et non est suspensum cum aliqua uenarum: tunc seca ipsum, sicut secantur nodi: et extrahe ipsum cum eo quod continet ex kisti, si est in kisti: et si non, tunc perscrutare totum eius.	If therefore you find it similar to a fatty node, and it is not suspended with any of the veins: then cut it, as nodes are cut: and extract it with that which contains the cyst, if it is in a cyst: and if not, then search out all of it.
Deinde cura locum cum eo quod oportet ex curatione, donec sanetur.	Then treat the area with what is necessary from treatment, until it heals.
¶ De sectione super species Nodorum.	¶ On the surgical treatment of various types of Nodes
Caput XLV.	Chapter 45.
Nodorum multae sunt species, et ego iam dixi omnes species eorum in diuisione: et oportet ut narrem hic differentiam inter Nodum, et Exituram: cum sit dubitationem faciens.	There are many types of Nodes, and I have already described all their types in the classification: and here I must explain the difference between a Node and an Abscess, since it can cause confusion.
Dico ergo, quod cum Exitura est caliditas, et febris, et dolores uehementes, donec sedatur ebullitio superfluitatis, et completur putrefactio: tunc enim quiescunt febris et calor.	Therefore I say that with an Abscess there is heat, and fever, and severe pains, until the boiling of the superfluity subsides, and putrefaction is complete: for then the fever and heat cease.
Cum Nodo uero non est caliditas, neque febris, neque dolores, et continet eos kistis sifachin, qui est eis saccus proprius, et est secundum colorem corporis: et est incaeptio eorum sicut cicer, et fit sicut batecha, et maior et minor.	With a Node however there is no heat, nor fever, nor pains, and they are contained within a membranous cyst, which is their proper sac, and it is the same color as the body: and they begin the size of a chickpea, and become like a melon, and larger and smaller.
Et sunt secundum duas species: aut pingues: aut continent humiditatem.	And they are of two types: either fatty, or containing fluid.
Et colores humiditatis sunt multi, secundum quod dixi in diuisione.	And the colors of the fluid are many, according to what I said in the classification.
Oportet ergo, quando peruenis ad curationem Nodi, ut experiaris eum, et inquiras ipsum in primis cum instrumento quod nominatur Intromissum, secundum quod ueniet forma eius in capitulo quod est post hoc.	Therefore, when you come to treat a Node, you must examine it and investigate it first with an instrument called the Probe, according to the form that will be shown in the chapter after this.
Et modus inquisitionis apostematum, et Nodorum omnium est, ut accipias hoc instrumentum, et intromittas ipsum in humidiorem locum, quem inuenis in apostemate: et tu reuolue digitos tuos cum eo paulatim, donec scias quod instrumentum iam penetrauit cutem.	And the method of investigating swellings and all Nodes is that you take this instrument and insert it into the most fluid place that you find in the swelling: and you rotate your fingers with it gradually until you know that the instrument has penetrated the skin.
Deinde ultima manum tuam secundum mensuram magnitudinis apostematis.	Then advance your hand according to the size of the swelling.
Deinde extrahe Intromissum, et considera illud quod egrediur in uestigio eius.	Then withdraw the Probe and examine what comes out in its track.
Si ergo egreditur humiditas currens, quicunque color sit: tunc seca ipsum sectione superficiali, secundum quod dixi in reliquis apostematibus.	If therefore fluid comes out, whatever color it may be: then cut it with a superficial incision, according to what I said regarding other swellings.
Et si non egreditur humiditas in uestigio Intromissi, tunc scias quia est pinguis: seca ergo super ipsum sectione habente formam crucis, secundum formam hanc, sicut docui te: et suspende ipsum cum uncinis, et excoria cutem ab omni parte cum facilitate: et custodi kistin si potes super illud, ut extrahas ipsam sanam cum Nodo.	And if no fluid comes out in the track of the Probe, then know that it is fatty: therefore cut over it with a cruciform incision, according to this form, as I taught you: and hold it with hooks, and carefully separate the skin from all sides: and preserve the cyst if you can, so that you may extract it intact with the Node.
Si autem disrumpitur kistis apud operationem, et non est possibile extrahere ipsam sanam, multotiens enim accidit illud, tunc extrahe ipsam frustatim, donec non remaneat ex ea aliquid.	But if the cyst ruptures during the operation, and it is not possible to extract it intact, for this often happens, then extract it piece by piece until none of it remains.
Nam si remanet ex ea aliquid parum, aut multum, redit Nodus secundum plurimum.	For if any of it remains, whether little or much, the Node usually returns.
Quod si uincit te, et remanet ex eo parum: tunc imple uulnus apud completionem tuam, quibusdam pulueribus corrosiuis acutis: et stringe uulnus, et pone supra ipsum quod sedet apostema calidum, et cura ipsum cum reliqua curatione, donec sanetur.	But if it defeats you, and a little remains: then fill the wound upon your completion with some sharp corrosive powders: and bind the wound, and place upon it what calms a hot swelling, and treat it with the remaining treatment until it heals.
Si ergo est Nodus magnus, tunc sue duo labia eius, et cura ipsum cum eo quod incarnat.	If therefore the Node is large, then suture its two edges, and treat it with what causes flesh to grow.
Si autem est tibi contraria uena pulsatilis, aut non pulsatilis: tunc propera, et imple locum zegi trito, et dimitte ipsum strictum duobus diebus, aut tribus, donec putrefiat uulnus, et quiescat ebullitio sanguinis: deinde redi ad incidendum illud quod remansit ex Nodo.	But if you encounter a pulsating or non-pulsating vein: then hurry and fill the place with ground vitriol, and leave it bound for two or three days, until the wound putrefies and the blood's boiling subsides: then return to cutting what remained of the Node.
¶ De foris instrumentorum pro sectione et perforatione.	¶ On the forms of instruments for cutting and perforation.
Caput XLVI.	Chapter 46.
EX Eis sunt formae Intromissorum, et sunt trium specierum.	Among these are the forms of probes, and they are of three types.
Ex eis enim est magnum, et ex eis est medium, et ex eis est paruum.	Of these, one is large, one is medium, and one is small.
Fiant ex ferro alfulud quadratarum extremitatum decenter, ut festinent introitum in apostemate.	They are made of iron with squared ends appropriately, so that they may quickly enter into abscesses.
Et istae sunt formae Experientium, et no, id est, perforantia: et unum eorum nominatur beris, idest, peforans: et sunt trium specierum.	And these are the forms of probes, and of perforating instruments: and one of them is called beris, that is, perforator: and they are of three types.
Ex eis enim est magnum, et medium, et paruum.	Of these indeed is large, medium, and small.
Conueniunt, ut inuestigentur per ea apostemata, et exiturae, et fistulae, et bubones ab eo quod inter ea est ex ossibus.	They are suitable for investigating abscesses, lesions, fistulas, and swellings from what lies between them in the bones.
Et aliis fiunt rotunda, tersa, lenia, sicut acus magnae quibus subsellia suuntur, ex citrino scilicet, aut ex aere, aut ferro, aut argento.	And others are made round, smooth, polished, like large needles with which cushions are sewn, made from brass, or from bronze, or iron, or silver.
Et meliora eorum sunt quae fiunt ex citrino.	And the best of them are those made from brass.
Et fiunt Experientia etiam de plumbo nigro, quae conueniunt ut per ea experiantur fistulae, quarum concauitate sunt reflexiones, ut reflectantur cum lenitate sua cum illis reflexionibus.	And probes are also made from black lead, which are suitable for examining fistulas that have bends in their cavity, so that they may bend with their smoothness along those curves.
Et sunt iterum trium specierum.	And again they are of three types.
Quoniam ex eis sunt longa, ex eis media, et ex eis breuia, secundum quantitatem amplitudinis fistulae et stricturae eius.	For among them are long ones, medium ones, and short ones, according to the size of the width of the fistula and its narrowness.
Forma Vncinorum, et sunt multarum specierum.	The form of hooks, and they are of many types.
Quoniam ex eis sunt simplices, scilicet quibus est curuitas una: et sunt trium specierum sicut uides, Magni, Medii, et Parui.	For among them are simple ones, namely those which have one curve: and they are of three types as you see, Large, Medium, and Small.
Et ex eis sunt Vncini caeci: et sunt trium specierum.	And among them are blind hooks: and they are of three types.
Et ex eis sunt uncini habentes duas curuaturas, et sunt trium specierum: et ex eis sunt uncini habentes tres curuaturas, et sunt trium specierum: et omnes isti sunt necessarii in loco suo.	And among them are hooks having two curves, and they are of three types: and among them are hooks having three curves, and they are of three types: and all these are necessary in their place.
Et istae sunt formae Scalpellorum, quibus secantur et excoriantur Nodi, et apostemata: et sunt trium specierum: quoniam ex eis est magnum, medium, et paruum.	And these are the forms of scalpels, with which nodes and abscesses are cut and excoriated: and they are of three types: for among them is large, medium, and small.
Eorum extremitates quibus fit sectio sunt acutae, extremitates aliae sunt non acutae: et non ponuntur taliter, nisi ut cum eis fiat iuuamentum in excoriatione Nodorum apud timorem incisionis uenae, aut nerui: et ut sanetur per ea infirmus, et inueniat tranquillitatem parumper ex adustione quam inuenit apud excoriationem apostematis.	Their ends with which cutting is done are sharp, the other ends are not sharp: and they are not made thus, except that with them help may be given in the excoriation of nodes when there is fear of cutting a vein or nerve: and that through them the patient may be healed, and find some relief from the burning which occurs during the excoriation of an abscess.
Istae sunt Magda, et sunt specierum trium.	These are probes (Magda), and they are of three types.
Fiunt ex aere, et sunt similia Radio, cum quo fit alcohol: et in extremitate lata est puncta Spatumilis occultata: et in ea currit ad interiora, et ad exteriora quando uis, sicut uides.	They are made of bronze, and are similar to the stick with which kohl is applied: and in the broad end there is a hidden spatula point: and in it runs to the interior and to the exterior when you wish, as you see.
Forma Spatumilium quae absconduntur inter digitos apud perforationem apostematum: et non percipiunt ea infirmi: et sunt trium specierum, magnum, medium, et paruum.	The form of spatulas which are hidden between the fingers when perforating abscesses: and patients do not perceive them: and they are of three types, large, medium, and small.
Fomae Ventosarum cum quibus abscinditur fluxus sanguinis: et sunt trium specierum, magnae, mediae, et paruae.	The forms of cupping vessels with which blood flow is stopped: and they are of three types, large, medium, and small.
Fiant ex aere, aut citrino, rotundae, ad longitudinem parumper, sicut uides: et sint ad subtilitatem.	They are made of bronze or brass, round, somewhat elongated, as you see: and they should be rather thin.
Et oportet ut sint istae species Ventosarum apud te magnae, et paruae: ut abscindas per eas sanguinem cum uelocitate apud necessitatem, et tunc quando non est tibi praesens medicina.	And it is necessary that these types of cupping vessels be available to you, large and small: so that you may stop blood flow quickly when necessary, and then when medicine is not present to you.
Verumtamen non utaris eis in abscisione sanguinis in omni loco corporis, et non utaris nisi in locis carnosis: sicut lacertis cruris, et coxae, et lacertis brachiorum, et mammillarum, et uentris, et inguinum, et similibus eis, ex lacertis carnosis, humidis.	However, do not use them for stopping blood in every part of the body, and do not use them except in fleshy places: such as the muscles of the leg, and thigh, and muscles of the arms, and breasts, and belly, and groin, and similar to these, from among the fleshy, moist muscles.
Et quandoque fiunt ex eis instrumenta parua alia similia corticibus fisticorum, secundum suam formam: quibus abscinditur sanguis quando fluit ex loco phlebotomiae, aut apud incisionem uenae, aut arteriae: et quandoque fiunt ex eis rotundae secundum hanc formam.	And sometimes small instruments are made from these similar to pistachio shells, according to their form: with which blood is stopped when it flows from the place of bloodletting, or during the cutting of a vein or artery: and sometimes they are made round according to this form.
¶ De cura Mammillarum hominum quae mammillis mulierum assimilantur.	On the treatment of men's breasts which resemble women's breasts.
Caput XLVII.	Chapter 47.
Quandoque inflantur Mammillae quorundam hominum apud complementum somni (id est, cum incipiunt pollui in somno) donec similantur mammillis mulierum: et remanent apostemosae foede.	Sometimes the breasts of certain men swell at the completion of sleep (that is, when they begin to have nocturnal emissions) until they resemble women's breasts: and they remain swollen in an unsightly way.
Qui ergo abhorret illud, oportet ut secet super mammillas sectione lunari, secundum hanc formam ex linea, b. ad lineam, g. Deinde excoria pinguedinem totam.	Therefore, whoever abhors this condition should cut above the breasts with a lunar incision, according to this form from line b. to line g. Then strip away all the fat.
Postea imple uulnus ex medicamine incarnatiuo.	Afterward, fill the wound with flesh-generating medicine.
Deinde aggrega duo labia uulneris cum sutura, et cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then bring together the two lips of the wound with sutures, and treat it until it heals.
Si autem declinat mammilla ad inferiora, et mollificatur propter magnitudinem suam, sicut accidit mulieribus: tunc oportet ut findatur in duobus lateribus suis superioribus duabus sectionibus similibus figurae lunari, quarum unaquaeque continetur cum altera apud fines utriusque, donec sit linea maior continens minorem, secundum hanc formam ex linea, b. ad lineam, g. Postea excoria cutem quae est inter duo labia, et aufer pinguedinem, et administra quod diximus de sutura et pulueribus, quod est necessarium ex curatione, donec sanetur.	If however the breast droops downward and becomes soft due to its size, as happens in women: then it is necessary to make two incisions on its upper sides similar to the lunar figure, each of which connects with the other at both ends, so that the larger line contains the smaller one, according to this form from line b. to line g. Afterward strip away the skin that is between the two lips, and remove the fat, and apply what we mentioned about sutures and powders, which is necessary for treatment, until it heals.
Si autem non comples incisionem eius quod oportet te incidere, propter inquietudinem infirmi, aut propter fluxum sanguinis: tunc oportet ut impleas uulnus coto submerso unguento corrosiuo, et dimitte ipsum, donec corrodat illud quod remansit ex pinguedine.	If however you cannot complete the incision of what you need to cut, due to the patient's restlessness, or due to blood flow: then you should fill the wound with cotton soaked in corrosive ointment, and leave it until it corrodes what remains of the fat.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then treat it until it heals.
¶ De perforatione apostematis, quod accidit sub Titillico.	On the perforation of swellings that occur under the armpit.
Caput XLVIII.	Chapter 48.
Ista apostemata quae accidunt sub Titillico, sunt ex speciebus Strophularum dura, quae continet kistis, et ex eis sunt quae continent humiditates.	These swellings that occur under the armpit are of the types of hard scrofula which contain cysts, and some of them contain fluids.
Quae ergo sunt ex eis quae continent humiditates, oportet ut secentur sectione lunari, secundum hanc formam, ex linea b. ad lineam, g. cum ergo euacuatur totum quod est in apostemate ex sanie, tunc imple ipsum coto ueteri, et dimitte ipsum usque ad diem alium.	Therefore those of them which contain fluids should be cut with a lunar incision, according to this form, from line b. to line g. When therefore all the pus that is in the swelling is evacuated, then fill it with old cotton, and leave it until another day.
Deinde auferatur cotum, et curetur cum unguento conueniente ad illud, donec sanetur.	Then remove the cotton, and treat it with suitable ointment until it heals.
Quod si apostema fuerit ex specie nodorum Strophularum, tunc scinde super ipsum, sicut diximus in sectione super Strophulas aequaliter.	But if the swelling is of the type of scrofulous nodes, then cut into it, just as we described in the section on scrofula similarly.
Si autem extenditur uulnus in hoc ut emittat pus, tunc administra in eo cauterium, secundum quod diximus in eo quod praemissum est.	If however the wound extends to emit pus, then apply cautery to it, according to what we described previously.
¶ De sectione apostematis quod accidit propter Arteriam et Venam.	On cutting swellings that occur due to arteries and veins.
Caput XLIX.	Chapter 49.
Quando disrumpitur Arteria, et consolidatur cutis quae est supra eam, tuno multotiens accidit inde apostema: et similiter accidit Venae etiam, ut accidat in ea apostema et inflatio.	When an artery ruptures, and the skin above it heals over, then often a swelling occurs from this: and similarly it happens with veins also, that swelling and inflammation occur in them.
Et signa quibus cognoscitur, quod apostema et inflatio sint propter Arteriam et Venam, sunt: quoniam, quando apostema est propter arteriam, est longum, aggregatum in profundo corporis: et quando impellis apostema digits tuis, sentis quasi sit ei stridor.	And the signs by which it is known that the swelling and inflammation are due to an artery and vein are: that when the swelling is due to an artery, it is long, gathered in the depth of the body: and when you push the swelling with your fingers, you feel as if it has a whistling sound.
Et illud quod est propter Venam, est rotundum in manifesto corporis.	And that which is due to a vein is round and visible on the body's surface.
Et sectio super hoc apostema est error, et praecipue quod est sub ascellis, et inguinibus, et collo, et in locis multis corporis: et est magnum ualde.	And cutting into this type of swelling is an error, especially that which is under the armpits, and groin, and neck, and in many places of the body: and it is very dangerous.
Oportet ergo ut deuitetur eius cura cum ferro, et quod ex eis etiam est in extremitatibus, aut in capite, oportet ut deuitetur.	Therefore its treatment with iron [surgical instruments] should be avoided, and those of them which are in the extremities, or in the head, should be avoided.
Super illud ergo quod ex eis est ex inflatione orificii Arteriae, finde in cute sectione in longitudine.	Therefore for that which is from inflation of the artery's opening, make an incision in the skin lengthwise.
Deinde aperi sectionem cum uncinis, postea Arteriam: et libera eam ex tunicis, donec detegatur.	Then open the incision with hooks, then the artery: and free it from its coverings, until it is exposed.
Deinde intromitte sub ea acum, et fac eam penetrare usque ad latus aliud, et stringe Arteriam cum filo duplo in duobus locis, secundum quod docui te in extractione duarum Arteriarum quae sunt in timporibus.	Then introduce a needle under it, and make it penetrate to the other side, and tie the artery with a double thread in two places, according to what I taught you in the extraction of the two arteries which are in the temples.
Deinde punge locum, qui est inter duo ligamenta cum spatumili, donec egrediatur sanguis qui est in eo totus, et soluatur apostema.	Then puncture the place which is between the two ligatures with a spatula, until all the blood which is in it comes out, and the swelling is resolved.
Deinde administra curationem quae generat pus, donec cadant ligamenta: postea cura illud cum unguentis conuenientibus ad illud, donec sanetur.	Then administer treatment which generates pus, until the ligatures fall off: afterward treat it with ointments suitable for that, until it heals.
Quod si fuerit apostema propter sectionem Venae, tunc oportet ut teneas manu tua quod tibi possibile est ex apostemate cum cute.	If there is an abscess due to cutting a vein, then you should hold with your hand as much of the abscess with the skin as you can.
Deinde intromitte acum sub loco quem tenuisti manu tua, et fac eam penetrare: et sit in ea filum duplum, donec extrahas ipsum ex latere altero.	Then insert a needle under the place which you held with your hand, and make it penetrate: and let there be a double thread in it, until you draw it out from the other side.
Deinde liga cum ipso apostema ligamento bono: secundum quod dixi tibi in ligamento uuae, a duabus partibus cum duabus extremitatibus fili.	Then bind the abscess with this thread with a good binding: according to what I told you about binding a grape, from two parts with the two ends of the thread.
Si autem times quod extrahatur filum, tunc intromitte acum aliam cum filo alio sub apostemate toto apud incisionem acus: preme, et stringe fila tua in quatuor locis.	If however you fear that the thread might come out, then insert another needle with another thread under the whole abscess near the first needle's incision: press, and tighten your threads in four places.
Deinde seca apostema in medio sui, donec quando egreditur quod in eo est: tunc incide superfluitatem cutis, et dimitte quod ligatum est ex ea.	Then cut the abscess in its middle, until what is inside comes out: then cut away the excess skin, and leave what is bound from it.
Deinde pone super ipsum puluillum quem submersisti in uino, et oleo.	Then place upon it a compress which you have soaked in wine and oil.
Deinde administra curationem, quae fit cum liciniis et unguentis, donec sanetur.	Then administer treatment, which is done with lint and ointments, until it heals.
¶ De apostemate quod accidit ex torsione Neruorum.	¶ Concerning the abscess which occurs from twisting of Nerves.
Caput L.	Chapter 50.
Sicut accidit apostema in Arteria et Vena, similiter accidit apostema in Neruis: quod accidit in eis percussio, aut accidit a labore superfluo, et similibus: et fit plurimum illis in locis adiutoriorum, aut calcanei, et in omni loco in quo mouentur iuncturae: et est apostema graue.	Just as an abscess occurs in Artery and Vein, similarly an abscess occurs in Nerves: which occurs in them from a blow, or occurs from excessive work, and similar things: and it happens most often in those places of the upper arms, or heel, and in every place where joints move: and it is a serious abscess.
Similatur color eius reliquo corpori, et est in pluribus dispositionibus absque dolore: et quando stringitur cum uehementia, sentit in eo infirmus simile stupori.	Its color resembles the rest of the body, and is in most conditions without pain: and when it is pressed firmly, the patient feels something like numbness in it.
Et non est apostema aggregatum in profundo corporis, imo est sub cute, et ipsum mouetur ad omnem partem, et non uadit ad anteriora, uel ante, neque retro ad posteriora.	And it is not an abscess gathered in the depth of the body, but rather is under the skin, and it moves to every part, and does not go forward, or ahead, nor backward to the rear.
Quod ergo ex eis est in iuncturis, non oportet ut inuadatur cum ferro.	Therefore those of them that are in joints, should not be invaded with iron.
Fortasse enim accidet contractio.	For perhaps contraction will occur.
In illo autem quod ex eis est in capite, aut in fronte, finde cutem cum spatumili.	But in that which is of them in the head, or in the forehead, split the skin with a spatula.
Si ergo est apostema paruum, tunc tene ipsum cum forficibus, et abscinde ipsum a radice.	If therefore the abscess is small, then hold it with forceps, and cut it off from the root.
Et si est magnum, tunc suspende ipsum eum uncino, et excoria ipsum: deinde aufer ipsum, et aggrega uulnus cum sutura: et cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	And if it is large, then suspend it with a hook, and flay it: then remove it, and join the wound with suture: and treat it until it heals.
¶ De sectione apostematis, quod accidit in uentre.	¶ Concerning the cutting of an abscess, which occurs in the belly.
Caput LI.	Chapter 51.
Accidunt quibusdam hominibus multotiens in uentribus eorum, et in reliquis corporibus ipsorum, thelil, quae nominantur Fungalia, per similitudinem ipsorum cum fungis.	There occur in some people many times in their bellies, and in other parts of their bodies, warts, which are called Fungal, due to their similarity with mushrooms.
Quorum radix est subtilis, et ipsorum caput est grossum, et conuersa sunt labia eorum.	Whose root is thin, and their head is thick, and their edges are turned outward.
Et est ex eis paruum: et est ex eis quod magnificatur ualde.	And some of them are small: and some of them become very large.
Et ego quidem iam uidi uirum, et in uentre eius erant duo thelil, quae erant magis quam rebus aliis similia fungis: non erat differentia inter ea, alba, minutae radicis, et inuersabantur labia eorum, et findebantur, et humiditas currebat ex eis semper.	And I indeed have seen a man, and in his belly there were two warts, which were more similar to mushrooms than other things: there was no difference between them, white, of minute root, and their edges were turned outward, and they were split, and moisture always ran from them.
Incidi ergo ea, et inueni in pondere unius quasi X et VIII uncia et in altero quasi VI uncia Et operatio in incisione eorum est, ut consideres tunc, si infirmus est humidus, et color thelil est albus, humidum, subtilis radicis: tunc incide ipsum cum spatumili lato, et sint in praesentia tua cauteria in igne.	Therefore I cut them, and found in the weight of one about 18 ounces and in the other about 6 ounces And the operation in cutting them is, that you consider then, if the patient is moist, and the color of the wart is white, moist, of thin root: then cut it with a broad spatula, and let there be cauteries in the fire in your presence.
Multotiens enim expellitur apud sectionem eius sanguis multus: propera ergo si te uincit sanguis, tunc cauteriza ipsum.	For many times during its cutting much blood is expelled: hurry therefore if blood overcomes you, then cauterize it.
Quod si uides infirmum pauidum et timidum ab incisione cum ferro, tunc accipe filum ex plumbo decenter factum, et stringe cum eo athelul: cuius modus est quem diximus, et dimitte ipsum duobus diebus.	But if you see the patient fearful and afraid of cutting with iron, then take a thread of lead properly made, and bind the wart with it: whose method is what we have said, and leave it for two days.
Deinde adde in strictura plumbi.	Then increase in the tightness of the lead.
Non ergo cesses stringere plumbum, quotiens imprimit in thelil, donec abscindatur, et cadat per se absque labore.	Therefore do not cease to tighten the lead, as often as it makes an impression in the wart, until it is cut off, and falls by itself without effort.
Si autem thelil grossae fuerit radicis, tunc in incisione eius est quiddam timoris et pauoris: praecipue quod est in uentre.	If however the wart should be of thick root, then in cutting it there is something of fear and dread: especially that which is in the belly.
Verumtamen possibile est, ut incidas medietatem eius.	Nevertheless it is possible, that you cut half of it.
Deinde cauteriza ipsum, ut non redeat.	Then cauterize it, so that it does not return.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur uulnus.	Then treat it, until the wound heals.
Et caue ne praesumas incidere thelil quod est fusci coloris, pauci sensus, foedi aspectus: ipsum enim est apostema cancerosum: et ego ueniam cum rememoratione Cancri post hoc.	And beware lest you presume to cut a wart which is of dark color, of little sensation, of foul appearance: for it is a cancerous abscess: and I will come with the remembrance of Cancer after this.
¶ De cura eminentiae Vmbilici.	On the Treatment of Protruding Navel.
Caput LII.	Chapter 52.
Fit eminentia Vmbilici ex caussis multis.	A protruding navel occurs from many causes.
Aut ex fissuris sifac, quod super uentrem est: et exit ex eo althub, aut intestinum, secundum quod accidit in reliquis rupturis.	Either from tears in the sifac [abdominal wall] which is above the belly: and from it emerges the althub [omentum], or intestine, according to what happens in other ruptures.
Aut ex sanguine qui fluit ex Vena, aut ex Arteria, secundum quod praemissum est.	Or from blood that flows from a Vein, or from an Artery, according to what was mentioned before.
Aut ex uentositate coartata in eo.	Or from trapped wind in it.
Si autem est propter fissuram sifac, et exitum thirbi: tunc est color apostematis similis colori corporis: et est lene, absque dolore: et apparet diuersi situs.	If however it is due to a tear in the sifac, and exit of the omentum: then the color of the swelling is similar to the color of the body: and it is smooth, without pain: and appears in different positions.
Et si est propter egressionem intestini, tunc est situs eius, cum eo quod narrauimus, uehementioris diuersitatis.	And if it is due to the protrusion of intestine, then its position, with what we have described, is of greater variability.
Cum ergo tu premis ipsum digitis tuis, occultatur: deinde redit, et fortasse est cum eo sonitus: et magnificatur multum apud introitum balnei, et laborem uehaementum.	When therefore you press it with your fingers, it disappears: then returns, and perhaps there is a sound with it: and it greatly increases upon entering the bath, and with vigorous exercise.
Si uero est propter humiditatem, est lene, tunc non occultatur quando premis ipsum manu tua, neque constringium, neque additur.	If indeed it is due to fluid, it is smooth, then it does not disappear when you press it with your hand, nor is it constricted, nor does it increase.
Quod si est propter sanguinem, tunc cum istis signis apparet apostema ad nigredinem de cliue.	But if it is due to blood, then with these signs the swelling appears declining toward blackness.
Si autem est propter carnem natam: tunc est apostema graue, grossum, durum, et figitur secundum quantitatem unam.	If however it is due to grown flesh: then the swelling is heavy, thick, hard, and fixed in one size.
Si uero est propter uentositatem, tunc tactus eius est lenis.	If indeed it is due to wind, then its touch is smooth.
Et operatio in illo est, ut consideres tunc, si eminentia umbilici est propter sanguinem Arteriae, aut Venae, aut uentositatem: tunc oportet ut prohibearis a curatione eius.	And the procedure in that case is, that you should consider then, if the protrusion of the navel is due to blood from an Artery, or Vein, or wind: then you must refrain from treating it.
Nam in illo est timor et pauor, sicut docui te in capitulo, in quo dixi apostemata propter arteriam et uenam.	For in that there is fear and dread, as I taught you in the chapter in which I spoke of swellings due to artery and vein.
Quod si eminentia umbilici est propter intestinum, aut zirbum: tunc oportet ut praecipias infirmo, quatenus teneat anhelitum suum, et stet stans extensus.	But if the protrusion of the navel is due to intestine, or omentum: then you must instruct the patient to hold their breath, and stand upright extended.
Deinde signa cum encaustro in circumitu umbilici totius.	Then mark with ink around the entire navel.
Postea praecipe ei, ut resupinetur inter manus tuas super dorsum suum.	Afterward command them to lie back between your hands upon their back.
Deinde circunda cum spatumili lato in circumitu umbilici super locum quem signasti cum encaustro.	Then encircle with a broad spatula around the navel above the place which you marked with ink.
Postea extende medium apostematis ad superiora, cum uncino magno.	Afterward extend the middle of the swelling upward, with a large hook.
Deinde liga eum in circumitu forti cum filo, aut cum chorda de serico ligamento firmo: et sit nodus ligamenti alenxotati.	Then bind it around firmly with thread, or with silk cord in a secure binding: and let the knot of the binding be of the alenxotati type [special surgical knot].
Deinde aperi medium apostematis extensum supra ligamentum.	Then open the middle of the swelling extended above the binding.
Si ergo inueneris ipsum iam captum a ligamento: tunc extrahe alenxotati, et intromitte in ipsum digitum indicem, et impelle intestinum ad interiora uentris: et si inueneris zirbum, tunc accipe ipsum cum uncino, et incide superfluitatem eius.	If therefore you find it has been caught by the binding: then remove the alenxotati, and insert your index finger, and push the intestine to the interior of the belly: and if you find omentum, then take it with a hook, and cut off its excess.
Si autem contraria est tibi arteria, aut uena: tunc circunda ipsum multum.	If however an artery or vein opposes you: then encircle it extensively.
Deinde redi ad operationem tuam.	Then return to your procedure.
Et accipe duas acus, et intromitte in eis duo fila fortia: et intromitte duas acus in circumitu quem fecisti circa apostema in modum crucis, quas facis penetrare.	And take two needles, and insert in them two strong threads: and insert the two needles around what you made around the swelling in the form of a cross, which you make penetrate.
Deinde stringe apostema in quatuor locis super acus: et si uis, aufer acus, et dimitte locum, donec putrefiat caro extensa: et cadat per se: aut incide ipsam quando subtiliatur et putrefit.	Then tighten the swelling in four places above the needles: and if you wish, remove the needles, and leave the place until the extended flesh putrefies: and falls off by itself: or cut it when it becomes thin and putrefied.
Deinde cura ipsum cum eo quod oportet ex unguentis, donec sanetur.	Then treat it with what is necessary from ointments, until it heals.
Quod si eminentia umbilici est ex carne nara in eo, aut ex humiditate: tunc oportet ut concaues apostema, sicut diximus.	But if the protrusion of the navel is from flesh grown in it, or from fluid: then you must hollow out the swelling, as we said.
Et extrahas sanguinem, aut humiditatem, quam inuenis in eo.	And extract the blood, or fluid, which you find in it.
Deinde cura ipsum cum eo quod solidat locum.	Then treat it with what solidifies the area.
¶ De cura CANCRI.	On the treatment of CANCER.
Caput LIII.	Chapter 53.
Iam diximus in diuisione species Cancri, et qualiter est uia ad curationem eius cum medicinis: et cauendum ab eo cum curatione eius cum ferro, ut non ulceretur: et diximus Cancrum generatum in matrice, et cautelam a curatione eius.	We have already discussed in the classification the types of Cancer, and how it may be treated with medicines: and that treatment with iron [surgery] should be avoided, lest it become ulcerated: and we discussed Cancer generated in the womb, and the precaution in treating it.
Et dixerunt antiqui, quod quandoque Cancer est in loco, ubi possibilis est eius eradicatio: sicut Cancer qui est in mammillis, aut in coxa, et eis similibus, ex membris locatis ad extrahendum totum eius: praecipue quando est incipiens paruus.	And the ancients said that sometimes Cancer is in a place where its eradication is possible: like Cancer that is in the breasts, or in the hip, and similar ones, from members situated for extracting all of it: especially when it is small and beginning.
Quando uero antiquatur, et est magnus, non oportet ut appropinques ei.	When it is old and large, you should not approach it.
Ego enim non potui sanare ex eo aliquem: neque uidi alium ante me qui peruenerit ad illud.	For I have not been able to cure any of it: nor have I seen another before me who achieved that.
Et operatio in eo, quando est locatus sicut diximus, est, ut praecedas, et soluas infirmum ex cholera nigra aliquotiens.	And the operation on it, when it is situated as we said, is that you should proceed first and purge the patient of black bile several times.
Deinde phlebotoma ipsum si inuenis cum repletione manifesta.	Then bleed them if you find obvious fullness [of blood].
Deinde praepara infirmum praeparatione, in qua locetur cum operatione.	Then prepare the patient with preparation, in which they are positioned for the operation.
Deinde proiice in Cancrum uncinos qui conueniunt ei.	Then cast suitable hooks into the Cancer.
Postea concaua ipsum ab omni parte cum cute, secundum perscrutationem, donec non remaneat aliquid ex radicibus eius: et dimitte sanguinem currere, et non abscindas ipsum uelociter, imo exprime loca, et absterge sanguinem grossum totum manu tua, aut cum quo possibile est ibi ex instrumentis.	Afterwards hollow it out from all sides with the skin, according to careful examination, until none of its roots remain: and let the blood flow, and do not cut it off quickly, rather compress the areas, and wipe away all the thick blood with your hand, or with whatever instruments are possible there.
Si autem contrarietatem facit tibi fluxus sanguinis grossi ex incisione arteriae, aut uenae: tunc cauteriza uenam, donec abscindatur sanguis.	If however the flow of thick blood from cutting an artery or vein gives you trouble: then cauterize the vein until the blood is stopped.
Deinde cura ipsum cum reliqua curatione, donec sanetur.	Then treat it with the remaining treatment until it heals.
¶ De cura Hydropisis.	On the treatment of DROPSY.
Caput LIIII.	Chapter 54.
Iam narrauimus in diuisione species Hydropisis, et qualiter fit aggregatio aquae: et signa omnis speciei, et curationem eius cum medicinis.	We have already described in the classification the types of Dropsy, and how water accumulates: and the signs of every type, and its treatment with medicines.
Et illa quae curatur cum ferro, non est nisi species asclitis sola: et non approximatur cum ferro speciei timpanitis: neque speciei hyposarcae penitus: nam illud mortale est.	And that which is treated with iron is only the ascitic type alone: and the tympanitic type should not be approached with iron: nor the hyposarca type at all: for that is fatal.
Quando tu iam medicatus es hanc speciem Hydropisis timpanitis cum medicinis, et non contulit medicatio tua: tunc considera.	When you have already treated this tympanitic type of Dropsy with medicines, and your treatment has not helped: then consider.
Nam si infirmo iam consecuta est debilitas, aut est cum eo infirmitas alia praeter Hydropisim: sicut si sit cum eo tussis, aut uentris solutio, et similia illis: tunc caue ne mediceris ei cum ferro: quoniam est timor illud.	For if weakness has already followed in the patient, or there is another illness besides Dropsy: such as if they have a cough, or looseness of the belly, and similar things: then beware of treating them with iron: since that is dangerous.
Si autem uides infirmum exuberantis uirtutis, neque est cum eo aegritudo praeter Hydropisim solam: et non est puer, neque senex: tunc modus operationis in eo est, ut tu eleues infirmum stantem inter manus tuas, et minister post ipsum exprimat uentrem eius manu sua impellendo aquam ad inferiorem partem pectinis.	But if you see the patient has abundant strength, and they have no illness besides Dropsy alone: and is neither a child nor elderly: then the method of operation on them is that you raise the patient standing between your hands, and an assistant behind them compresses their belly with their hand pushing the water to the lower part of the pubic area.
Deinde accipe spatumile spinosum, secundum hanc formam.	Then take a spiny spatula, according to this form.
Sit duarum partium acutarum, longum, acutae extremitatis sicut Spatumile.	Let it be of two sharp parts, long, with a sharp end like a Spatula.
Verumtamen in eo sit quiddam breuitatis paulatim, ut non pertranseas cum eo apud operationem usque ad intestinum, et laedas ipsum.	However let there be some gradual shortness in it, so that you do not pass through with it during the operation all the way to the intestine, and harm it.
Deinde considera.	Then consider.
Nam si est generatio Hydropisis ex parte intestinorum, tunc oportet ut elongeris cum sectione ab umbilico quantitate trium digitorum, ad inferiora in directo eius supra pectinem.	For if the generation of Dropsy is from the part of the intestines, then you should distance yourself with the incision from the navel by the amount of three fingers, downward in line with it above the pubic area.
Si uero generatio Hydropisis est propter aegritudinem epatis: tunc sit sectio tua sinistra ab umbilico tribus digitis.	If however the generation of Dropsy is due to illness of the liver: then let your incision be to the left of the navel by three fingers.
Et si generatio eius est propter splenem, tunc sit sectio in latere dextro: et non oportet etiam ut sit sectio in latere super quod uult iacere infirmus, ut non currant superfluitates ad illum locum debilem.	And if its generation is due to the spleen, then let the incision be on the right side: and also the incision should not be on the side on which the patient wants to lie, so that excess fluids do not run to that weak place.
Deinde perfora cum instrumento cutem totam.	Then pierce through the whole skin with the instrument.
Deinde intromitte in illam sectionem, et eleua manum tuam cum Spatumili inter cutem, et sifac, quasi tu excories ipsum: et sit quantitas quae excoriatur quantitas unguis, aut circiter ilud.	Then introduce into that incision, and raise your hand with the Spatula between the skin and the peritoneum, as if you are skinning it: and let the amount that is skinned be the amount of a fingernail, or thereabouts.
Deinde perfora sifac, donec perueniat Spatumile ad locum uacuum: et est locus aquae.	Then pierce the peritoneum, until the Spatula reaches the empty space: which is the place of the water.
Deinde extrahe ipsum, et intromitte in foramen instrumentum, cuius haec est forma.	Then remove it, and introduce into the hole an instrument, of which this is the form.
Et est simile cannulae: fit ex argento, aut aere, aut aurichalco, lene, tersum: cui in inferiori parte sui est foramen paruum, et in lateribus eius sunt tria foramina, duo ab una parte, et unum a parte altera: et facia est extremitas eius incisa, secundum modum incisionis calami, sicut uides: in extremitate eius superiore est armilla.	And it is like a small tube: made from silver, or bronze, or brass, smooth, polished: which has a small hole in its lower part, and in its sides are three holes, two on one side, and one on the other side: and its end is cut, in the manner of cutting a reed, as you see: at its upper end is a ring.
Nam quando instrumentum peruenit ad aquam, tunc ipsa descendit statim super instrumentum, ergo euacua ex aqua in hora quantitatem mediam.	For when the instrument reaches the water, then it descends immediately upon the instrument, therefore evacuate half the quantity of water at that time.
Quoniam si tu euacuas ex ea plus quam oportet, in hora fortasse moritur infirmus per resolutionem spiritus sui animalis: aut accidit ei syncopis quae appropinquat morti.	Since if you evacuate more of it than necessary, at that moment the patient may die through the dissolution of his vital spirit: or he may suffer a fainting spell that approaches death.
Verum euacua ex ea secundum quantitatem uirtutis eius, et secundum quod significant tibi dispositiones infirmi ex uirtute pulsus eius, et ex bonitate eius.	Indeed, evacuate from it according to the measure of his strength, and according to what the patient's conditions indicate to you from his pulse strength, and from its quality.
Deinde extrahe instrumentum, et retine aquam.	Then withdraw the instrument, and retain the water.
Quod est, quia retinetur statim propter cutem quae retinet foramen quod est super sifac: de quo narraui, ut perfores ipsum secundum illum modum.	Which is because it is retained immediately due to the skin that holds the opening which is above the peritoneum: about which I told you to pierce it according to that method.
Deinde itera instrumentum die altero, si uides infirmum tolerare illud: et extrahe etiam ex aqua quantitatem paruam.	Then repeat the instrument the next day, if you see the patient can tolerate it: and draw out also a small quantity of water.
